Developments in Washington
SENATE Still looking (or |ust one more vote to win passage, Senate ReDunicans agreed to a showdown today on the balanced budget
amendment. The vote is scheduled for 2 P.M., and the Republican maloni, leader. Bob Dole, pledged that it it failed, he would revive the issue al the height of the 1996 election campaign. He attacked several
Democratic opponents for what he called a "stunning flipflop" on a
measure they voted for a year ago, and other Republican senators criticized President Clinton's opposition, as well. On Tuesday, Mr. Dole
suddenly postponed ihe vote on the amendment when it became clear
that he had just 66 of the 67 votes needed. The decision to have the fi-,
nai vole today came alter apparently unsuccessful attempts to reach a
compromise that would-keep Social Security trust funds off limits to
budget cullers There is no reason a balanced budget-amendment
coma nol pass with nearly 80 votes in a matter of a few mjnutes — if
they're willing lo prolecl Social Security," said Senator Harry Reid. a
Nevada Democrat
1 he latest New York Times/CBS News Poll found that 79 percent of
Americans said they favored a constitutional amendment that would require the Federal Government to balance the budget 2002, but only 32
percent said they were in favor if it would require cuts in Social Security
HOUSE Under intense pressure from Republican governors. House Republican leaders partly reversed themselves and agreed to let some
states use Federal food stamp money to feed poor people in any way
mat state officials wanted Under the agreement, Ihe states could set
their own eligibility criteria and benefit levels, replacing the uniform national standards in the food stamp program. Low-income people now"
receiving food stamps would not necessarily be entitled to food assistance under the new programs. The agreement represents the second
major change on the issue by House Republican leaders in less than a
week
The House-passed Ihe Regulatory Reform and Relief Act. a noncontro- .
versial portion of the Republican agenda for regulatory change. It is intended to make regulations affecting small businesses more flexible

line. Even today, Haley Barbour,
chairman of the Republican National Committee, was visiting the last
Republican holdout against the
amendment, Senator Mark 0. Hatfield of Oregon, pleading for his support for "a must piece of legislation.
for the Republican Party," according to Mr. Hatfield. (The Oregon
Republican said he did not relent.)
But Democrats asserted that Mr.
Dole crossed the line when he stalled .
the proceedings on Tuesday night —
— and warned that he will pay in the
fixture. At issue was the kind of
agreement that is widely used by
party leaders in the Senate to set
forth a rough schedule for debating
and voting on legislation; in this
case, Democrats had agreed for a
series of voles on their amendments
on Feb. 28, followed by a vole on the
overall constitutional amendment itself.
The Senate Parliamentarian noted
that the agreement did not specify
that the main vole would come immediately on Tuesday night without
any intervening business. But Democrats cried foul. " I thought that a
deal was a deal," said Senator Tom
Daschle, ihe Democratic leader. " I
thought that our word was our
bond." Analysts said that without the
understanding that such agreements
would be honored, it would be veryhard to get much done in the Senate.
"They are central and indispensible," said Ross K. Baker, a scholar
on the Senate at Rutgers University.
This fallout carries real danger
for Mr. Dole: a majority can get
things done in a bitterly partisan
House; it can get blocked at every
turn in a bitterly partisan Senate.
1
Democrats, for their part, faced
dangers of their own. If they win the
legislative struggle on Thursday,
thanks in part to the parliamentary
skills of Senator Robert C. Byrd,
they could still lose the political war.
Some Republicans, in fact, argue
that their party can'only profit by
Democrats blocking legislation that
is supported by three-fourths of the
American people.
That explained the careful positioning under way in a series of news
conferences today, when Democrats
made the point again and again that
they do not oppose balancing the
budget, only balancing it with a bad
ly flawed amendment that puts Social Security at risk.
Mr. Byrd spoke with great disdain
this week of a world ruled by "talk
shows, public opinion polls, bumpersticker slogans and a so-called political Contract With America." But
Democrats with more unsettled
seats than Mr. Byrd's were paying
attention to the polls. In fact, Republicans appear to have calculated that
this apprehension, in the end, would
turn the final Democrats to their
cause.
If this week showed anything,
though, it showed thai simple political calculations are a poor predictor
of the United States Senate.

brother was assured of becoming
Speaker, plans to attend the Human . Rights Campaign Fund

member of Congress, Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania; to fight cuts

support for AIDS programs or
increase it. '.

I N D I A N A P O L I S , Feb. 25 .— Except for one day a year, when car?
race at breakneck speed for 500
miles around an oval t r a c k , this unpretentious M i d w e s t e r n c i t y is so
unaccustomed to the national limelight that it' m o c k i n g l y calls itself
"Indy-a-no-place."
But as Indianapolis pursues the
nation's most d a r i n g e x p e r i m e n t in
t r a n s f o r m i n g local government into
a business-like enterprise, this c i t y
of about 800,000 people is a n y t h i n g
but obscure among u r b a n experts
and politicians around the country.
M a y o r Stephen G o l d s m i t h , a Republican, has cut more than $100
m i l l i o n f r o m the m u n i c i p a l budget
since taking office in 1992, l a r g e l y by
f o r c i n g city d e p a r t m e n t s to bid for
contracts against p r i v a t e businesses
on more than 50 services, f r o m f i l l ing potholes to cleaning f i r e engines.
In the process, he has reduced the
n u m b e r of city employees by a quarter, won wage concessions and increased p r o d u c t i v i t y .
Moreover, M r . G o l d s m i t h has won
the backing of unions that had vigorously opposed his election: While he
has cut hundreds of jobs in m i d d l e
m a n a g e m e n t , not a single union
w o r k e r has been laid off.
Big-city m a y o r s f r o m around the
c o u n t r y have been calling to learn
about the p r o g r a m s . M a y o r R i c h a r d
J. R i o r d a n of Los Angeles flew here
to study the Indianapolis strategy
A n d M a y o r G o l d s m i t h has flown to
New Y o r k three times at the invitation of M a y o r Rudolph W. Giuliani to
discuss t h a t . strategy. Indeed, the
v o l u m e of visitors is so heavy that
Indianapolis has scheduled a day in
A p r i l when more than 30 u r b a n experts can visit at one t i m e .
" I t ' s a m a z i n g what G o l d s m i t h has
been able to d o , " said J i m Mercer,
who heads a government consultinf:
group in Atlanta. " E v e r y b o d y is paying attention to h i m . "
It has become a x i o m a t i c in A m e r i can politics that w h a t e v e r public
w o r k e r s can do, p r i v a t e business can
do better. And g o v e r n m e n t s in recent years have begun to hire outside companies to do work usually
done by municipal employees, a
trend known as p r i v a t i z a t i o n .
When he took office, M r . Goldsmith initially planned'to privatize
most city services. And he has done
i in some cases, for e x a m p l e , sellig off the. waste- water t r e a t m e n t
i r v i c e . Bui more often, he has purj e d a strategy known among govrnment a d m i n i s t r a t o r s as c o m p e t i on, which treats the city departicnis as businesses and gives w o r k i s a voice in ways to cut costs. If the
e p a r t m e m can put in a w i n n i n g bid
gainst p r i v a t e competitors, the city
orkers continue to provide that
a r t i c u l a r service and r e m a i n on the
ity payroll.
" T h e issue-is noi public or p r i a i c , " said the 47-yeai-old M a y o r ,
ho is r u m o r e d to be considering a
in for governor next year. " T h e
oblem is monopolies. If you b r i n g
a p r i v a t e contractor w i t h a moipoly, you're not going to be any
!tter off — maybe w o r s e . "
The use of p r i v a t e businesses to
ovide services to city governents dates to the t u r n of the centu.'. But when m a n y of these p r i v a t e
isinesses developed
monopolies
i d took u n f a i r advantage, Progrcsves in the ]920.'s and 30's began
ringing m a n y services under govrnrricni control.
j
'Indy-a-First-Place
. The m o r e recent trend t o w a r d using p r i v a t e companies to provide
c i t y services began largely in 1979 in
Phoenix, which hired outside businesses to collect trash. But in that
case, c i t y departments have won
back jobs in the last few years by
bettering the bids of outside companies.
Indianapolis's 1995 budget of $471
m i l l i o n w i l l include the smallest
n u m b e r of employees in more than
20 years. Since M r . Goldsmith took
office,
total
employment
has
dropped about 25 percent, to 3,870.
Most of the reductions have been
achieved through a t t r i t i o n .
While Indianapolis is pursuing the
most ambitious e f f o r t to t u r n c i t y
departments into businesses, scores
of. m a y o r s around the country are
fine-tuning services in ways that
save money. .
" A t the same t i m e that resources
are d w i n d l i n g , city governments are
being asked to do more than ever —
taking care of the homeless, for exa m p l e , " said Inge F r y k l u n d , who
teaches a course on innovative government techniques at Northwestern University. "So you've got mayors desperately looking for ways to
provide services, and they've got to
be c r e a t i v e . "
M a y o r G o l d s m i t h , who joins a
crew of city employees on a job once
a week, has also won over union
leaders by consulting w i t h w o r k e r s .
" N o b o d y knows better than the
w o r k e r how the job can be done
more e f f i c i e n t l y , " he said. " Y o u
M a n y of the mid-level managers got
their jobs through patronage f r o m
earlier Republican administrations.
The m a y o r ' s office in Indianapolis
has been controlled by Republicans
since 1967.
To be sure, the union has not supported M r . G o l d s m i t h on e v e r y
move. In some cases, like waste water t r e a t m e n t , they note, he decided
not to allow city w o r k e r s to bid on
jobs. The M a y o r argued that some
services were s i m p l y better done by
outside companies.
Critics have said M r . G o l d s m i t h
has sometimes been too hasty. A f t e r
maintenance of city golf courses was
awarded to businesses, the M a r i o n
County prosecutor charged that the
state law on bids was violated. But
he brought no charges, and his successer as prosecutor has not taken
up the case.

Raul Salinas, had been arrested on candidacy to head-the World Trade
charges of arranging the assassina- Organization, a move that had been
widely iexpected.
"In recent days I made it known
that I had chosen to withdraw my
candidacy for the directorship" of
the newly created trade organization, Mr. Salinas said in a statement.
"Today 1 am making it formal."
The political fallout from Raul Salinas's arrest helped push down the
Mexican stock exchange, which lost
a little more than 2 percent to close
at just under 1,518 today.
However, the peso was almost unchanged, closing at 5.945 to the dollar. Interest rates on 28-day treasury
certificates fell 9.3 percentage
points, to 49.7 percent, suggesting
some modest relief from Mexico's
soaring interest rates.
Interviews with several Govern-,
ment officials and statements by the
Bank of Mexico indicate that the
Zedillo administration was persuaded by the nation's business leaders
and bankers to drop its original plan
to let the peso float freely and instead simply to adjust its rate downward by 15 percent against the dollar.
Before this, the peso was worth
nearly 29 cents. The devaluation, on
the first day of the crisis brought it
to just above 25 cents. Today, the
peso is worth less than 17 cents.
The Bank of Mexico, the central
bank, acknowledged that the Government's Exchange Rate Commission decided on Dec. 19 that Mexico
had no choice but to abandon a fixed
exchange rate because its international reserves had dropped below
$11 billion; which was considered insufficient to fight off an attack by
currency speculators. The reserves
have since been reinforced by an
international rescue package that includes $20 billion in American loans
and guarantees.
Members of Mr. Zedillo's Govern- .
ment confirmed that the businessmen opposed any floating exchange
rate at the meeting on Dec 20.
"We went to them with the idea of
a floating rate and they got absolute- •
ly scared,", said one Government
official, referring to the business
leaders and bankers. "But eventual-,
ly they convinced us that a free float
wasn't the right way to go."
Once the Bank of Mexico had disclosed to the bankers and businessmen that it lacked; sufficient reserves to protect the peso, many
went out after the meeting to convert
pesos into dollars. By the evening of Dec. 21, the Government Exchange
Rate Commission was forced: to let
the peso float freely.
Many American investors have
complained that the Mexican Government had either wittingly or unwittingly given Mexican investors
inside information about currency
reserves that allowed them to safeguard their positions before the peso's fixed exchange rate, was abandoned. Mr." Salinas's remarks appear to corroborate their suspicions.
Luis R. Luis, head of research for
Scudder,,Stevens & Clark of Boston,
said that so much money left Mexico
in those two days of December that
it "weakened the last hope the central bank had of having a fixed peso
policy."
But Mr, Luis did not believe that
the economic crisis, which has cost
Mexico hundreds of thousands of
Jobs and lowered almost everyone's
standard of living/ was caused solely
by the mistakes made in December.
"The seeds for the crisis," Mr.
Luis said; "were planted much earlier."

In theory that is possible if Mexico would be
allowed to use its newly borrowed currency reserves to buy back all ihe pesos it is offered at 3.5
pesos lo the dollar. But nonbelievers view revaluation as a recipe for disaster. For unless foreign
investors are miraculously inspired to flood Mexico with dollars, the crunch on Ihe supply of money
as pesos are exchanged at the central bank for
foreign currency would cut deep into consumption
and invest ment.
' . Wages and prices would eventually fall, easing
the. Cash crunch, making Mexican exporis competitive and putting Mexicans back to: work. Or
maybe nol: A long, bitter recession would surely
tempt the ruling party's old guard to play the
nationalism card, jettisoning the economic and
political reforms that have given Mexico a shot at
joining the affluent industrial world.
Supply-side recipe: restore
Mexico's old exchange rate.
W
ITH the wounded Mexican peso trading
at roughly six to the dollar, why are
influential Congressional Republicans
still talking about a return to the pre-crisis exchange rate of 3.5 pesos to the dollar?
A plausible explanation is that the talk is a
- political freebie, a way to capitalize on the Whitie
House's embarrassment over the collapse of the
peso without appearing to sabotage efforts to
, cope with Mexico's financial meltdown. But like
|;many ideas from "supply side" conservatives,
• there is just enough common sense to give a life of
i its own to the notion that currency devaluation
; ;only worsens badly managed economies.
.; Mexico apparently got into trouble because its
• Government did not respond to investors' loss of
; confidence in the economy last year after the
; Chiapas revolt. Indeed, Ihe Salinas administra: lion concealed the fact that Mexico's central bank
'. was spending billions of dollars a month last fall
lo prop up the peso while failing to prevent the
surging growth of the domestic money supply.
The dam burst when the ceniral bank ran out of
. foreign currency to buy back the pesos it had been
busily pumping into the economy to keep interest
rates down and business booming. The exchange
, value of the peso has since fallen by almost half.
reducing living standards in an economy accus. lomed to cheap imports and leaving businesses
; thai owed money in dollars near ruin:
Mainstream economists, including many with
. impeccable conservative credentials, view depreciation of the peso as pari of the solution. If
inflation can be kept in check — a.big " i f " — they
argue Ihat Ihe new exchange rale will make
Mexican exporis more competitive, as well as
: making Mexican securities more attractive to
3'
s:
, Ninilaf Asdu
foreigners. The supply-siders' alternative, using
Mexico's new line of credit from the United Stales
Treasury and the Internationa) Monetary Fund to
restore the old exchange rate, is seen by Steve
Hanke of Johns Hopkins Univeriity as "complete
madness" — and the very opposite of prudent
policy.
But that has not stopped prominent Republicans including Jack Kemp and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, from wondering out loud why
Mexico cannot be held to its old promises never lo
devalue. Nor has it stopped Jude Wanniski, the
doyen of supply-side ideologues, from labeling
devaluation as "a nitwit idea that comes deep
from the heart of Keynesian philosophy."
Mr. Wanniski argues Ihat devaluation is a
breach pf trust with the Mexican middle class,
undermining both their savings and confidence in
free markets. And he dismisses efforts lo make
exports cheaper by depreciating Ihe currency as
a failed nostrum lhal leads to inflalion and more
depreciation. His solution for Mexico (and oiher
countries bullied by "the evil death star known as
the International Monetary Fund") is lo lei il
claw its way back to the pre-crisis exchange rale.
While mainstream economists are thus uniled
in the opposition to revaluation of the peso, they
don't agree on much else. Mr. Hanke argues Ihat
the most plausible way . to restore the peso's
credibility is to put monetary policy on automatic
pilot. He favors the creation of a "currency
board" Ihat would exchange the peso for dollars
at a fixed rate to all comers — and lack the power
to bail out either the Goviemtnent budget or the
banking system.
This approach worked in Europe's colonies in
the 19th century, he says. And il is now working in
Argentina, allowing that nation to shed a centuryold reputation for currency-mismanagement.
Why not try the same in Mexico?
Jeffrey Sachs, an economist at Harvard, concedes lhal currency boards are a plausible last
resori, but argues that the idea of pulling the peso
in a ''straitjacket" is premature. Carefully modulated austerity combined with a new honesty and
iransparcncy in currency mailers, he says, could
do the job with less pain.
He had betlcr be right. For Ihat is plainly the
direction the While House is pushing Mexico, and
Congress is not about lo provide the cash for yet
another rescue allnmpl.

PJIOSCOW, March 1 — One of Russi;»js best-known television jOumalisii, Vladislav Listyev, was killed
toi^ght in a gangland-style murder
in (fie ehtryway of his Moscow apartment building, the police said.
Ir. Listyev, 38, made his reputalio in the glasnost period when he
ofi n sparred on the air with Mikhail
S. iorbachev, the Soviet President,
wh i was striving to remove the
stifling cloak of official lies that
surrounded everything here.
ijlr. Listyev had recently been
nnftied executive director of the reorganized Oslankino television netwofk, a job with major financial
responsibilities. He supported a ban
en .advertising on the channel that
wafc announced on Feb. 20 and due to
ln ^in April 1, There was immediate
sporulalion tonight lhal Mr. Listyev,
whj) was shot in the heart and died
insjantly, was killed, over profits,
ndfl journalism.
Aleksandr Yakovlev, a former PolitWiro member under Mr. Gorbachev and chairman of the board of
thfl}channel, told the Itar-Tass news
agency tonight that he himself had
begun receiving telephone threats
after the decision to stop, showing
advertisements. " We must "have got
in someone's way," Mr. Yakovlev
said, expressing shock at Mr. Listyev's killing.
Mr. .Yakovlev said that Russian
public television recently changed
its methods of selling advertisements, creating an in-house agency
that multiplied the company's advertising revenues seven times,
from $1.1 million a month to $7.8
million.
"The difference must have ended
up in the pockets of some moguls,"
Mr. Yakovlev said. "•
But then the company decided to
suspend showing advertising altogether.
Mr. Listyev was one of three
people behind the hard-hilling news
program, Vzglyad, - or Viewpoint.
More recently, he was the- host of
Chas Pik, or Rush Hour, an interview show modeled on CNN's Larry
King Live.
The last several months brought
many changes to Ostankino. the biggest stale television channel that
re.iches across Ihe entire former So-

advertising may have
created enemies.
viet Union. Last November, President Boris N. Yeltsin made Ostankino Channel One into Russian public television, but the state kept a

The remaining shares were offered to a select group of companies
including Itar-Tass, Aeroflot International Airlines and commercial
banks including Menatep, Stolichny,
Inkombank and Roscredit.
Because of its widespread influence, who controls Russian public
television" is considered crucial to
winning the parliamentary elections
scheduled for December and the
presidenlial vote scheduled for June
1996. Mr. Yakovlev has spoken in the
past of intense political pressure,
saying: "Unfortunately, people
think that to take the Kremlin, they
must first take Ostankino."
Igor Shabdrasulov, a Government
representative on the board, said the
ban on advertising was intended "to
determine the proper correlation between advertising on the one hand
and the interests of economic development and moral criteria on the
other." He said that during Ihe ban,
losses would be offset by private
shareholders.
The day after the ban was announced, Mr. Yeltsin announced a
nationwide ban on advertising tobacco and alcohol products and ads
for popular faith healers. But enforcement is likely to be difficult.
Anatoly Lysenko, director-general
of Ihe state-owned Russian Radio
and Television Company, or Channel
2, warned against the ban, saying
that advertising accounts for a third
of revenue, and companies like Ostankino would be hard-pressed to
come up with the lost money.

�THE NEW YORK TIMES, THURSDAY, MARCH 2, 1995
I.M.F. Loan Is Expected for Ukraine
By PAUL LEWIS
In a development that could have
important implications for economic
change in neighboring Russia,
Ukraine is expected to borrow close
to $1.5 billion from the.International
Monetary Fund later this month.
Ukraine's representative at the'
I.M.F. in Washington, Oleh Havryly. shyn, and Anders Aslund, a Swedish
economic adviser to President Leonid Kuchma of, Ukraine, confirmed
in separate interviews, yesterday
that the Ukranian, Government
would sign a letter this week accepting the l.M.F.'s terms for the loan,
which would be by far the largest the
institution has given any country of
the former Soviet Union. Ukraine, a
country of 52 million people, is sand
wiched between Russia, Poland and
the Black Sea.
The confirmations came after Mr.
Kuchma announced yesterday the
resignation of Prime Minister Vitaly
Masol, a holdover from the, Soviet
era, and replaced him with. First
Deputy Prime Minister Yevhen
Marchuk! who is widely considered
to be more sympathetic to the President's efforts to create a free-enterprise economy in Ukraine.
"This is the beginning of a big
surge forward in Ukraine," Mr. Havrylyshyn said.
Mr. Aslund, who said the l.M.F.'s
:
From a $1.5 billion
pact, new pressure
on Russia.
executive board was likely to give
formal approval to the loan later this
month, described it as "a stamp of
international approval for Ukraine's
effort to transform its economy."
He added that Ukraine had al-.
ready privatized 11,000 state-owned'
enterprises and planned to sell an
additional 8,000 large and mediumsized companies this year. He said it
had also cut its inflation rate from
10,200 percent in 1993 to about 1percent a month and had reducfc'the
budget deficit to the equivalent of 5
percent of the economy's output.
In a further show of support for
Mr. Kuchma and his economic policies, the l.M.F.'s managing director,
Michel Camdessus, will visit Kiev,
the capital, next week, officials said.
The immediate purpose of the new
I.M.F. credit is to help Ukraine gather about $6 billion in foreign economic assistance this , year to finance
economic development.
Mr. Aslund said he hoped to raise
the rest of the money by persuading
Russia to reschedule $2.5 billion in
Ukrainian debts that come due this
year for imports of oil and natural
gas and to get money from the World
Bank, the United States, Western
Europe and Japan.
But he warned that Ukraine's success in borrowing from the I.M.F.
might'make Russia — which is still
negotiating for a much larger $6.5
billion I.M.F. credit — reluctant to
reschedule the debts that Ukraine
owes it. "The Russians will ask why
they should help.Ukraine when they
are not getting I.M.F. help but
Ukraine is," he said.
Mr. Aslund also criticized the Europeans for slowness in assisting
Ukraine, saying that although Germany and the Netherlands were
sympathetic, France, Italy and
Spain were more interested in aiding
Algeria and other Arab countries of
North Africa in a struggle against
Islamic fundamentalism.
However,' I.M.F. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said
they were reasonably conf ident that
they could successfully conclude
their loan negotiations with the Russians within the next few weeks, so
that both Russia and Ukraine would
get their assistance at about the
same time.
Mr. Camdessus has already made
tentative plans to visit. Moscow at
the end of the month in anticipation
of such an agreement, these officials
said.
These officials and some private
experts also suggest that granting
Ukraine: its loan now will put extra
pressure on Russian ministries, to
compromise and accept the l.M.F.'s
terms. The big stumbling block, they
say, is the reluctance of the Ministries of Finance and Foreign Economic Relations to surrender their
control over Russian oil exports, as
the I.M.F. is demanding.
"When other branches of the Russian Government see Ukraine is getting I.M.F. money, they will put extra pressure on them to stop blocking the deal," said Donald Green, a
Russian expert with Plan Econ, a
Washington economic consultancy
firm that specializes in the former
Communist world.
In fact, Mr Green said, the I.M.F.
is already effectively helping Russia
by lending to Ukraine and some other parts of the former Soviet Union
because these countries spend much
of the money buying oil, gas and
other raw materials from Russia.

THE NEW YORK TIMES, THURSDAY, MARCH 2, 1995
/Somalia: Not a Total Failure
Little fanfare attends the efforts this week of
United States Marines helping to evacuate the last
United Natiori^ forces from Somalia. Two years ago
and one beach away, 26,000 Americans troops waded aishore in a televised spectacular meant to
symbolize a. new humanitarian vocation for the
United States military after the end of the cold war.
Nobody wants to talk about that symbolism
now. Somalia, including the'death of 30 Americans,
has become a cautionary example of a mercy
mission gone wrong, cited mainly by those who
would keep Americans out of future peacekeeping.
The story of international intervention in Somalia is not as negative as conventional wisdom holds.
Yes, with the departure of the last U.N. troops;
anarchy and civil war are quickly returning. Idealistic assumptions, ill-conceived expansion of the
mission and fatal confusions over command and
control marred military operations. They cost the
lives of 100 peacekeepers and several hundred
Somalis as the focus shifted from delivering food to
hunting.down Gen..Mohammed Farah Aidid.
But this time, the fighting has not engulfed the
food supply, so it is unlikely the deadly starvation
that inspired international action 'will'soon, return.
Some 350,000 Somalis died of hunger before President Bush sent the first American troops in Decern- ,
ber 1992. Perhaps 250,000 more were saved by the
Americans and the U.N. forces that followed.
Lessons need to be learned'from the many
mistakes made by Washington and the United Na-
tions. But the painful Somalia experience warrants
tempered pride, not shame. The appropriate conclusion, is to proceed with greater caution in future
humanitarian emergencies.
Americans want to help when they see people
starving. It is a human impulse. Sometimes soldiers
can and should provide the help. But the need for
soldiers instead of relief workers usually means the
humanitarian crisis cannot be solved without subduing military conflict first.
Before political leaders send troops into these
situations, they need to analyze the risks, define a
mission that can be accomplished at acceptable
costs and then honestly explain the decision to the
American people and seek Congressional approval.
None of that ground was adequately covered for the
Somalia operation by the Bush Administration,
which launched it, or the Clinton Administration,
which expanded it. American mistakes were compounded by.U.N. Secretary General Boutros Ghali,
who allowed the U.N. to become embroiled in local
clan feuds, compromising its neutrality.
The worst errors were made by the U.N. Security Council. With the enthusiastic participation of
the United States, it hastily converted a food deliv•ery operation into an ambitious and ultimately
futile exercise in nation-building, coupled with a
searchand-destroy war against General Aidid.
Blame for the mistakes of Somalia can be
widely shared. But so can credit for the larger good
that was done, and now seems all but forgotten.
:
Mr, Rubin's Sensible Bank Reform
The timing was atrocious — coming the same
week that reckless trades by a junior employee
bankrupted the oldest investment bank in Britain.
Yet the regulatory relaxation proposed as a banking reform by Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin
makes good sense..
Mr. Rubin would wipe away rules dating back
to the Depression that are unsuited for modern
financial markets. He would allow banks to join
forces with insurance and securities companies, ,
creating a competitive mix that should benefit
customers. The plan would, by diversifying investment opportunities, make banks less risky. — the
best way to avoid a taxpayer-financed bailout of
depositors. Had banks been allowed to sell insurance and stock, they would not have been bankrupted by the collapse of real estate markets in the
igso's. •
Congress forbade banks to sell insurance or
securities in part because it believed that such
activities contributed to bankruptcies during the
Depression. But history and logic suggest Congress
should change direction..
Studies by Prof. George Benston of Emory
University have shown; that securities activities did
not contribute to bank failures in the IQSO's; nor did
banks exploit unwitting customers by, for example,
selling them shares of stock in weak compianies that
owed the bank money.
In recent decades, banks have lost customers
. as depositors flocked to mutual funds and corporate
borrowers tapped financial markets directly. By
permitting affiliation with insurance and brokerage
firms, Mr. Rubin would allow banks to find new
customers and, thereby, stabilize revenues. The
•proposal would protect insured deposits by requiring banks to maintain large reserves and requiring
regulators to intervene once those reserves dip
below pre-set levels.
Other reform bills — by Chairman Jim Leach
of the House Banking Committee and Chairman
Alfonse D'Amato of the Seriate Banking Committee
— would take Federal law in the same direction.
The bills propose different legal structures and
safeguards against misuse of insured deposits.
Some of these differences are important — for
example, Mr. Leach would, indefensibly, insulate
insurance agents from competition by banks. Others are petty'— such as ttirf battles over.which
regulatory agency would reign supreme.
The importam point is that for the first time
key Congressional committees and the Clinton Administration are pulling in the same direction. That
will make it harder for insurance or'Securities
lobbies to scuttle reform. Nailing down a compromise should not prove difficult if, as the Republican
agenda unfolds, Congress can keep its mind on this
vitally important, if unglamorous, topic.

Cutting Mass Transit, Carefully
1 X
The New York City Transit Authority has a
rational plan to save $113 million this year, avoiding
the need for a midsummer fare increase. Painful as.
some of the contemplated cuts are, still more cuts
are coming, or higher'fares, or both, probably
before year's end. All concerned — City Hall,. Albany and the transit agency's parent, the Metropolitan
Transportation Authority — need to agree on a new
overall plan for the next several years, rather than
ripping the system apart mile by mile.
The immediate plan has the M.T.A.'s go-ahead
for everything but the proposed cuts in service,
which must go through public hearings. The Transit
Authority sensibly seeks the biggest savings from
trimming bureaucracy .and increasing productivity.
Less than one-fifth of the total would come from
reduced bus and subway service, mostly at night or
on lightly used or duplicative routes.
It makes sense to cut service during the hours
when it is least used and, as proposed/ to shut a
subway station with ohly.94 paying customers a day
and five times that many fare-beaters. Indeed,
there are other stations that could be shut, where
the next nearest station is close by. But any such
move is politically incendiary; it needs support
from City Hall and Albany.
The M.T.A. says the propdsed service cuts
would affect only 36,000 of the five million daily
rides on city buses and sybways; alternative routes
would be available, just less convenient, But these
cuts need the close examination they will get in
public hearings. The affected riders are typically
the poor, transit cuts hamper their access to jobs
and schools.
New York City sustains 24-hour public transit
service unmatched anywhere else. That is one of the
glories of the city, but within the framework of overall rethinking, there may be room to cut back.
Transit subsidies are shrinking. There will be less
city and state aid, and almost surely less Federal
aid.
A fare hike should probably be the last resort.
Some further cuts in service can be handled. Still
other, less painful remedies are available if other
governmental entities cooperate. Millions could be
saved if Washington set less rigid rules for accommodating disabled riders, for conducting largescale random drug testing of employees and for
buying American products. It could also benefit if
Albany would let the M.T.A. transfer subsidy money
among its several subdivisions, which also include
commuter railroads, bridges and tunnels.
One key to the system's gradual recovery from
past neglect has been its ability to plan ahead, to
know how much money there would be and allocate
il more than a year in advance. The new savings are
only a stopgap. Given today's tighter conditions,
New York City's transit network needs a new plai..

�THE NEW YORK TIMES, THURSDAY, MARCH 2, 1995
Essay
WILLIAM SAFIRE
Singapore Sling
WASHINGTON
In Singapore last year, 27-year-old
Nick Leeson was fined $140 for indecently exposing himself before a
group of women in a discotheque.
But when he was running up $27
billion in financial-derivative trades
that bankrupted a venerable merchant bank, what did the see-no-evil
regulators of Simex, Singapore's
swinging stock exchange, do? They
shyly looked the other way.
"It would be much harder, nearly
impossible, to work that kind of conspiracy in New York than in Singapore," says David Shulman, chief
equity strategist, at Salomon Brothers. Like Paul Volcker and Alan
Greenspan, he cautions against
making the new form of gambling —
the casino-style bets that are made
on the movement of real securities
and commodities — the scapegoat
for recent huge losses.
I have had my ear bent with how
wonderful derivatives can be in
sharing risk, and how swaps and
Stop the
derivatives binge.
hedges now bestraddling the financial world insure global traders
against currency swings; Wall
Streeters pass along dire warnings
about "disturbing the cosmic
rhythms of the universe"; about regulation driving up the cost of hedging's insurance. And there's quavering in the Quadriad about triggering
fearsome credit contraction by slowing the derivatives' merry-go-round.
But it strikes me, after the sudden
ruination of London's Barings bank
by its Singapore slinger in a simple
index-option gamble, that our financial sages are being a little too cool
and comfortable.
jGerald Corrigan, former head of
the New York Fed now with Goldman, Sachs, has a neat way of accepting Establishment soothing syrup and then pouring it down the
drain: "Derivativesreducethe statistical probability of a systemic financial disruption," he tells me, "but
with the complexity, speed, interdependence and leverage growing out
of financial derivatives — if you do
have a systemic disruption, they
would make » far more damaging
than u otherwise would have been "
Translation: Although the new
gambling may reduce the odds on a
bust, it would turn any bust that does
come into a global debacle. His Derivatives Policy Group, a suggestion
of S.E.C. Chairman Arthur Levitt,
issues a report next week.
But too many old guys don't know
what the young guys are doing, or
how to stop them before one huge
loss gets computer-driven into a
chain reaction that wipes out wealth,
reputation and jobs. .
What to do about a danger we can
sense but do not comprehend?
First, investment bankers owe it
to customers, owners and trainees to
do a thorough "values check."
Their economic purpose is to assemble capital and provide it wisely
for business development, an honorable service in which they can take
pride and make profit.
Their purpose is not to use inside
expertise gained from companies
they underwrite to trade for their
own accounts, while advising investment clients to follow them along
and enhance their early positions.
Such "proprietary activity," as
this dog-wagging by the trading tail
is euphemized, is legal but dishonorable — the banking equivalent of
"honest graft" in politics. If the mefirst, corporate-cultural sleaziness
of high leverage and lightning-fast
shuffling continues to grow, the business of investment banking will gain
a stigma that will shame its practitioners and turn away its customers.
Next, in overseeing banking and
securities, global exchanges and national regulators need to draw a line
between legitimate risk and reckless
endangerment.
That means getting the Bank for
International Settlements in Basle,
Switzerland (central bank for the G10), to sit down with the International Organization of Securities Commissions in Montreal to plan now to
avert a world financial crisis.
Working with the exchanges and
reporting services, these too-sleepy
bureaucracies could help set standards for managerial monitoring,
public disclosure, leverage and
firewalls in the interconnected marketplace. They could stimulate the
creation of regulatory software to
counter trading software, making
transparent to accountants and regulators who is trading how much on
whose account and on what margin.

President,
Dole Divide
Over Policy
Emphasis Differs
OnU.S. World Role
By Ann Devroy
a
t
Washington Post Stiff Writer
President Clinton and Senate Majority Leader Robert J. Dole (RKan.) sketched out competing visions of American foreign policy yesterday, with Dole accusing Democrats of failing to grasp grim global
realities and Clinton stemly warning
of the dangers of "a new American
isolationism."
Dole, who is seeking the GOP
presidential nomination and whose
long tenure in the Senate has given
him more foreign policy experience
than the other declared candidates,
was clearly partisan, particularly in
his attacks on the administration's
Russia policies. Clinton, speaking
from the same podium only hours
later, was presidential and named no
names in his references to "hypo
crites" and isolationists.
That was left to White House officials, who earlier said the president
had Republicans in mind, particularly
in the House, when he complained of
a failure to accept, promote and pay
for American leadership in the
world.
Dole, in remarks built around the
theme of "global realities" that the
United States must see clearly with
a "new vision," sharply questioned
the administration's "misguided devotion' to Russian President Boris
Yeltsin. He accused it of having a
"Russia first" attitude and chipped
away at Clinton policies toward Iran,
Iraq, North Korea and on a string of
other fronts.
Although congressional Republicans have begun drawing lines with
the Clinton administration over foreign policy, particularly United Nations peacekeeping operations and
foreign aid, Dole's address was the
first from a senior party leader and a
1996 presidential candidate broadly
to critique the administration's foreign policies. Of the two Republican

presidential candidates who have
formally announced, Sen. Phil
Gramm (Tex.) and former Tennessee governor Lamar Alexander, foreign policy has barely rated a paragraph in their announcement
The setting for Clinton and Dole
yesterday was a conference at the
Nixon Center for Peace and Freedom on "Defining An American Role
in an Uncertain World." Clinton
struck what historically has been a
presidential theme of the need for
American leadership and resistance
to the impulse by Americans to withdraw from that burden.
• In a barely concealed reference to
Republicans, Clinton said the "new
isolationists" would "eliminate any
meaningful role for the United Nations . . . would deny resources to
peacekeepers and even to our
tional leader of the reform movement there. U.S. disagreements
with Yeltsin, he said, have been
made clear.
Clinton used the administration's
nuclear nonproliferation efforts as
the prime example of the need and
rewards of engagement abroad.
Clinton's speech coincided with the
start of an administration push to
win an indefinite extension of the 25year-old nuclear Non-Proliferation
Treaty (MPT) at a 172-nation conference that opens in New York next
month.
To underscore his commitment to
curb nuclear weaponry, the president announced that the United
States would remove 200 tons of
bomb-building material—enriched
uranium and plutonium—from its
nuclear stockpiles.
Dole ignored the peacekeeping
and other immediate battles with
Congress to concentrate on how
America should respond to "a resurgent Russia, asserting its position
around the globe." And even though
several members of the defeated
Bush administration team sat stoically in the audience, Dole did not flinch
from criticizing the Russia policy of
the former president.
"Just as it was wrong to place too
much focus on [then-Soviet president Mikhail] Gorbachev in 1991, it
is wrong in 1995 to ignore the fact
that President Yeltsin has made serious errors, has moved toward authoritarian rule and has lost the political support of virtually all
reform-minded Russians," Dole said.
Dole has shown consistency in having criticized former President Bush
for embracing Gorbachev too closely,
and now in criticizing Clinton for embracing Yeltsin too closely.
Today Russia's foreign policy. Dole
said, "is often in conflict with American interests." Yet Clinton, captive of
a "misguided devotion to a Russia
first policy, which has turned into a
Yeltsin firat policy" runs an administration that has "excused, ignored and
minimized" Yeltsin's errors, he said.
Reading the lines as if they were an
indictment. Dole accused Russia of
meddling in the U.S.-North Korean
nuclear agreement, of threatening
prospective new East European members of NATO whose entry it opposed, of continuing to support Fidel
Castro in Cuba, and of subverting and
intimidatingformerSoviet states in
Russia's so-called "near abroad."
The United States, Dole suggested, has looked the other way and
failed vigorously to protest, resulting
in a loss of a "tremendous opportunity" to make dear American objections. In the case of Russia's military
action in Chechnya, Washington failed
to act "before thousands were slaughtered," he said.
Dole said a "new realism" with Russia means not a return to the Cold
War but to developing a more honest
relationship "that does not paper over
important policy differences with an
appeal to personal ties."
Beyond Russia, Dole listed a string
of other "globalrealities"he said the
United States must face, including the
reality that traditional nuclear nonproliferation efforts sometimes fail
Iraq, Iran and North Korea, he said,
"illustrate the failures" of traditional
treaties. He said the nuclear deal the
United States is trying to work with
North Korea "has little prospect of
successfully addressing" the threat;
said a "cash-hungry Russia" will give
Iran a leap forward in its nuclear problem; and accused the administration of
"timidity" in dealing with Iraq.

that is lower here than almost anywhere else: the

THIRSOAY. MARCH 2,1995
Education Chief Learns Lesson on Cuts
With Department Under GOP Attack, Riley Defends Programs
By Rene Sanchez
CUTTING EDUCATION PROGRAMS
Wuhmjloo Ftat Sua Wriur
A few weeks ago, Education Secretary Richard W. Riley believed he
had reason to boast His department
had just unveiled a budget that proposed killing or merging 68 programs to save $727 million. "We
thought" Riley said, "we had been
rather bold."
He's thinking twice now.
• That's because Republican leaders in the House are proposing to
cut, $1.7 billion in education spending this year—more than double his
suggestion. The GOPs plan would
scale back initiatives such as Goals
2000 and erase the federal money
that schools get for anti-drug and violence programs, homeless children
and improved classroom technology.
Goals 2000, a program that is designed to raise standards, stands to
lose about $175 million under the
proposal The $29 million the Education Department gives school districts to help homeless children
would go, as would the $482 million
it gives states to improve school
safety andfightdrug use.
Yesterday, as have other of President Clinton's Cabinet secretaries in
recent weeks, Riley pleaded with
Republican lawmakers not to approve the cuts, then visited Hine Junior High School on Capitol Hill to
highlight their possible effect
Riley and his deputies are attempting to portray the Republican
budget decisions, which still have to
be approved by the full Congress, as
harsh, short-sighted steps that will
directly harm some of the nation's
most disadvantaged schools.
This is a real frightening indication of how education is going to be
treated," Riley said. "It certainly
goes counter to what the American
people are concerned about."
But Republicans say the cuts are

The decision constitutes an exception to the rule that prosecutors cannot use illegally seized evidence. The

from unreasonable searches or seizures; it requires police who believe
criminal activity is underway to first
obtain an arrest or search warrant

was narrow, and a majority of the
justices expressed concerns about
safeguards in an en of nationwide
computerized arrest records.
The police, of course, are entitled
to enjoy the substantial advantages
this technology confers," Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote in a statement concurring in the decision.
They may not however, rdy on it
blindly. With the benefits of more efficient law enforcement mechanisms
comes the burden of corresponding
constitutknal responsibilities."

the First Amendment mandate that
Virginia Press Case Hinges on Funding, Justices Told
High Court Shows Some Sympathy for University Aid to Student-Run Evangelical Magazin
government "shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion."
The oral arguments in the case,
testing how that mandate intersects
with free speech, were, among the
most-anticipated of this term. The
court has been sharply divided over
government aid to rehgious entities.
Some of the more conservative
justices have said the court should
reconsider its standards for determining whether a government policy
unconstitutionally advances religion.
They want the court to allow more
interaction between government and
religious interests, a position that
could end up meaning more taxpayer
support, including school vouchers,
for church groups.
The case began when Ronald W.
Rosenberger of Great Falls and other students were denied funds for
their "Wide Awake: A Christian Perspective at the University of Virginia."
The legal dilemma comes down to
two questions: Whether the Constitution's guarantee offreespeech requires the university to provide student activity funds to religious
magazines as it does for nonreligious
publications and whether the Establishment Clause bars the university
from doing i t
Jeffries, a law professor at the university, said, There is a long tradition in this country offinancialdisengagement between church and
state." He stressed the university
was "not picking out a rehgious point
of view and trying to suppress it."
Rather, he said, the university was
making basic funding choices. He
noted the policy also refuses to subsidize political advocacy. He said student fees may not be used for lobbying or electioneering.
But Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
said he did not think those political
activities could be compared with
"abstract views" of religion. Kennedy and Justice Antonin Scalia particularly pressed Jeffries on whether a
religious activity, or mere viewpoint,
was being quashed.
Jeffries said the magazine engaged in "proselytizing."
Justice David H. Souter suggested
it would be difficult for universities
to differentiate between religious
groups that merely express rehgious
viewpoints and those that are more
activist Souter seemed to resist the
idea that public funds should pay for
a religiously oriented magazine.
Jeffries acknowledged the Supreme Court in 1993 had said public
schools must allow church groups
access to empty classrooms on the
same basis as nonchurch groups, but
he added, "there cannot be arightof
access to the budget."
Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said
she knew of no case allowing direct
payment to a religious group. But
Scalia asked Jeffries if there was "a
major step" between giving access to
a classroom and giving the money to'
rent one: "Is that the step off the
cliff?" Jeffries said yes.
McConnell, a University of Chicago law professor, told the court the
university should not be in the position of deciding among views students may express.
They say they are funding educational activities by students," Justice.
Stephen G. Breyer told McConnell..
"Can't they do thatf"
"But the activity of student journalism is educational," McConnell
countered.
I
Kennedy questioned whether,
there might be a "gray area" that allows the school to deny religious
groups funding based on fears it',
might be unconstitutionally advanc-"
ing religion.
Free speech and free press,
McConnell insisted, should not be
defeated by "some nebulous fear" of
violating the Establishment Clause. '
A decision in Rosenberger v. Rector .
and Visitors of the University of Vir-.,
ginia is expected before, the court
recesses this summer.

The nation's red-hot industrial sector, a source of major inflation worries for government policymakers and
investors, is finally showing signs of
cooling off a bit.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday
its index of manufacturing activity fell
last month to 54.5—the lowest reading since November 1993—from
57.9 in January. An index reading of
50 or more indicates the manufacturing portion of the economy is expanding.
Analysts said the decline from a
peak of 60 last November is another
in a string of recent reports indicating
a slowing of economic growth. Other
signs include much smaller monthly
gains in retail sales and a substantial
drop in home sales and construction.

By Rick Atkinson

MOGADISHU, Somalia, March
1—In a scene reminiscent of both a
land rush and a Wild West shootout,
gunmen loyal to faction leader Mohamed Farah Aideed today routed a
mob of looters shortly after United
Nations peacekeeping troops abandoned the Mogadishu airport.
When the gunfire and pillage had
finally stopped, control of the airport
was in Somali hands for the first
time in 2Vi years and the United Nations was only a day away from its final withdrawal from a mission that
sought unsuccessfully to stabilize Somalia after a devastating famine and
civil war.
Aideed, who controls south Mogadishu and was long the object of a
U.N. manhunt, took a languid victory lap around the airport terminals
and warehouses—only 300 yards
below U.S. Marines looking down
from their sand dune bunkers east of
the airport.
After inspecting the facilities with
a crowd of 200 followers and a personal bodyguard of six "technicals"—machine-gun-mounted pickup
trucks—Aideed issued a call for law
and order in a city where both have
been conspicuously absent for years.
Whether that appeal will be heeded remains to be seen on Thursday,
when the United Nations is scheduled to complete its withdrawal from
down the runway and out the airport's rear gate. The maneuver left
the facility unguarded by international troops for the first time since
U.S. Marines came ashore in December 1992 to combat Somalia's
civil war-generated famine.
As if on cue, hundreds of looters
swarmed onto the airport, scavenging pipes and light fixtures, U.N.
furniture and used tires.
Within minutes, however, an armada of Aideed's technicals burst
through the airport gates in a melee
of gunfire that sent U.S. and Italian
troops scurrying for cover behind
sandbag fortifications on the dune
line.
"It's a bad day to be tall," Sgt.
Maj. Hank Callahan, an Army Special Forces soldier, said as he
crouched with journalists atop Hill
22 overlooking the runway.

whizzing overhead, Marine sharp— Unidentified American officer shooters and Italian troopsfiredre-,

know what this reminds me of? An
Easter egg hunt"

consensus that this is the last sunset we'll see in Somalia."

�ifghans Say City Is Calmer Under Militants
)nce-Lawless Kandahar M r Livable Now, but Order Maintained Through Strict Islamic Law
oe
By John Ward Anderson
Wntmun POM P<m«i Sam
KANDAHAR. Afghanistan—Many shaggy men'
in this rugged frontier town had a rude shock last
week when they were dragged out of stores and
hauled off buses to have their heads shaved by Islamic students who control the local government.
Women have lost their jobs and for a while were
banned from dty markets and bazaars, even when
wearing mandatory burkhas— tent-like shawls that
cover them entirely. Schools have been closed, and
children are prohibited from playing soccer or
chess and watching television because the ruling
council has declared such activities un-Islamk.
Yet nearly everyone says life here is a vast improvement over what it was just a few months ago,
before a mysterious group called Taliban—or Islamic students—rose up to liberate Kandahar, Afghanistan's second-largest city,fromviolent mili, tias arid tribal gangs that preyed on civilians.
There was no security, no one was responsible, but everything now is under control," said Najibullah Fazly, 40, a driver for the World Health
Organization. "The local people are very happy
Taliban has come to the city."
Now, after a two-month, 330-mile march
across'southern Afghanistan, during which every
opposing army gave way before it, Taliban stands
just 10 miles south of Kabul, the capital, where
citizens await its arrival with a mixture of joy, fear
and suspicion. The group is demanding that all militias disarm and that an Islamic government with
popular support be formed.
Kandahar's 200,000 residents seem grateful for
their new-found security/ but many are also concerned about Taliban's brand of Islamic fundamentalism. Unmarried lovers have been publicly
flogged. At least four people have been executed. A
thief was painted in blackface and paraded around
town. Two shopkeepers caught selling goods to
women were jailed for three days. Music has been
banned. Schools have been closed—permanently to
girls, while boys are to receive a religious education
based on the Koran, Islam's holy book.
Taliban leaders contend that "the Koran says
women are not allowed to go out,, and they don't
want the boys to get knowledge in the sciences, only theology," said a 39-year-old Afghan woman, who
asked not to be identified for fear of reprisals.
"But the ideas they have—no one will accept
this. They will have to change," the woman said.
See KANDAHAR, A2i CoL S
KANDAHAR, From A23
"Sixteen yean offightinghave made
people very tired, so now they are only thinking of peace, and they're happy the Taliban has brought them security. But they are worried about the
future of their children and the future
of Afghanistan."
Still, as religious students with few

V
ice President Gore will make the adminiatration's first real statement on
public broadcasting today with a
speech at American University . . .
The speech will address the ways in which
public broadcasting helps educate children
through its preschool shows, and adults
through its "distance learning" program . . .
It comes as the new Congress is threatening
to cut funds for the Corporation for Public
Broadcasting. Last week, a House Appropriations subcommittee voted to cut 15 percent of
CPB's funds in 1996 and 30 percent in 1997,
and the prospect of federal funding being
zeroed out in the following years is still very
much alive . . .
The full committee is scheduled to vote on
that today...
Meanwhile, Democratic Reps. Nita Lowey
(N.Y.), Nancy Pelosi (Calif.) and Ed Markey
(Mass.) held a news conference yesterday to
show off 35,000 postcards in support of public
broadcasting from viewers around the country. After that, the cards were delivered to
various congressional offices by Bert and Ernie of "Sesame Street" fame. Or at least by
staffers who looked a lot like them....
In Other News
Sen. Richard Lugar (R-Ind.) is expected to
reveal his presidential candidacy on tonight's
edition of CNN's "Larry King Live"
He'll take phone calls during the appear-,
ance...
Lugar will hold a news conference tomorrow moming at the Senate Agriculture Committee, which he chairs'...
Michael Knox, removed as a juror in the
OJ. Simpson murder trial yesterday by Judge
Ito, will be interviewed on ABC News's
"Nightline" tonight (Channel 7,11:35)...
CBS News said yesterday Troy Roberts has
been named co-anchor of "CBS Morning
News" and will be a New York-based correspondent for various other CBS News broadcasts, starting Monday. He'll be teamed with
newly named Jane Robelot later this
month...
Roberts has been with the network's overnight broadcast Up to the Minute" . . .
C-SPAN will provide live coverage of the
South Carolina Republican Straw Vote and
Forum tomorrow starting at 8 p.m. The event
in Columbia, S.C., will feature speeches by Pat
Buchanan, Sen. Phil Gramm, Lamar Alexander, Rep. Bob Doman and Alan Keyes, former
U.S. Senate candidate from Maryland . . .
Results of the straw vote are expected
about 10 p.m....
After hearing again that the congressional budget process will mean
cuts for everybody, the chairmen of
the arts and humanities endowments
yesterday gave a Senate panel somber
views of what will be missing if their
agencies are forced to take scaled-back
roles in the future.
"Wefearthat with another significant
cut, we would lose more institutions,
more employees and more quality of life
in those localities," sax) Jane Alexander,
chainnan of the National Endowment
for the Arts. There is no substitution
for the nationalrecognitionof excellence. . . . If the endowment did not exist today, you would have to invent it"
Both Alexander and Sheldon Hackney, chairman cf the National Endowment for the Humanities, appeared yesterday before the Senate's Interior
appropriations subcommittee. The
hearing was a preliminary step toward
approval of a budget forfiscal1996, and
Chainnan Slade Gorton (R-Wash.) pre:
dieted that the process wouldn't be
completedformonths. He also warned
that agencies under the committee's jurisdiction would have to "compete" for
their share of a dwindling pool cf funds.
Threatened, said Hackney, would be
the NEH's historic-preservation projects and teacher institutes.
Last week a House appropriations
subcommittee sliced $5 million from
each of the endowments' budgets for
the currentfiscalyear. The arts endowment was targeted for areductkmerf $1
million in administrative expenses and
$4 million for individual fellowships.
If thoseredsionmeasures are approved, Alexander said, the staff will
have to be furloughed for eight days.
She added that the unspent funds for
theremaindercf the year didn't include $4 million for individual fellowships and that if the endowment must
makereductionsin grants, she would
prefer cutting across the board.
But yesterday's hearing veered far
from the subject of appropriations and
took on a range of topics, including the
value of regional arts centers, Thomas
Jefferson and political correctness,
George Washington and history standards and eStism.
Trying to bhmt charges of cultural
elitism that have been leveled at the
endowments, Hackney said: "I recognize that many people confuse the
NEH with the NEA, or think that the
NEH is part of the Humane Society, or
that we are somehow involved in humanitarianism. High-profile we are not
We are the blue-collar workers of the
cultural world."
Because the arts endowment has
been plagued by a political uproar over
various individual grants—and resultant reductions in the agency's budget—Sen. Ted Stevens (R-Alaska) demanded to know what reforms had
been introduced to prevent the awarding of questionable grants in the future.
Alexander described accountability
measures, saying the agency is now receiving interim reports on what projects are being sponsored by organizations with NEA money. "It sounds
better," said Stevens.

JACK ANDERSON and MICHAEL BINSTEIN
National Gallery to Feel New Heat
n unflattering portrait of the National
Gallery of Art will be on exhibit this week
before the House Appropriations
subcommittee on Interior.
And the subcommittee chainnan, Rep. Ralph
Regula (R-Ohio) is warning gallery officials in
advance not to airbrush over evidence that it's
failing to protect the nation's art treasures.
Last year, the gallery asked an independent team
of experts from the Association of Higher Education
Facilities Officers to assess the safety and security
of its collection, which includes more than 75,000
works of art rangingfromPicasso to van Gogh.
Although, the gallery grumbles at the broad brush
review, the evaluation team was "unanimous in its
opinion that the conditions of the facilities and the
organizational problems" at the gallery "threaten
the security of the collection," according to a copy of
association's report. "If I were them, I would
address the issue in my opening statement," Regula
told our associate Ed Henry. "And if they don't,
we're certainly going to get to it in our
questions
You can't ignore the concerns
expressed in the report."
At a time when the new Congress is scrutinizing,
arts funding, President Clinton wants to boost the
gallery's $55 million budget. But Regula, who holds
the gallery's purse strings, revealed that the report
is coloring his early impressions.
"We want to know what's happening to the money
because they've been getting a substantial sum
through the budget process plus they have a lot of
private endowment," said Regula. Last month, he
sliced from this year's budget over $400,000 the
gallery wanted to use to start building a
multimillion-dollar sculpture garden.
"I think before we start investing in [the garden],
let's take care of what we have," Regula said of the
gallery's irreplaceable artwork.
The association, a respected nonprofit
organization, completed the scathing evaluation last
September. It charged that the gallery's skylights
and roof "leak extensively," allowing water to seep
into the gallery's East and West buildings. The
buildings' heating and cooling system was assailed
forfrequenttemperature and humidity malfunctions
that "could easily exceed poorly trained workers'
abilities" to bring the problem under control before
it damages priceless artwork. Even though the
A
gallery commissioned the group's services, gallery
spokeswoman Ruth Kaplan says the report is
"misleading" because it did not take into view
corrective measures that were already combating
the problems.
In fact, the report noted that "these conditions
are recognized by [gallery] staff and plans exist for
their correction." But the report added: "The team
wishes to state emphatically that steps should be
undertaken immediately to correct these
deficiencies before disaster occurs."
Six months later, the gallery has not taken those
immediate steps. Kaplan told us that all of the
skylights in the modern East Building will be
reseated by the middle of April, but she confirmed
that the building suffered a water leak just last
month after a snowstorm in Washington. There was
no damage, but 35 paintings were moved to
temporary storage as a precautionary measure.
Meanwhile, a four-year renovation of the
skylights in the old West Building will not even
begin until June 1996. Thanks to a $2 million grant
from the Department of Energy, the gallery vrill
also receive a state-of-the-art building automation
system for heating and cooling. But the installation
won't start until June and will take more than two
years. Malfunctions may relate more to the staff
than to the system. The report charged that the
buildings' mechanical systems are operated in a
"by-the-seat-of-the-pants manner" and that
temperatures in the gallery swing wildly from too
hot to too cold.
The recent selection of retired Air Force Gen.
Michael P.C. Cams to be the new CIA director
surprised no one more than the head of the
president's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board.
Former defense secretary Les Aspin was
appointed last year to oversee the 12-member
board, which was essentially created to spy on the
spooks and evaluate the performance of the $28
billion-a-year intelligence community. But Aspin has
complained to friends that he had no early
intelligence about Cams's nomination.
Sue days before the White House announcement,
Aspin spoke to President Clinton and White House
Chief of Staff Leon E. Panetta—and at that point
Cams's name was not even on the "short list,"
according to sources close to Aspin.

R
(D-S.D.) about the proposed balanced
budget amendment on "Fox Morning
News" yesterday:
Ron Talley: Senator . . . you're the
key vote right now. . . . Everyone's
looking to you.
Sen. Conrad: Well, my principal concern is that we not loot the Social Security trust fund surplus in order to
balance the budget. As I said last
night, only in Washington would people think they're balancing the budget
when they're taking trust fund monies,
retirement fund monies and using it to
balance the operating expenses of the
government....
Q: Now, a member of your own party, Sen. John Breaux of Louisiana today said, "Wait a second, Congress
isn't going to touch that." I mean, realistically speaking, Congress won't
touch that
A:... If you read the plain language
of the amendment, it is very clear that
the Social Security trust fund surpluses, in the next seven years—$636 billion—will be used, every penny of it.
There won't be a trust fund. It will be
gone. It will be spent to help balance
the operating expenses of the government . . . I think that's wrong....
Another very serious concern . . . is
in the case of economic emergency.
For example, we know now the right
policy is to balance the budget, to cut
spending, get this deficit down. But
that was exactly the wrong policy 60
years ago in the midst of the Depression. Then, raising taxes and cutting
spending to balance the budget were
precisely the wrong options. So, I
think we need to have special provision in the case of economic emergency so that we don't put the country
at risk.
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
'Conflict of Interest'
In the Student Loan Program
In opposing President Clinton's
money-saving reforms of the student
loan program ["Clinton, GOP Split
Over Student Loans," front page,
Feb. 14|, USA Croup argues that it
supports the "competition" in the current "private-public partnership."
Ironically, the only things "private
sector" about USA Group are its salaries.
As a guarantor responsible for
helping to oversee banks' roles in the
student loan program, USAG has no
private investors or contributors. Every penny of the $141,087,845 that
USAG had in the bank in 1993 came
from federal entitlements set by lobbying Congress, not through privatesector competition.
Furthermore, USAG has taken
those taxpayer funds and used them

One d the most frequently voiced arguments in
favor of the balanced budget amendment is that 48
of the states have a balanced budget requirement—35 of them constitutional, 13 statutory—so
if they can bve with it, why not the federal
government' But the truth is that governors and
state legislators who arefamiliarwith balanced
budget strictures know that they don't necessarily
work, especially when elected officials don't want
them to work, and that in fact such strictures have
tended to push pubbc officials into manipulative
actions and outright decepoons.
Although this behavior is usually limited to
periods of fiscal stress, states do run deficits,
sometimes obvious but often disguised. Two recent studies, one from the General Accounting
Office and another from the Nelson A Rockefeller
Institute at Government, make this point
GAO reports that of the 21 states that can carry
over orfinancedeficits despite balanced budget
mandates, at least 10 have done so one or more
times in 1990, 1991 and 1992. The Rockefeller
Institutereportsthat from one to 11 states had
deficits in each of the years 1983 through 1991.'
Indeed, the Department of Commerce's widely
used national income and product account figures
show state and local government expenditures
exceeding receipts by more than $50 billion in
1991,1992 and 1993.
The potential perversity of a balanced budget
amendment can be seen in states that run de facto
deficits (though they are not called that)—mainly
achieved by dubious practices that temporarily
paper over actual deficits. Some examples are the
shifting of expenditures to off-budget accounts,
borrowingfrompoob of money outside the general
fund and shifting thefinancingef functions to
so-called independent agencies or authorities.
States can "tuueT receipt and payment activities:
They acceleraterevenuereceipts such as tax
payments so as to collect them in a year developing
red ink, or they postpone expenditures to localities
and school district suppliers, and delay refunds to
taxpayers and salary and expense payments to
employees—shifting them to the next year. These
ploys mask deficits.
Statesreducecontributions to pension funds by
forcing changes in actuarial assumptuos. They use
the credit markets. States can borrow repeatedly
against the same assets, byrefinancingthem even
after the original debt has been mostlyrepaid,and
finally, states sell assets. They sell buddings and
roads either outright (sometimes as part of a valid
privatiation program) or transfer themtoanother
state agency under a sale and lease-back scheme.
Even though these practices are difficult to
detect fromfinancialrecords and interviews, GAO
reports that at least a dozen states recently closed
approximately 20 percent of their budget gaps
using these gimmicks. My own experience with
statefiscalsystems indicates that the practice is
more widespread thanreported.New York and
California are cases in point
In New York a series of borrowings by state
construction authorities was authorized by the
legislature and governor—usually in the earto
hours of the moming during marathon budget
sessions—that generated $1.2 billion to balance
the budgets from 1990 through 1992. Though
they might have helped a few state officials get
reelected, these borrowings created little improvement in the quality of life, and the debt serriefc
amounting to $2.9 billion, wiD be paid by taxpayep
over the next several decades.
During the same three years, the budgets we&
propped up when state officials changed the fun*
ing method of the pension system in order-to
acceleratereductionsin state contributions by
billion in those few years. This move was successfully challenged in the courts, and now tpe
state wiD have to pay back the system with
interest, yet this transaction is not labeled (as^t
should have been) deficit financing.
In Cahfomia, officials have used a full menu flf
devices to achieve budget balance. They defer
contributions to the pension system, postpone
vendor payments, especially MediCal bills, and
make adjustments in accounting systems. Fife
consecutive years of deficits were rolled forwutd
with a series of increasingly larger borrowings,
some done from internal off-budget accounts agd
some extemaOy in the public credit markets.
A balanced budget requirement at the federal
level could encourage such duplicity. Papering ovbr
an mhalancfd budget shifts the cost of todays
programs to tomorrow's taxpayers and erodes thie
accountability of elected officials—the very conation the new members of Congress vow to chahg4.
If this federal amendment moves to the agendfe

vote, the numerous consideratioos that have been
so thoroughly discussed about this amendment In

Bill Clinton's determination to support
Mexican ex-president Carlos Salinas de
Gortari turned out to be a bad gamble. The
American leader's prestige is now unhappily invested more heavily in scandal-plagued
Mexico than in any other spot on the globe.
Salinas, who helped cover up Mexico's
financial problems in 1994, is now touched
by revelations of even more sinister coverups involving Mexico's two national political assassinations last year. Late Tuesday,
Salinas's brother, Raul, was arrested in
connection with the slaying of political leader Francisco Ruiz Massieu. A few days
earlier, it had become clear that Salinas
himself had to have been aware of a massive, visible coverup in the earlier murder
