Willard Gaylin and Allan Rosenfield
Medical Morality: When Consent Is Not Informed
Every week seems to bring a new undocumented assault on the character of Or. Henry
Foster, the U.S. surgeon general nominee.
In response to the disclosure that in 1974
Foster performed a "small number" of sterilizations on severely retarded women (four
seems to be the number), Charles Krauthammer asked whether it was "ethical to perform
surgery and permanently sterilise women in
no position to give consent" [op-ed, Feb. 17].
Krauthammer, who is not only a respected
journalist but also a physician with a wellknown interest in and seusitivity to moral
problems in medicine, raised predsety the
right question. Unfortunately he came to an
uncharacteristically simpliatic judgment
Medical ethics in this most individualistic of
. all modern cultures has been "autanomy"-driv. en. Informed consent is at the heart of i t But
with the seriously mentally impaired, consent
itself can be immoral—if not impossible—to
obtain. For example, one would not allow a
significantly impaired person to sign away her
fortune and her security. Nor, by the same
token, should she be allowed to make major
decisions that infringe on her health and survival. Whether she is to be subjected to an
amputation, a coronary bypass or a sterilization procedure will all be decided by others.
In the case q? the mentally impaired, we are
forced to violate a cardinal principle of medical
ethics: We abrogate her authority to decide
for herself, assigning this right to others—the
family or institutions of society and the state.
Sterilizatioa procedures have traditionally
aroused anxiety and distrust, particularly
tions formed to defend them, which questioned even the definition of retardation.
Mainstreanung became the order of the day.
Oddly enough, this new attitude created an
atmosphere in which such extreme measures
as permanent sterilization for the retarded
were discussed in terms of their beneficence
and as promoting the rights of the individual.
The argument was that they would offer
retarded persons an opportunity to participate
in the new sexual freedom, unfettered by fears
since the World War D horrors of Nazi "eugen- of pregnancies and child-rearing, which they
ics" and the complicity, of German doctors in might not be able to manage.
- All this is by way of pointing out that what
racial experiments. So strong was the fear of
eugenics that even authentic research in ge- was morally correct and incorrect had hardly
netic mflitences on behavior was viewed with been settled by 1974, when Dr. Foster perdistrust As distinguished a biologist as E. 0. formed his operations. The law was confused,
Wilson was assaulted by some of his col- the philosophical community was divided, and
leagues as a fascist for daring to present the the medical community was uncertain. Even
data (suggesting that human beings, like in- the advocacy groups for the mentally retarded
sects, have genetic directives) that have since were deeply divided.
built his reputation as one of the great and
So great was the confusion that in 1976 a
humane scientists of our day.
grant was given by the National Science FounBut in the 1970s a counter-trend emerged. dation to the Hastings Center (a nonpartisan,
The civil rights movement had become a nondoctrinaire research institute concerned
model for many disenfranchised populations with society, ethics and the life sciences) to
other than African Americans, among them convene a group of scholars and advocates to
the handicapped. Consumer advocacy groups help sort out the moral contradictions in this
were being formed. The rights of the mentally complex area.
retarded were freshly reasserted by organizaThe nature of that ethical discourse is too
Tkking Exception
extended to be encompassed in this article,
but a number of variables obviously would
determine moral justification for sterilization
procedures: Who initiated it, the government
or the individual's family? If the government,
what section: the punitive branch of the Justice Department in a criminal case or some
paternalistic (although not necessarily more to
be trusted) institution of mental care?
Also to be considered: Things done to a
person to serve her interest are judged by
different standardsfromthose done her in the
interest of her family, other like individuals,
the institution or the state. Moral dilemmas
exist under all these conditions, and the proper resolutions in each case may be entirely
different.
In that debate a distinguished liberal philosopher argued that sterilization of mentally
retarded persons would be morally mandated
if it would "enhance their position in the moral
community" by facilitating their living together at home or in small communities outside
traditional institutions. We do not have to
accept that particular argument, but what is
clear to those of us who were privy to these
discussions is that the moral question was not
settled then, as it is probably not settled now.
It is particularly unjust tc equate a doctor who
performs sterilization procedures for therapeutic reasons—even if you feel he is misguided—with doctors who participated in radiation
experiments on unconsenting, unsuspecting
subjects during the Cold War years, let alone
the obscene Nazi camp experiments.
Krauthammer argues that "sterilization of
the mentally infirm is a morally problematic
procedure"; with that we heartily concur. But
it is clearly immoral (nothing problematic
here) to impugn the ethical character of Henry
Foster on the basis of sterilization procedures
he has performed or. for that matter,-on
abortions he has performed.
People of goodwill and good heart are entitled to hold differing views on emotionally
charged social issues (in-vitro fertilization,
assisted suicide, organ transplants, genetic
engineering or. for that matter, divorce, capital punishment and gun control) without being
demonized. For the Senate to form a judgment
on Dr. Foster's character on the basis of his
having performed such procedures would be
indefensible and indecent.
Willard Gaylin is professor of psychiatry at
Columbia University and co-fou nder of the •
Hastings Center. Allan Rosenfield is dean of
the Columbia School of Public Health.
�THE WASHINGTON POST^
THIRSDAV. MARCH 2,1995
Mexico Investigates a Murder
ITH THE ARREST of Raul Salinas,
brother of the former president, the
profound split in Mexico's government
party becomes more open to outsiders' view. Mr.
Salinas is accused of setting up the assassination
test September of the secretary general of the
Institutional Revolutionary Party—the PRI. The
party has run Mexico with an iron hand that,
from 1929 until very recently, permitted little
challenge. The struggle is between the reformers, who are working to turn Mexico into a
genuine democracy, and traditionalists determined to preserve the old style of order and
privilege.
The murdered party leader was a reformer.
Another was the party's then-candidate for presi"dent, assassinated similarly last spring. Another
is the man who succeeded him, the current
'president, Emesto Zedillo. The movement to•ward free elections is being led from the top, but
support is far from unanimous.
Mexico is hardly the only country that has
begun the transition to democracy in recent
' years, but it faces a far more difficult passage
'..than most. Unlike, say, Argentina or Chile, Mexi,co-is not merely replacing a bloody-handed military junta that had become bitterly unpopular—
and the PRI has been in power much longer than
the juntas, long enough to form all of the'country's political institutions in its own image. Unlike
w
:
:
the former Soviet satellites in Eastern Europe,
the Mexicans are not throwing off foreign domination, and there is no surge of nationalism to
help their democracy.
A closer parallel is Spain and its evolution after
the death of the dictator Francisco Franco 20
years ago. But Spain had two enormous advantages. The distribution of wealth there was
relatively equal, ameliorating social tensions.
Mexico's is among the most unequal in the world.
That's what underlies the uprising in Chiapas.
Equally important, Spain's democrats have had
strong and consistent support from their richer
neighbors to the north. They made it very clear
that membership in the Common Market was
open only to countries that held fair elections.
The United States was never entirely explicit on
that point in negotiating the North American
Free Trade Agreement. NAFTA continues to be
under noisy attack from American isolationists on
the left, just as the rescue of the peso is currently
under attack from the isolationists on the right.
The United States cannot greatly influence the
enormous internal struggle now being played out
over Mexico's political destiny. But Americans
should at least try to avoid undercutting leaders
like President Zedillo who are trying to advance
democratic principles.
Out of the Rubble in Richmond
ONE WAS even a pretense of Old Dominion courtliness at the General Assembly
session in Richmond this year. It started
real mean—when the legislators wouldn't even
give Gov. Allen the time on opening day to
address them in the customary fashion—and
ended with parting shots that would have had the
burgesses blushing. But civility aside, as it was
throughout, the outcome proved to be a reasonable standoff that blocked the worst of Gov.
Allen's bad agenda.
The front-page headline in the Richmond
Times-Dispatch last Friday carried the gubernatorial understatement of the season: "Allen adI' niits he may have cut too deeply." Too dogmatically as well, if you ask lawmakers of both parties
who left him embarrassed with a huge defeat on
' the budget. It was enough to rally Republican as
well as Democratic business leaders, educators
' and other defenders of the state's higher educa3 d n system, who dynamited not only the gover'. nor's budget but also his notion that Virginians
would forsake any programs for a small tax cut.
While conceding that his cuts were perhaps too
deep, the governor still isn't sparing the partisan
"insults, summarizing his opponents in the legisla. tUjre as contemptuous of Virginians and interest.jedonly in retaining their power and perks. "They
Jeit they needed to deflate me and tear down my
ideas. They feel threatened from the last election
'-and the elections this fall."
^ "that they took a beating last time was clear,
_and it was underscored during last year's session,
when the Democrats went along with nearly all of
Gov. Allen's major proposals focusing on crime
G
and an end to parole. But this year the governor's
insults and railroading attempts galvanized the
Democrats and made enough members of his
own party uncomfortable that he suffered some
humiliating defeats.
Only a compromise on welfare—in which he
and enough Democrats agreed on a stringent
proposal for time limits on receiving benefits and
getting jobs—could be claimed by Gov. Allen as
an advance. The plan is to force recipients into
jobs after 90 days and to cut their benefits after
two years. It will affect some 74,000 poor women
and their children across the state and deny
payments for additional children bom to aid
recipients. The test here will be in how the state
handles the transitions of those who have long
been out of work to the availability and obligations of work.
Though he didn't do well during the regular
session, Gov. Allen isn't ready to surrender to
the legislature yet. He has a line-item veto to test
opposition at an April 5 session and then will tum
to the voters in November, when all 140 legislative seats are up for election. Republicans must
pick up three seats in each chamber to become
the majority. With Gov. Allen able to use his
office to assist the campaigns of Republican
candidates, the Democrats may find themselves
on the defensive in some parts of the state. But
as some of the most nervous Northern Virginia
Republicans during this session noted, politics is
still local, and Gov. Allen may not be all that
helpful.

Making a Bad Amendment Worse
HE SENATE keeps trying to fix the balanced budget amendment to the Constitution. The fixes only make it worse. To pick
up a couple of needed votes, the sponsors agreed
to limit the authority of the courts to interpret
arid enforce the amendment. To pick up a final
vote, they are being asked to put Social Security
out of harm's way as well. The bidding for votes
only underscores the basic hypocrisy of the
exercise. This is an effort once again to let
members parade in favor offiscalresponsibility
\yhile deferring the means of achieving it. If in
the process they trivialize the Constitution and
destabilize the traditional balance of powers,
well, that's tomorrow's problem for someone else
to solve.
The balanced budget amendment's sponsors
have never been able to answer the enforcement
question. The rule would be that Congress could
adopt unbalanced budgets only by three-fifths
votes of both houses. What if it cheated, as it has
done so often in the recent past, and achieved the
requisite balance only by fudging thefiguresor
declaring some spending "off budget" and not
part of the official accounts? The normal procedure would be to take an unconstitutional act of
Congress to court, but an unelected judiciary
ought not to be writing the budget. So rightly
Said Sam Nunn and other waverers; to win them
over, the sponsors have added language that "the
judicial power of the United States" shall extend
fo this amendment only insofar as Congress may
later allow.
Nowhere else in the Constitution is there such
language. The courts have themselves decided
that under the Constitution they should defer to
the other branches in certain circumstances, but
in those cases it was the courts that were doing
the deciding; the fundamental principle that the
judiciary interprets the Constitution was not
breached. Nor does the language that too easily
satisfied Mr. Nunn solve the enforcement prob-
T
IK*-" I
lem; it only papers it over. If the courts can't
discipline an errant Congress except with Congress's consent, to whom does that job fall? Why
won't a future president say it's up to him to
impound unconstitutional spending? Then you are
back where you started; the contours of the
budget are once again a political issue for the
elected branches to fight over in the usual way.
As with the courts, so also with the Constitution:
It should not be invoked to solve a political
problem to which it is not suited.
The second of the current issues, having to do
with Social Security, is the perfect illustration of
why this is so. Some of the senatorial holdouts
say they will vote for the amendment only if
Social Security is protected. But why should it
be, except for the fact that a seventh of the
population receives the benefits? They want to
exempt it even though they also want to balance
the budget largely by spending cuts, and it
accounts for a fourth of all spending for other
than interest on the debt. Is it special because it's
so important? Why not, then, exempt defense and
law enforcement and the budget of the Internal
Revenue Service and who knows what else—perhaps spending to stave off hunger and provide
health care—as well? Or perhaps it's exempted
because it has its ownfinancingsource, but then
so does much of Medicare and the highway
program. Should they be exempted as well?
This is a mischievous amendment that would
install in the Constitution the principle of minority rule while locking the country into what in
many years would be bad economic policy. They
ought to drop the sham and get on with the
business of narrowing the deficit. We hope the
North Dakota Democrats who have been holding
out continue to do so. They do the country a
service, and put to shame their fellow Democrats
who have folded.

in halting illegal shippers.

For decades, Mexico has been ruled by
a political elite. Its members went to the
same schools. They worked their way up
through government ranks together. They
iiyed in the same areas and aie liii sanv.
restaurants. They married one another's
sisters. They protected each other, even
when someone committed a crime.
But the new president, who was never
more than an adopted orphan in that
political family, has
said that Mexico
now will be ruled by
laws and institutions and not by the
personal connections built up over
the years within the
ruling elite.
Actually, Mr. Zedillo had been saying such things
since he became the
ruling party's accidental candidate for
Emesto Zedillo
president, thrust
into the job when his predecessor was
assassinated last March. It is just that now
people are beginning to believe him.
"Zedillo has just changed the rules of
Mexican politics for the first time in 66
years," said Raymundo Riva Palacio, a
political commentator whose cousin is an
ambassador. He cited the 1929 formation of
the ruling Partido Revolucionario Institucional (PRI) as the last change of similar
magnitude.
If President Zedillo can make the
changes stick, the result will be a far more
democratic country. Mexico would also be
much more understandable to foreign investors, who, not having grown up exposed
to the political family, have often found it
hard to figure out who had an in with
whom.
But it will be tough going for the new
president, a 43-year-old economist inexperienced in politics. He already is facing an
economic crisis that he set off with his Dec.
20 devaluation of the peso, which has
sapped the strength of his support among
Mexicans. In addition, powerful political
factions have a vested interest in maintaining the old, familial system because of
the corruption it allowed. Investigators say
these factions have shown they will even
kill to get what they want.
" I now ask myself: 'What are the new
rules of the game?' says Adolfo Aguilar,
an opposition congressman.
Until
there are new rules,
he says, "this is going to be vicious."

Clinton Outlines Plan to Lift Export Ban
On the Oil From Alaska's North Slope
By TIMOTHY NOAH
Staff Reporter of T H E W A L L STREET JOURNAL
WASHINGTON - The Clinton administration, in testimony before Congress, outlined its plan to lift the export ban on oil
from Alaska's North Slope.
Several influential members of Congress have long pressed for lifting the
export ban - which was a condition imposed by Congress when it approved the
trans-Alaska pipeline in the 1970s-and the
administration has offered them much
encouragement. Foremost among oil companies advocating the change has been
British Petroleum PLC.
But until yesterday, the White House
withheld formal support of any specific
plan, citing practical problems involving
trade and other matters. Now a resolution
to these problems has been found, according to Deputy Energy Secretary William
White. In testimony before the Senate
Energy and Natural Resources Committee, Mr. White said the president would
support a bill lifting the ban provided it
contained several specific protections.
Although environmentalists voiced
some objections, Mr. White's statements
before the committee make it highly likely
that the Alaska ban will be lifted this year.
The Republican chairmen of the Senate
Energy committee and the House Natural
Resources committee - Sen. Frank Murkowski and Rep. Don Young - are both
Alaskans who strongly favor lifting the
export ban.
Mr. White said the bill must permit the
president to reinstate the ban should ex-
port of the oil harm the economy, the
environment or energy security in the
U.S. He also said the oil must be exported
in U.S.-flag vessels with U.S. crews (so as
not to deprive jobs to U.S. workers, who by
law currently man the ships that bring
Alaska North Slope oil to the lower 48
states). The exports must also be found not
to cause "substantial increases to retail
gasoline or other petroleum product
prices," Mr. White said, or result in crude
supply shortages on the West Coast, where
most of the Alaska North Slope oil ends up
today.
Previously, Mr. White had said the
administration was concerned that guaranteeing U.S. crews for ships carrying
Alaska North Slope oil might violate international trade agreements. But in his
testimony. Mr. White said that the administration now views the flag-preference
requirement as "unique" and that it
"shouldn't be viewed as opening further
possibilities for cargo preference, which
this administration strongly opposes.'.' Mr.
White said the administration.wouldn't
support any move to require that the ships
be U.S.built.
A spokesman for Mr. Murkowski said
that only one of the conditions proposed by
Mr. White would require further negotiation between the administration and Congress: that before the oil be exported, an
environmental impact assessment be
made under the National Environmental
Policy Act of 1970. According to the
spokesman, no such assessment has ever
before been a condition of granting an
export license.

By CARLA ANNE ROBBINS
Staff Reporter of T H E W A L L S T R E E T J O U R N A L
WASHINGTON - The Republicans have
found a target to replace the "evil empire": the United Nations. And if they get
their way, the U.N. could be out of the
business of peacekeeping.
The assault on the U.N. is part of a
broader challenge to President Clinton's
foreign policy contained in the National
Security Revitalization Act, which the
House is expected to approve today after
the Democrats surprisingly won some revisions last night. The bill, part of the GOP's
"Contract With America," reflects a deepseated Republican fear that the U.S. is
losing its military dominance in the world
and a deep-seated conviction that the U.N.
is to blame.
At the start of yesterday's tumultuous
debate, California freshman Rep. Andrea
Seastrand summed up Republican anger,
saying the bill would "ensure the U.S. is
not a servant to the U.N." and that
American troops "would not serve in a
(U.N. I blue beret when they serve the red,
white and blue."
Decline in Standing
The U.N.'s standing has declined
sharply with the U.S. public since 1990,
when Congress insisted President Bush
first seek Security Council authorization
before it would support the Gulf War. And
although the world body has had some
genuine successes in recent years-including Cambodia and Mozambique - spectacular failures in Somalia and Bosnia have
persuaded many Americans that the organization isn't just wasteful, but actually
dangerous. Defenders say the U.N., at
both its best and worst, is almost always a
servant of the Security Council, most
prominently the U.S.
President Clinton, who came out
against the GOP bill this week, has contributed to the current bash-the-U.N. atmosphere. Mr. Clinton used the U.N. as a
scapegoat for American over-reaching in
Somalia-the 1 Army Rangers killed there
8
were under U.S., not U.N. command - and
he continues to blame the U.N. for American inaction in Bosnia.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton doesn't
want to lose the United Nations. In a
strongly worded letter to House Speaker
Newt Gingrich, Mr. Clinton argued that
the U.N. is a useful to^l, especially when
less-than-vital interests are at stake. And
he warned that the legislation could "place
U.S. forces at greater risk by forcing us
to act unilaterally or not at all." In a flurry
of news conferences and speeches this
week, Mr. Clinton's top advisers sought to
portray the fight as one between internationalism and isolationism rather than a
defense of the U.N. itself.
Warning of "Star Wars Redux." House
Democrats last night managed to defeat a
key "Contract With America" provision:
hottest button issue" for American voters,
says GOP Rep. Floyd Spence of South
Carolina, chairman of the National Security Committee. "They start screaming
and clapping whenever it s mentioned."
It's also largely moot because, in the wake
of Somalia, Mr. Clinton pledged to keep
U.S. troops under U.S. command whenever
there is a serious risk of combat.
Democrats last night also were able to
strike a provision that would have required
congressional approval before any U.S.
troops can join a U.N. peacekeeping mission. Congress historically has shied away

WASHINGTON - Republican governors, unhappy with the GOP congressional
leadership's decision to keep food stamps a
federal program, have won concessions
from House leaders to give states more
flexibility in running the $27 billion program.
The 31-year-old food-stamp program
supplies vouchers to poor people to buy
groceries. In their "Contract With
America," Republicans proposed taking
money the federal government spends on
food stamps and giving it to states in a
"block grant" to spend on assistance programs of their own design.
But last week, under pressure from
farm-state Republicans, the House leadership said they had decided to keep food
stamps a federal program as they push
legislation through Congress to reform the
welfare system.
After meeting with the leadership Tuesday night, Gov. John Engler of Michigan
said House leaders had agreed to alter
their legislation to allow states to run their
Key Senator Indicates
More Moderate Line
On Trimming HUD
By
a WALL
STREET
JOURNAL
Staff
Reporter
WASHINGTON - The Senate is preparing to take a more moderate approach than
the House toward paring the Department
of Housing and Urban Development, according to Sen. Christopher S. Bond, chairman of a Senate Appropriations subcommittee.
Amid signs some House Republicans
are having second thoughts about a $7.2
billion attack made by a House Appropriations subcommittee last week, the Missouri Republican said any reform should
"provide protection for the tenants who
depend on HUD for the roof over their
heads."
"We're going to have to cut, but our
cuts will look different from the House and
they may not be the same level as in the
House," he said, referring: to the debate
on trimming HUD's $28 billion 1995 budget
and other agency budgets to pay for tax
cuts, California disaster relief and other
bills facing Congress.
This week, HUD Secretary Henry Cisneros tried to pressure Congress to restore
some cuts. News releases to 12 major cities
showed how the House cuts would be
"devastating" to the poor and cost cities
hundreds of millions in federal aid.
In a letter to Rep. Jerry Lewis, chairman of the House panel that made the cuts,
Secretary Cisneros said the move would
force HUD tenants "into the street," and
stymie programs to restore some slum
properties and tear down buildings that
can't be fixed. " I ask that you seriously
consider the human toll of the rescissions
you have recommended," he wrote.
Mr. Cisneros's campaign didn't appear
to mollify his Republican critics. " I think it
would be far more productive if Secretary
Cisneros would tell us how the details of his
budget will work," said Sen. Bond.
own food-stamp programs if the state goes
to a statewide "Electronic Benefits Transfer" system. Under EBT, food-stamp beneficiaries are given a computerized card,
similar to an automatic teller debit card, to
buy food. Currently, only Maryland is on a
statewide EBT system, according to a
House Agriculture Committee official.
Mr. Engler, who was accompanied-by
Massachusetts Gov. William Weld, at
the meeting said that House leaders had
also agreed to write provisions into their
welfare legislation that would give states
the authority to sanction food-stamp recipients if they do not meet work requirements under the government's main cash
welfare program, Aid to Families with
Dependent Children. He said a state could
go so far as to cut off an entire family from
food stamps if the adult refuses to go to
work.
Moreover, under the agreement, states
could "cash out" food stamps for some
welfare recipients who go to work in
private-sector jobs, giving certain recipients money that could be spent on items
other than food. The measure is "part of
our effort to make work pay," said Mr.
Engler. According to a House aide, people
would be eligible only if they were on both
AFDC and food stamps, had worked in a
private-sector job for at least three months
and were earning at least $350 a month.
Meanwhile, the Clinton administration
announced plans to attack food-stamp
fraud. Government officials estimate they
lose about $1 billion annually in illegal
trafficking of food stamps for cash, alcohol, drugs, guns and other items. At a news
conference yesterday, Agriculture Department officials said they are proposing
legislation that will toughen penalties
for food-stamp traffickers and better
screen retailers who want to participate in
the program.
"This administration has made clear
our opposition to block grants for our
nutrition programs," President Clinton
said in a statement. "With this tough,
workable antifraud initiative, we are ensuring that the food-stamp program will
earn the public trust, and continue to help
people who need it."

Key Senator Weighs Saving Tax Break
Tied to Viacom Plan for Cable-TV Sale
By GREG HITT
And MARK H. ANDERSON
S t a f f Reporters of T H E W A L L S T R E E T J O U R N A L
WASHINGTON - Senate Finance
Chairman Bob Packwood is weighing
whether to preserve a tax break for Viacom
Inc. that is critical to the media concern's
proposed S2.3 billion sale of its cable-television operations.
The House voted last month to rescind
the break by retroactively repealing a
Federal Communications Commission program designed to encourage minority ownership of media properties. Under the
program. Viacom would receive a tax
break of S 0 million to $600 million
40
because it arranged to sell its cable-TV
systems to a partnership led by black
media executive Frank Washington.
Sen. Packwood said in an interview
that he wants to find out if the Viacom
transaction was a "done deal" when the
House began to act earlier this year, and
whether the deal represents an "egregious" abuse of the tax code. He indicated
his decision will rest on the outcome of a
Senate Finance Committee hearing next
week.
The Oregon Republican expressed concerns that the House appears to be singling
out Viacom by repealing the FCC program
as of Jan. 17; the cable-TV deal was
announced days later. The company recently said that without the tax break, it
would halt the transaction. "Republicans
made a big deal about retroactivity last
year," Sen. Packwood said. Throughout
the last Congress, Republicans upbraided
President Clinton and Democrats for supporting retroactive.tax increases on upperincome individuals.
House Ways and Means Chairman Bill
Archer (R., Texas) said he attempted this
week to allay Sen. Packwood's concerns.
"This is a transaction," said Rep. Archer,
adding that he put the private sector on
notice about his intentions in mid-January.
Tied to Insurance Deduction
In the House, lawmakers tied repeal of
the FCC program to a popular proposal to
reinstitute a 25% tax deduction for health
insurance purchased by self-employed individuals. Repealing the FCC program
would raise SI.6 billion over five years,
helping to pay for the deduction, which
expired last year and which lawmakers
want to revive before the April 17 tax-filing
deadline.
Rep. Archer suggested the Senate,
bogged down on the balanced-budget
amendment, needs to act quickly. "We're
going to be leaving here after the first week
in April," he said, indicating that the
popular tax deduction must clear the Senate by then if lawmakers want to meet the
tax-filing deadline.
Some senators would like to see the FCC
;
program repeal split from the tax-deduction measure. While they are eager to
approve the deduction quickly - 75 senators signed a letter in January backing
renewal of the program-they fear igniting
a divisive, protracted debate on affirmative action. House debate on the matter
last month was racially charged, with
liberal black lawmakers accusing GOP
leaders of taking the first step toward
dismantling affirmative action. GOP leaders have argued the FCC program is rife
with abuse, and said the partnership that
wants to buy Viacom's cable systems is
backed by Tele-Communications Inc., the
nation's largest cable-TV company.
The newest member of the Senate Finance Committee, Sen. Carol MoseleyBraun (D., 111.) is lobbying her colleagues
to substitute a provision that would tighten
taxation on U.S. citizens who renounce
their citizenship for the provision repealing the FCC program. "That will raise $2.2
billion, which is more than enough to pay
for the 25% deduction" for health insurance. Sen. Moseley-Braun said. "It would
be a shame to retroactively repeal the
[FCC] program just to pay for this one
bill."
A Viacom spokesman said, "We are
hopeful that any final legislation will be
consistent with prevailing concerns voicci
by many in Congress against retroactive
tax measures."

WASHINGTON - The Justice Department is reviewing allegations involving yet
another Clinton cabinet member. Transportation Secretary Federico Pena, to see
if it should ask for an independent counsel.
The department's criminal division has
begun a 30-day review of the complaints,
the first stage of the process set up by the
independent-counsel law. If the complaints
are found to be credible, a 90-day inquiry
would follow. After that, the attorney general would decide whether to ask a threejudge panel to name a counsel.

comment, but he has said previously that
he sold his interest in the company before
joining the federal government and that he
hasn't given the transit agency any special
or favorable treatment. In the fall of 1994,
DOT's Federal Transit Administration suspended funding for the Los Angeles subway project when problems arose during
tunnel construction. The funding was reinstated after changes to the oversight structure, Mr. Pena has said.
A Pena spokesman said yesterday
that the secretary had "no plans" to
return to his old firm -when he leaves
office.

WASHINGTON-Manufacturing activity continued to slow in February and price
pressures for materials subsided a bit. a
new survey of purchasing managers suggests.
The .National Association of Purchasing
Management said its index fell to
in
February from ~u.y~r the month before.
The level still indicates the manufacturing
sector is healthy - just not as strong as it
has been over the past year and a half.
The pricing component of the index,
while still quite high, also slowed during
the month with a reading of S.H. compared
with S7.1 in January. In addition, the
percentage of suppliers reporting, slower
delivery times held steady during the
month, suggesting price pressures aren't
building.
Given Federal Reserve Chairman Alan
Greenspan's recent remark that the vendor-performance component of the survey
is an important inflation gauge, the report
seems to be just what the Fed has been
looking for: A sign that the. economy is
slowing and that material prices, which
have been rising fairly significantly in
recent months, aren't in danger of overheating.
Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President J. Alfred Broaddus, one of the Fed's
most hardline inflation foes, said yesterday that there are "tentative signs we may
be beginning to see some deceleration" in
prices.
Stable.Rates Seen
The figures, said Merrill Lynch senior
economist Bruce Steinberg "imply slowing, but positive growth and stable interest
rates."
Separately, a revision to the government's figures on economic growth during
the fourth quarter shows that the nation'soutput of goods and services was slightly
stronger than first thought. The Commerce
Department said the economy grew at a
4.61 annual rate, not the 4.51 pace reported last month.
While the revision was tiny, the components making up economic growth were
adjusted significantly, painting quite a
different picture of what drove the economy in the final phase of last year. Inventories, which many analysts thought had
built up too quickly in the fourth quarter,
actually increased only $48.1 billion - less
than in the third quarter. Net exports were
revised upward by SM.5 billion. There
were smaller upward revisions to consumer spending, federal government purchases and residential investment, while
the investment in durable equipment was
revised slightly downward.
Improved Inflation Picture
The inflation picture also looked better.
The implicit price deflator was revised
downward to 1.31 growth from 1.61. The
fixed weighted price index remained the
same at 2.61.
The purchasing managers report found
that production, new orders and employment all grew more slowly in the manufacturing sector last month. Despite a slowdown in jobs, "a number of purchasing
managers reported tight markets in manufacturing labor in their areas," said Ralph
Kauffman, chairman of the survey and.
manager of procurement and materials at
Oryx Energy Co.
In the latest report, purchasing managers also expressed concern over the
Mexican peso crisis. Export orders slowed
last month, and several companies said the
problems in Mexico played a role.
Also, the Commerce Department said
construction spending fell 0.21 in January
to S426.3 billion, after adjustments for
inflation. Residential construction fell
while commercial and public construction
increased.
All figures have been adjusted for normal seasonal variations.

GIORDANO TO RETURN TO BEIJING
Giordano Holdings Ltd., a Hong Kong
clothing retailer that was forced in August
to close its Beijing store, is being allowed
to return to the Chinese capital. City
officials had questioned a franchisee's
license, but politics was suspected after a
former Giordano official's magazine called
China's premier unflattering names. Giordano, which operates 45 stores in China
and expects to open 50 more this year, has
received about a dozen offers from wouldbe Beijing franchisees.

MEXICO CITY - Former Mexican
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari withdrew his bid to head the World Trade
Organization.
Mr. Salinas's announcement followed
the arrest Tuesday of his elder brother,
Raul, on charges of orchestrating the
assassination last year of a senior rulingparty official.
Diplomats said the Mexican political
turmoil had already undermined the former president's chances of assuming the
top post at the WTO, the successor
body to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. U.S. officials, who had
been among Mr. Salinas's biggest
backers, appeared to waver in their
support following Tuesday's arrest.
Mr. Salinas is a director of Dow Jones
& Co., publisher of this newspaper.
The former Mexican president's with- j
drawal from the WTO race appears to
greatly improve the prospects of Renato
Ruggiero, the candidate backed by the
European Union. Mr. Ruggiero, a former;
Italian trade minister, had already gar-nered the support of nearly one-half ojjj
the WTO's member nations. The other;
official candidate is Kim Chul Su, a for
mer South Korean trade minister backed'
by Japan and other Asian nationa.

By AMY DOCKSER MARCUS

KAFR BARA. Israel - For years, radical Islamic groups in the West Bank and
Gaza Strip have been Israel's Me noir. But
lately, officials have begun worrying about
whether there's a growing Islamic threat
in the heart of Israel itself.
An Islamic movement among Israeli
Arabs is enjoying growing electoral clout.
In the most recent municipal elections, its
members won seats on more than a dozen
local councils and captured the mayoralty
or council chairmanship in seven places.
Islamic leaders say they may set up a
political party to run for Israeli Parliament
seats in the 1996 national elections.
If Israel's S O O Arab citizens unite
OO O
.
; behind a party backed by the Islamic
movement, experts estimate that Arab
parties can increase their representation
in the 120-member Parliament from five
seats to as many as 15, giving the communitv unprecedented leverage in Israeli poli: tics!
So great is the perceived threat that the
opposition Likud party is discussing
whether to try to bar the Islamic movement
• from running in the next elections.
The movement's current rise is fueled
by frustration over the peace process
among Israeli Arabs, who make up 181 of
the Israeli population. Israeli Arabs had
expected the peace agreement between
Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization to bring about an end to decades of
discrimination in jobs, housing and education. Instead, more than a year after the
• Israel-PLO deal, many Israeli Arabs feel
that Mr. Rabin is making peace with the
country's Arab enemies but continuing
to neglect the demands for equality by
. Israel's own loyal Arab population.
"We are no longer ready to sacrifice
our own interests for the sake of the peace
process." says Sheik Ibrahim Sarsur, an
Mamie movement leader.
The Islamic movement's origins lie in
the Family of the Holy War, an underground paramilitary group set up in the
early 1980s whose 70 Israeli Arab members
were arrested and sentenced to prison
terms after carrying out a number of acts
of sabotage, including arson. Since then,
the group has been careful to stay within
the bounds of Israeli law.
"We obey Israeli law, and we accept
Israel's right to exist." says Sheik Sarsur.
But one Israeli official says, "They
skate right on the edge." and worries that
their unspoken message to followers encourages anti-Israel sentiments. Leaders
of the Gaza-based Islamic Jihad say some
Israeli Arabs have volunteered to lead
suicide attacks against Israeli targets.
The movement's power comes from the
vast social infrastructure it has built up
over the years. Using donations of money,
Islamic activists also upset the delicate
balancing act performed by the current
crop of Israeli Arab politicians. Walid
Sadik, an Israeli Arab serving as the
deputy minister of agriculture, shares
many of the same goals as the Islamic
activists but believes the best chance for
advancement lies in Arab integration
within existing political parties. The movement's aggressive "Arab power" message.

state in part of Palestine is sincere or
merely the pragmatic response of a minority trying to get along with the dominant
culture.
contends Mr. Sadik, may increase the
number of Arab seats in the Parliament in
the next elections, but will ultimately scare
the ruling Labor Party into the arms of the

" I don't think the Islamic movement
can deliver the goods. They see the world
in black and white." says Mr. Sadik.
"National politics requires seeing all the
colors in the middle."
And'yet for all their differences, the
peace process is narrowing the distance
between moderates like Mr. Sadik and
Islamic activists. The two sides find common ground on the issue of Israel's

not the state of all its citizens," says Kafr

Employers Confront Domestic Abuse
By JOSEPH PEREIRA
S t a f f Reporter of T H E W A L L S T R E E T J O U R N A L
Patrick Thomas was sentenced to life in
prison in 1993 for gunning down his former
girlfriend at her Houston office.
Then, the family of 22-year-old Francesia La Rose sued her employer and the
property firm that ran the office building
for failing to protect her - even though she
notified them that a restraining order had
been issued against Mr. Thomas. Ms. La
Rose had expressed fear that he would kill
her. "They didn't believe her story," says
her mother, Margaret La Rose.
State Mutual Life Assurance Co., Ms.
La Rose's employer, and the property
company, Duddlesten Management Co.,
denied any wrongdoing. But last month
they settled the case in Texas district court
in Houston for more than 5350,000.
The case is among the first workplaceviolence lawsuits in which the perpetrator
is an ex-boyfriend or husband. Domestic
violence is spilling into the workplace,
though inumbers are hard to come by.
Homicide was the No. 2 cause of death in
the workplace in 1992, according to the
Bureau of Labor Statistics. And in the year
ended July 1993, 2.2 million people were
attacked at work, according to Northwestern National Life Insurance Co., Minneapolis. Neither survey tracked incidents
involving abusive partners.
In the past, employers who learned of
domestic violence often looked the other
way. But that's changing, with more
women in the workplace, high divorce
rates and more antistalking orders against
abusers. More companies are wrestling
with the issue partly out of humane concern, but also to keep talent, reduce absenteeism and avoid liability.
"This is a relatively unexplored area
for companies," says Richard Gelles, director of the Family Violence Research
Project at Rhode Island University. And
experts say civil actions - including
those against employers-will increase under the federal Violence Against Women
Act, effective this year. It makes battering
t ^Vften the only place a
X J batterer can find a
woman is at work,' says a
Harvard School of Public
Health researcher.
a civil rights violation and stiffens compensatory damages.
As part of efforts to guard against
workplace violence, some companies are
developing antiabuse programs.
Liz Claiborne Inc. holds seminars on
domestic violence issues annually for employees-on company time. Ceridian Corp.
provides a 24-hour telephone counseling
service for employees and their partners.
Polaroid Corp. taps the phones of women
who fear an attack, escorts them to and
from parking lots and occasionally posts
guards at their homes. The company also
seeks restraining orders in its name to
keep alleged abusers away from potential
Firms Forced to Face
Domestic Abuse as It
Spills Into Workplace
Continued From Page Bl
simply walk away."
Especially problematic is the relative
openness of many offices. In Houston, Ms.
La Rose worked as a clerk in an eighthfloor office and had asked for a desk out of
sight of the entranceway. "She was moved
to a different desk," her mother says, "but
she was still in sight of the front door.
Patrick, her ex-boyfriend, saw her from
the hallway, came in and just put the gun
to her head."
Even elaborate security systems can be
foiled. Last year. Army Sgt. Colton Holbrook was convicted of stalking and attempting to kill his ex-girl friend, Christine
Facey. at AT&T headquarters in Basking
Ridge. N.J. Although computerized access
passes are needed to open the doors, Sgt.
Holbrook was let in after he told a colleague of Ms. Facey's that he had a
surprise engagement ring for her. "People
may be a bit more leery of people walking
in the streets of New York, but in an office
environment, people's guards are down,"
says AT&T spokesman Burk Stihson.
victims' work sites, even when the suspect
is an employee.
Before Ken Wilson, a technician under state-court order to stay away from his
wife, visits her office at Polaroid, he calls
to alert her and her on-site counselor, saysJim Hardeman, a manager. Mr. Wilson
couldn't be reached last night. Mr. Wilson's wife. Elizabeth Wilson, an administrative assistant, says, "I feel completely
safe where 1 work; I know he's not going to
try anything."
Most battering occurs at home. But
experts theorize that workplace attacks
have increased as more women leave
abusive homes. "Often the only place a
batterer can find a woman is at work,"
says Nancy Isaac, a researcher at the
Harvard School of Public Health who is
studying corporate responses to domestic
violence.
Many companies are wary of greater
involvement, reasoning that knowledge of
abuse would leave them open to liability
should violence occur. Experts say there's
little liability when an employer isn't
aware of domestic abuse/ But when a
company is informed by the victim or takes
an interest in a case, it exposes itself to
charges of negligence.
"It's almost like a guy drowning in a
lake," says Fredrica Lehrman, head of the
domestic-violence project for the Trial
Lawyers Association. "If you toss him a
rope and bungle it, you could be in a
worse-off position than if you were to
Please Turn to Page BIO, Column 3
S m companies go to extraordinary
o e
lengths. Ms. Lehrman, whose Washington
law firm Shaw, Pittman, Potts. & Trowbridge, advises companies on domestic
violence for free, says one client sent an
abused employee into hiding. As the
woman's husband waited outside with a
gun, company officials slipped her out
through a back parking lot, drove her to the
airport and put her on a plane to a distant
city, she says.
But family-law experts say such cases
are still exceptions. Lacking reliable estimates, female executives at several New
England companies recently joined together to raise money for a study on the
potential financial impact of abuse on
employers.
Experts say that until a financial assessment is made, business won't take
domestic violence seriously. Companies
are just now beginning to look at the issue,
says Harvard's Dr. Isaac. "I think corporate America's awareness of domestic violence is about where it was with substance
abuse 2 years ago."

WASHINGTON - Treasury Secretnrv
Robert Rubin, pushing to deregulate the
financial-services business, sought to assure Congress that federally insured banks
can be insulated from the risks of being
involved in the securities and insurance
industries.
Worries about exposing banks to new
risks form the main obstacle to tearing
down the 1933 Glass-Steagall Act. which
has kept banks out of most securities
activities. Testifying in the House Banking
Committee, Mr. Rubin warned lawmakers
not to set up so many safeguards and
"fire walls" that the benefits of diverse
financial-service entities are thwarted.
"While we believe that appropriate
fire walls can be very helpful, there also is
a real danger that they can become excessive and rigid in nature," he said.
The administration criticized a pro-
posal by Rep. Jim Leach (R.. Iowa), chairman of the banking panel, because it
nesses be set up as separate subsidiaries
under a holding company. Mr. Rubin's
plan would allow a bank to create or
acquire a securities subsidiary.
Mr. Rubin also took exception to a
provision in the Leach bill that would
require the different financial subsidiaries
to have separate boards. Mixing the directors could be "appropriate and even beneficial." he said.
The secretary said financial affiliates
could be structured so that losses from a
securities or insurance unit wouldn't affect
the capital of the parent bank. Specifically,
he said that under the administration plan,
a federally insured bank could set up a
securities affiliate, but not count the capital of that unit as part of the bank capital.
In such a situation, he added, "the subsidiary could get wiped out, but not affect the
capital of the bank."
Mr. Rubin also stressed that the greatest risk for a bank is a traditional loan, not
a securities underwriting. A bank often
carries a loan on its books for years, while
in an underwriting, the investment bank
moves the securities through in a matter of
hours.

Aiding Prosecutions, Justices Allow Use
Of Some Improperly Obtained Evidence
By PAUL M. BARRETT
S t a f f Reporter of T H E W A L L S T R E E T J O U R N A L
WASHINGTON - The Supreme Court,
in a pro-prosecution decision, ruled that
judges shouldn't throw out criminal evidence gathered improperly on the basis of
faulty computer records.
The 7-2 ruling was a reminder that even
following two appointments by President
Clinton, the Supreme Court remains moderately conservative on many criminal-law
issues. One Clinton appointee, Justice Stephen Breyer, joined the majority opinion;
the other. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg,
dissented.
Writing for the majority, Chief Justice
William Rehnquist cast the decision in
narrow terms, shaped by the specific facts
of the case. Some scholars had anticipated
that the high court might use the case to
make a broad statement about the application of the Constitution to computer-age
technology in. law enforcement. But the
chief justice refrained from any such, pronouncements.
The ruling concerned the prosecution of
Isaac Evans, of Phoenix, on drug charges.
A police officer stopped Mr. Evans in 1991
for a routine traffic violation. Using a
computer terminal in his patrol car. the
officer discovered a misdemeanor arrest
warrant for Mr. Evans. In the course
of arresting him, the officer found a bag
of marijuana in Mr. Evans's car..
It later turned out that the arrest warrant had been canceled and a court clerk
apparently had failed to eliminate it from

* * *
SMALL MAKERS of medical devices
back a bill that mainly helps big firms.
A bit) that would protect manufacturers of raw materials used in medical
implants from liability lawsuits is winning
praise from many small health-device
makers. Most of these suppliers are large
concerns.
Small device makers say they haven't
been able to buy so-called biomaterials
from big manufacturers because those
suppliers don't want to expose themselves
to legal action if devices fail. Large
device makers generally haven't had this
.problem as they can afford to indemnify
the suppliers.
Without access to raw materials such
as silicone, some small firms say they have
had to stop developing, testing or making
medical implants. "It's a crisis," says
Thomas Thompson, chairman of the Medical Device Manufacturers Association and
president of Quest Medical Inc. in Allen,
Texas.
InControl Inc. of Redmond, Wash.,
says it lost its source of silicone in 1993
when its supplier stopped selling the synthetic to small implant makers. InControl,
which is developing an implant that would
help control a common heart-rhythm disorder, is now working with ah expensive
substitute material. Furthermore, the
company has had to spend extra time and
money testing the substitute, says Gena
Sears, the company's marketing vice president. "Our cost of development has be-
come more of a burden," she adds.
The bill, sponsored by Sen. Joseph
Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, Sen.
John McCain, an Arizona Republican, and
Rep. George W. Gekas, a Pennsylvania
Republican, would seek to dismiss product
liability lawsuits brought against suppliers
whose raw materials met contract specifications. It wouldn't exempt suppliers
whose raw materials caused or contributed
to the failure of a finished device.
Still, some consumer groups argue that
the proposed legislation would put patients
at risk while protecting large corporations.
But Ms. Sears says countless life-saving products will never reach patients
unless raw-material suppliers feel they can
sell to device makers without getting sued
if the finished product goes awry.
"What's the alternative?"Ms. Sears
asks. ''The alternative is that you stifle
opportunities to move forward. You stifle
innovation."

�Letters to the Editor
Christian Coalition's Janus Face
In his February Ki editorial-page commentary "Conservative Coalition Koicls
Finn." Ralph KYert optimistically claims
that "the much anticipated holy war' pitting moderates against religious people in
the GOP ended without a single shot being
fired." The implication that being moderate and being religious are mutually exclusive is typically offensive fare from the
Christian Coalition. But his swipe at religious moderates aside. Mr. Reed is simplywrong. Sure, there may be agreement
among Republicans on much of Newt Gingrich's "Contract With America." But
when Religious Right political groups turn
their focus on curbing reproductive freedoms, pushing organized classroom
. prayer, defunding public television and depriving gays and lesbians of the basic rights
of citizenship, Mr. Reed's peace declaration
will be about as likely to ward off war in the
GOP as Neville Chamberlain's umbrella.
Actually, the opening shots were being
fired-by Mr. Reed himself-even before
his Wall Street Journal article appeared.
Just days before he used your paper to call
for "unity" and "civil[ityl in disagreement" between economic and religious
conservatives, Mr. Reed was drawing a
line in the sand over abortion. If either the
' 1996 Republican presidential or vice presidential nominee favors a woman's right to
choose, Mr. Reed vowed to a conservative
gathering, his supporters would abandon
the GOP ticket.
For those who may be confused, Mr.
Reed's apparent about-face was just the
most recent example of the Christian
Coalition's good cop/bad cop routine. Good
cop Reed tells the press he is promoting
Rep. Gingrich's Contract as part of a broad
"pro-family" agenda. But bad cop Reed
tells his followers that working for the Contract is a tactical maneuver to force Republican Party support for the coalition's
more divisive social agenda. Moreover, the
escalating battle over the nomination of
•Dr. Henry Foster as Surgeon Generaland Religious Right leaders' increasinglynasty rhetoric-are exposing as fallacy
Mr. Reed's efforts to portray budgetary issues as his constituents' first priority.
So let's put the smiley buttons aside and
look at the real Christian Coalition agenda,
which is already emerging in Congress.
Mr. Reed backs the effort to junk the
National Endowment for the Arts, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the
Legal Services Corporation even as he
fails to explain how cutting support for museums, educational children's television,
. and local music and dance groups would
• help the families for whom he expresses
such concern. He pushes the discredited
notion that public TV viewers are all
wealthy, and asks why they should be
spared when single mothers are asked to
.make sacrifices. Where is all that compassion when Mr. Reed calls for cutting the
Legal Services lawyers who represent
those mothers in seeking child support
from deadbeat dads or challenging mis• managed child-welfare bureaucracies?
On education, Mr. Reed says, we need
to "shift power and responsibility for educating children away from Washington
and return it to local school boards and
parents." Sounds reasonable, but the truth
is that primary responsibility for educating children has never been in Washington; that responsibility overwhelmingly
rests with parents, local boards and state
education officials. The language of
parental control used by Ralph Reed actually puts a populist veneer on a radically
antipopulist goal: vouchers that would undermine public education by siphoning its
Wrong Spin on Ruling
i On Cellular Spinoff
resources to private religious schools-in
many cases to so-called Christian academies originally created to avoid r;:da! ini
tegration of the public schools.
Finally, Mr. Reed calls for Congress
to "secure religious liberty and freedom
of conscience for all citizens." Once
again, he advances a noble-sounding
goal to promote something far different.
There is no need for a constitutional
amendment to secure religious freedom.
We have the First Amendment, which although constantly challenged by Mr.
Reed and his mentor Pat Robertson, still
is the greatest guarantor of religious liberty in the world today.
Those of us who are familiar with the
Christian Coalition's strategy-putting a
moderate face before the public while
reassuring hard-core activists that patience will bring victory' for the extreme
social agenda-are adept at reading between the lines.
ARTHUR KROPP
President
People for the American Way
Washington
Your Feb. 2 editorial "Justice s Air
Ball." about our AirTouch decision, is out
of touch with both the facts and the law.
First, we agreed with AirTouch that
its new spunoff cellular business should
be freed from many of the restrictions of
the consent decree that broke up AT&T.
We offered to support the company in a
waiver request.
But AirTouch flatly turned us down and
chose all-out litigation instead because of
its objection to being labeled a "successor" to Pactel, its Baby Bell parent. Virtually all antitrust decrees contain provisions making them applicable.to "successors" in order to prevent easy evasion by
simply spinning off a new corporate Entity
to the same shareholders.
Second, our decision does not mean,
as you imply, that every time a Regional
Bell Operating Company sells a piece of
real estate or a cellular tower, the purchaser is subject to the decree. Isolated
asset sales are not the same as spinning
off an entire business, as was the case
with Pactel's cellular operations.
Finally, even though we disagreed with
AirTouch on the applicability of the decree, we indicated we would not seek
sanctions against it during the time it
asks the court for a declaratory ruling. In
short, we have been more than fair with
AirTouch. while at the same time carrying out our legal responsibilities to enforce the consent decree.
We agree on one thing, however: on the
need for federal legislation to set a national policy on telecommunications. But
that legislation must also preserve the central role for real competition that motivated the AT&T case and breakup, events
which have helped revolutionize telecommunications markets in the U.S. and kept
our telecommunications industry ahead of
the rest of the world. The administration
will be working with the Congress this
year to produce such legislation.
* * *
Mr. Reed has me very confused. Is the
man who authored this piece the same man
who, three days earlier (before a CPAC
meeting in Washington), threatened the
Republican Party with a "litmus test" for
its national ticket? Did he not say that
"pro-life and pro-family voters will not support a ticket that retreats from its noble
and historic defense of traditional values
or which has a national ticket or a platform
that does not share Ronald Reagan's belief
in the sanctity of innocent human life?"
Seventy-two hours later Mr. Reed was
saying it is best to acknowledge disagreements over issues such as abortion
forthrightly and "discuss them freely
while stressing unity on the broader
agenda." Mr. Reed would do his membership and registered Republicans nationally a great service by deciding
whether he is the angry firebrand or the
more moderate party builder.
The Christian Coalition is an important
voice in a much larger choir. Recent figures show that the Christian Coalition's
membership represents only 157c of registered Republicans nationally. And while
Washington
the turnout of self-identified born-again
evangelicals in the last election was commendable, it was still only 22% of the total
Republican turnout.
Sen. Arlen Specter put it concisely
when he said that Mr. Reed's remarks
make "second-class citizens" out of any
pro-choice Republican who may aspire to
the party's nomination. "The Republican
Party will not be blackmailed by any special-interest group. Our nominee will be
selected in the Republican primaries."
I would encourage Mr. Reed to consider
Gov. William Weld's remarks, as quoted in
the Associated Press, that it is intellectually dishonest for conservatives to advocate less government "while keeping a foot
on individual liberty."
ANNE K. BINGAMAN
Assistant Attorney General
Antitrust Division
Department of Justice
MICHAEL CUDAHY
National Political Director
Republican Coalition for Choice
Washington

�THE WALL STREET JQt RNAL THURSDAY. FEBRUARY 16. 1995
The Myth of Deadbeat Dads
By STV\RT A. MILLER
Child-support collection has' recently
become a big issue in Washington. President Clinton issued an executive nrcler this
week requiring all federal agencies \o facilitate the payment of fathers' debts. And
Health and- Human Senices Secretary
Donna Shalala testified that if we collect
all of the child support owed by Americans, we would reduce the $200 billion welfare cost by 25^. In fact. Republicans and
Democrats alike count on increased child
support collections as a cornerstone of
their welfare reform plans.
You don't have to be a member of the.
world champion U.S. Math Olympiad team
to see that there is something wrong with
those calculations. Even under the rosiest
projections of the government's Annual
Child Support Report, in 1992 (the last year
for which data are available! there was
about $10.9 billion in court-ordered child
support owed by all Americans and, of
that, a little more than $6 billion was paid.
This leaves $-1.9 billion in unpaid child support in 1992-far short of the $50 billion Ms.
Shalala hopes to raise.
But it's virtually impossible even to collect the smaller amount of child support
obligations. We've tried many times over
the past 1 years, yet no effort has in0
creased the percentage of collections for
welfare mothers (the biggest target group)
by more than r,.
This is due to a number of factors.
First, of the 30' > of child support payments
not collected, a significant number are
owed by fathers who are imprisoned. A
high percentage' of prisoners have childsupport obligations, and as many as onethird of the inmates in many county jails
are there in the first place because of child
support noncompliance.
Many of the other delinquent fathers are
addicts, alcoholics, disabled, mentally incapacitated, unemployed, or otherwise unable to pay pre-set child support amounts.
But the largest number of all delinquents
are those who simply don't exist.
Recently, the Florida Department of
Revenue, the agency responsible for child
support enforcement in that state, sent out
7(10.000 notices to allegedly delinquent fathers. The summonses demanded immediate payment or the recipient would be incarcerated. Subsequently, officials acknowledged that probably 500,000 of those
notices were sent to individuals who actually did not owe child support. One of those
recipients, Daniel Wells, died eight years
ago in a traffic accident, but the state still
wanted him to cough up $160,000 in pastdue -child support! (About the same
amount of money Florida wasted on
postage for the notices.)
Nor is this an isolated case. The General Accounting Office found in 1992 that-as
many as l-Tc of fathers who owe child support are dead. The report further stated
that 66^ of fathers who owe support "cannot afford to pay the amount ordered."
The easiest way, then, to increase the
figures on child-support collections is simply for the government to make an accurate tally. Until this happens, it's impossible to discuss remedies for the child-support problem.
Once a serious discussion gets under
way, one of the first items on the agenda
should be the inherent unfairness in taking something away from people and then
making them pay for it. Most, fathers are
deeply committed to their children, yet a
1991 Census Bureau study found that about
half of fathers receive no court-ordered
visitation. When fathers do receive visitation, almost SO'" pay all of their child support on time.and in full. When fathers receive joint custody, the child-support compliance rate jumps to more than 90'".
Joint custody is the cure to the child
support problem and is the closest thing to
a two-parent family that we can give a
child. Unfortunately, more than 90': of litigated divorces result in an award of sole
. custodv to the mother.
Even when fathers do receive court-ordered access to their children; their visitation attempts are often met with interference by the mothers. Joan Berlin Kelley
and Judith Wallerstein. in "Surviving the
Break-Up" (Basic Bonks, IW.JI. fnunci that
almost half of all mothers see no value in
the father's continued contact with his children following separation or divorce. Sanford Braver, a University of Arizona psychologist, confirmed these figures and
found that up to 40'"' of mothers interfere
with the dad's relationship with his kids.
Given this documented connection between a father's access to his children and
the payment of child support, why d"es
Washington seem intent on punishing the
father'. What about the mother who creates
a climate encouraging noneumplianee?
One way around this problem may be to
make child-support obligations more equitable. At'the moment, child support is almost exclusively the burden of fathers.
The federal Office of Income Security Pol- ',
icy found in •1991 that less than :',>)' '. of custodial fathers receive a child support
award, whereas almost SO'- of custodial
mothers do. Yet about 47, of those moth- J
ers who are ordered to pay support totally :
default on their obligation. In the interest
of fairness, if nothing else, policy makers
should make an effort to collect child support from both delinquent fathers and
mothers.
'
But of course the only real long-term :
answer is to support the two-parent f.imily-preferably in marriage a-i\d. if that •
doesn't work, through joint custody
arrangements. We need to re-engage lathers in their children's lives. Draconian'
transfer-of-wealth schemes will continue
to be as ineffective in the future as they
have proved to be in the past, no matter
how aggressively they are enforced.

By TKKKY EASTLAND
Does President Clinton's decision, to order an "intense, urgent review" of all federal affirmative action programs mean he
is about to take on the task of reforming
and even eliminating government policies
and programs that allocate benefits and
opportunities on the basis of race?
Very little in Bill Clinton's 1»92 campaign or his presidency prepares us for
this kind of President Clinton. True, in
"Putting People First." Gov. Clinton and
Sen. Gore vowed that they would "oppose
racial quotas." But Mr. Clinton, like many
in both parties who say they oppose quotas, never explained precisely what such
opposition would mean. Nor did he feature
this particular promise in his campaign.
As president, Mr. Clinton's greatest
claim to civil rights fame-meaning the
one he and his associates tout-concerns
executive and judicial appointments made
on the basis of "diversity," the now fashionable word for race and gender. He
widely advertised for a female attorney
general, for example, and persevered
through the ill-fated choices of Zoe Baird
and Kimba Wood until he finally got one.
Political Correctness
Within the administration itself, some
.of Mr. Clinton's more dedicated subordinates have imposed political correctness
upon federal workers. Regional administrators for HUD were told last year, for example, that to meet performance standards each should participate "as un active member of a minority, feminist or
other cultural organization."
As for people Mr. Clinton has appointed
to civil rights posts, Mary Frances Berry,
head of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission,
is on record as saying that "civil l ights
laws were not passed to give civil rights to
all Americans" but only to "disfavored
groups" such as "blacks. Hispanics and
women." The president hasn't appointed a
"new Democrat" critic of affirmative action to a civil rights j o b - i n fact very few
new Democi ats labor anywhere in his government.
With regard to policy, until late last
week. Mr. Clinton had said nothing to suggest that reform of affirmative action even
interested him. Given the record of his administration, moreover, the conclusion is
unavoidable that Mr. Clinton has sought to
strengthen and extend, and even revive,
affirmative action.
In 199,'t. Education Secretary Richard
Riley overturned a Bush administration
policy interpreting federal law as prohibiting universities receiving federal dollars
from offering scholarships on the basis of
race. Under the new policy, colleges don't
have to premise race-exclusive scholarships on a showing of past discrimination
and can determine for themselves whether
there have been instances of racism in
their past. In a law enforcement action in
keeping with the new Education policy, the
Justice Department's Civil Rights Division
has defended, so far unsuccessfully, the
University of Maryland's Banneker Schol-
ilornians favor. Because California is crucial to Mr. Clinton's re-election strategy,
and because the future of affirmative action is emerging as a major campaign issue, he cannot afford to be complacent
about affirmative action as currently practiced, much less defend it in the unyielding
terms advanced by, say, Jesse Jackson.
Mr. Clinton's new position has thankfully tended to silence defenders ol statusquo affirmative action who (all anyone
who proposes to reform or eliminate it a
racist comparable to Hitler. Hut what is
the administration's review likely to produce? Almost certainly another battle for
Mr. Clinton's soul.
On civil rights, we have seen such a
battle before, in 1993, when the President
Given the record of his administration, the conclusion
is unavoidable that Mr. Clinton has sought to strengthen
and extend, and even revive, affirmative action.
arships, available only to black students.
The Bush administration had stayed out of
this case, brought by a student of Costa Rican descent.
Deval Patrick, the assistant attorney
general in charge of the civil rights division, recently told the Washington Post,
"There is good affirmative action and
there is bad affirmative action." Hut on his
watch there has been no bad affirmative
action. With respect to education, employment, contracting and voting rights, the

had to decide whether to withdraw the
nomination of Lani Guinier, his first
choice to head the civil rights division. Mr.

writings and concluded he disagreed with

M Treatment
President Clinton and Republican Sen. Bob Dole, in a
preview of a possible 1996
presidential campaign debate,
are jabbing at each other's foreign policy Ideals.
Clinton, in a speech Wednesday to a foreign policy group,
criticized the "new isolationism" of those who want to cut
contributions to peacekeeping
Dole earlier told the group
there needs to be a "new realism" In relations with Russia,
Iraq and Iran.
But both men caution
against post-Cold War complacency and withdrawal from
the world's troubles.
"There is a struggle going on
between those who want to carry on the tradition of American
leadership and those who
would advocate a new isolationism," Clinton said.
Dole calls Clinton's policies
toward Russia too soft
"New realism means that
developments like arms sales
to Iran, violence in Chechnya
and U.N. vetoes on behalf of
aggressors should not be excused, ignored and minimized," said Dole of Kansas.
He sajd the world will continue to "test America's resolve
and her leadership. If we ...
refuse the mantle of leadership, any declaration of victory
will be a long time coming."
Clinton has said he'll veto a
House bill cutting U.N. contributions and requiring congressional approval of U.S. forces
in peacekeeping efforts. Dole
backs a similar Senate bill.
The U.S. peacekeeping tab
this year is $1 billion. There
are 60,000 U.N. peacekeepers
deployed worldwide, including
those now leaving Somalia.
Cuts, Clinton said, "would
eliminate any meaningful role
for the United Nations" and
deny "resources to peacekeepers and even to our troops and
squander them on 'star wars.'"
Clinton also announced the
withdrawal of 200 tons of fissionable material, "enough for
thousands of nuclear weapons," from the VS. nuclear
stockpile as a commitment tc
nuclear non-proliferation.
helps repair
HIV damage
By Doug Levy
USA TODAY
A naturally occurring protein may help rebuild the damaged immune system in some
people infected with the AIDS
virus, researchers report
The small, preliminary experiment found interleukin-2,'
an immune system protein, significantly boosted the number
of immune system cells in
some HIV-infected patients for
up to two years.
"I'm very excited," says Dr.
Clifford Lane of the National
Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
"We think this is essentially
the first time (anyone) has
been able to therapeutically
manipulate the immune system in a very substantial way."
Lane led the research effort
reported in today's New England Journal of Medicine.
Each patient received the
protein continuously for five
consecutive days, every two
months. They also took dru£
such as AZT, which target the
AIDS virus itself.
Ten patients began treatment while their CD4+ T cell
counts — a measure of their
immune system integrity —
were above 200.
In six of them, the interieukln-2 treatment Increased T
cell counts more than 50%.
But the treatment had this
effect in only two of the 15 patients who began with T cell
counts under 200 — meaning
they had progressed to AIDS.
The results suggest that interleukin-2 interferes with the
virus' assault on disease-fighting CD4+ T cells.
But administering it by Infusion, as in this study, is impractical on a large scale. The treatment also has significant side
effects such as fever, diarrhea
and reduced blood pressure.
Still, the researchers consider thefindingevidence a damaged immune system may be
repaired in some patients.

In some of the most troubling cases, no one catches the
warning signs, or pieces them together, until it's too late.
Neighbors recall seeing Donna Fleming weeping on the
Long Beach, Calif., bridge from which she later threw 22month-old Craig, who drowned, and 3-year-old Michael Jr.,
who survived. SixflmesIn the past 13 months, police went to
Fleming's home on complaints she was being beaten by husband Michael Sr., who was twice convicted of spouse abuse.
And six days before Fleming and her boys plunged from the
bridge, she got an abortion. She couldn't bear another child
"when I can't take care of these two," she told a friend.
Still, "It's not nearly as simple as it looks in the newspaper"
to predict such tragedies, let alone prevent them, says Winn, of
the Ada S. McKlnley Foster Care and Adoption Services.
Experts propose conflicting remedies:
• To stem what she calls "an epidemic of over-reporting,"
Mack urges states to ease mandatory reporting laws, and to
hold citizens legally liable forfilingfalse reports.
• Ryan Ralney, of the National Center for Prosecution of
Child Abuse, wants states to rethink the mandate that agencies
keep families together whenever possible. When accused
abusers gets kids back, he says, abuse often escalates, children
are scared Into recanting and cases collapse.
• Durfee says every state should form child abuse review
boards — teams of doctors, prosecutors, cops and social workers — to examine possible cases of serious maltreatment

Clinton cracks down
on food stamp fraud
The Clinton administration announced a broad strike
against food stamp fraud Wednesday to ensure the $27 billion a year program serves the needy, not the greedy. The
crackdown imposes tougher requirements on authorized
food stamp dealers and tightens screening to prevent people from buying selling or trading food stamps for cash or
other non-food items like drugs and guns. An estimated $1
billion a year in taxpayer money is lost to food stamp fraud.
"We are ensuring that the food stamp program will earn the
public trust, and continue to help the people who need it,"
President Clinton said in a statement
Concern for school lunches
Marine sniper kills gunman
as Somalis reclaim airport
A Marine sniper killed a Somalian gunman Wednesday
as U.N. troops neared the end of their withdrawal. The Somali hadfireda rocket-propelled grenade into the ocean
behind U.S. lines. Withdrawing Pakistanis are thefinalremnant of a once 28,000-strong U.N. force. As they pulled back,
warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid's militiamen swept into
the Mogadishu airport, chasing away looters andfillingthe
void left by the U.N. retreat U.S. and Italian troops watched
from the nearby dunes while the militiamen loyal to Aidid,
who once carried a $25,000 U.N. price on his head, roared
through the airport gates in stripped-down trucks and jeeps
mounted with heavy weapons. U.S. commanders say the
U.N. pullout could be complete by the end of the day today.
SALINAS WITHDRAWS:
Former Mexican president Carlos
Salinas de Gortari ended his candidacy to lead the World Trade Organization, a day after his brother
was arrested and charged in a conspiracy to assassinate a top political leader. The WTO is to replace
the General Agreement on Tariffs
and Trade (GATT).
Salinas' decision spared the
Reuters White House the unpleasant task of
SALINAS: Ends bid reversing its support for his candidacy, which was opposed by candidates from Europe and Asia. Salinas' chances also were
badly damaged by the peso crisis that started three weeks
after he left offlce.

Listyev, 38executive director of Russia's Ostankino Channel One, was shot once in the heart Listyev is the second
