VISfT: First lady Hillary Rodham Clinton meets pupils
Wednesday at Long Branch Elementary in Arlington, Va.
Clinton and Democrats visited the school to discuss lunch
subsidies, a program Republicans would give to states.
ABORTION DEBATE: Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee today plan to pass a measure allowing states to stop funding abortions for poor women in cases
ofrapeand incest Rep. Emest Istook, R-Okla., plans to offer an amendment that wouldreversea Clinton administration policy requiring states to use public funds to pay for
abortions in cases of rape and incest and when the woman's
life is endangered. House Speaker Newt Gingrich first said
he would not vote for Istook's amendment "I think it is a
legitimate condition in the Medicaid program." But later,
he reversed his position, saying states should be allowed —
but notrequired— to pay for those abortions.
PENA PROBE CONFIRMED: The Justice Departmenfs criminal division is reviewing what role, if any,
Transportation Secretary Federico Pena played in the
award of a Los Angeles transit system contract to his former management company, government officials said.
Pena has denied any impropriety in his dealings with the
managementfirm,Pena Investment Advisers Inc., a Denver money management company he founded.
LUGAR DECISION: Indiana Sen. Richard Lugar, 62,
willrevealwhether he'll run for the 1996 GOP presidential
nomination today on CNN's Larry King Live at 9 p.m. ET.
BALKAN MOVES: Assistant Secretary of State Richard
Holbrooke visits Croatia next week to try to persuade President Franjo Tudjman not to order U.N. troops to leave. U.S.
officials fear the withdrawal may widen the Balkan war.
BIG BANG: Semtex, a brand of plastic explosive favored
by guerrillas worldwide, stole the commercial spotlight
show when over 670 newly-private Czech firms began
share-trading. Buyersflockedto snatch up Semtex stock,
sending it to the maximum $53 a share; no other stocks had
much action. The plastic explosive, which comes in red, orange or black blocks similar to modelling clay, has been
used in a string of attacks, including the 1988 bombing of
PanAm Flight 103, which killed 270 people.

cooperator in thefightagainst drug trafficking but said it
would continue aid to the cocaine-producing country....
The Cabinet career of Winnie Mandela, the estranged wife
of South Africa's president appears to be at an end. Police
raided her luxury Soweto home after receiving information
that she had used her position to win low-cost housing contracts for a firm in which she hasfinancialinterests. Mandela said the raid was an attempt to discredit her.... British
Prime Minister John Major won a 319-to-314 vote in Parliament Wednesday for his government's policy toward the
European Union. The issue has split his Conservative Party.

Democratic Sen. Kent Conrad says he's standing on principle when he opposes the balanced budget amendment:
"The Social Security Trust
Fund should not be looted."
But on the other side, GOP
Leader Bob Dole says he's
pushing the balanced budget
amendment for a similar principle: "We feel strongly about
protecting Social Security."
Often called the third rail of
U.S. politics. Social Security is
once a ^ i n at the center of a
political debate.
Both sides in the battle over
the constitutional amendment
say they are acting in the best
interests of Social Security and
the people who depend on i t
But which side is right?
The answer isn't easy. The
Senate's debate has done little
to clarify the role Social Security plays in obscuring the true
size of the nation's budget problems on the books.
And whatever happens, the
Social Security system likely
will have to be altered in coming years.
"If you sound like you're for
a balanced budget, and sound
like you're for Social Security,
i fs a double win," says Pete Peterson, an investment executive and co-chairman of the
Concord Coalition, an anti-deficit group.
"But . . . ifs hypocritical in
the extreme to say you're for a
balanced budget amendment,
which obviously means longterm budget balancing, and
then ignore the . . . programs
that are going to drive it oil the
screen."

the federal budget. Deficit projections with and without the trust

By Marcy E. Mullins, USA TODAY
Social Security has become
the biggest program in the federal government, spending
$336 billion this year, 22% of
the entire federal budget, nearly one-fifth of the economy.
Conrad and others oppose
the GOP-sponsored amendment because they want to separate the Social Security system from budget-balancing
calculations.
They are not opposed to any
cuts in benefits. They acknowledge that adjustments will be
needed as the number of retirees grows and the number of
workers paying taxes to support benefits declines.
Instead, they say they object
to the federal government using Social Security revenues to
mask the true size of the budg-
et's imbalance, nearly $70 billion this year.
The Social Security system
now collects more in taxes
than it pays out in benefits.
That was the intention of the
1983 Social Security revision
enacted by Congress and
signed by President Reagan. It
trimmed future benefits, provided that some retirees be
taxed for the first time and
raised payroll taxes.
The idea was that surpluses
would be amassed unUl early
in the next century, when the
explosion of retirees would
start drawing down the reserves.
Instead, what's happening is
the government is spending Social Security's surplus as quickly as it flows in. The trust fund
holds government lOUs.
"They have a point, which
we've known for years," says
Norman Ornstein of the conservative American Enterprise
Institute. "This is an issue with
a substantial history."
What Conrad, his North Dakota colleague, Byron Dorgan,
and others want is an end to
the current practice.
But moving Social Security
off the page would make the
annual federal deficit even
larger than it is today and
make budget balancing almost
impassible.
Already, advocates of a balanced budget must find $1.2
trillion in spending reductions
from anticipated levels to bring
the federal budget into balance
by 2002. Taking away the So-
c
cial Security surplus would add
$600 billion to that total
Congress may not be capable of such a task. But the picture may change.
Social Security's surplus will
come to an end by about 2010,
when demands for benefits
will outstrip revenues. Even
with the lOUs called in, the
trust fund will be bust in another 20 years.
Without adjustments in Social Security, the deficit problem of the future will be in that
program, topping $1 trillion a
year by then.
Critics say a Constitution that
barred deficits but excluded a
program that far out of balance
would be meaningless.

�Gulf war sequel: Claims, counterclaims
The Pentagon denies that U.S.
forces in the Persian Gulf war were
exposed to chemical or biological
agents, but there are a growing
number of claims to the contrary.
By John Ritter
USA TODAY
The yellow ribbons are a
fading memory, but reports
that U.S. forces were exposed
to Iraqi chemical and biological agents during the gulf war
are mounting despite the Pentagon's vigorous denials.
Active duty officers and enlistees, once reticent for fear of
reprisals, are now signing a
gulf war illness registry at a
rate of 100 . a week and challenging the military's position.
And this week a top official
at the Department of Veterans
Affairs said he lacks confidence in Pentagon assertions
that troops were not exposed to
biological or chemical agents.
"Despite having heard from
the Department of Defense, I
remain concerned about what
actually happened, about exposures that either occurred or
not," said Kenneth Kizer, VA
undersecretary for health.
That's the area I feel most insecure about"
Even the White House has
signaled impatience with progress In understanding gulf illnesses. HUlary Rodham Clinton, who made two high-profile
visits with gulf vets last week
and the week before, said the
president has asked her to look
into "what we have left to do."
But former senator Donald
Riegle, whose two-year banking committee probe concluded last year that there's strong
evidence troops were exposed
to agents, says: "The problem
is so big and the implications so
serious, the professional bureaucracy at the Pentagon
can't afford to acknowledge it
"We saw this with Agent Or-
ange, where the troth can be so
calamitous to reputations and
careers and budgets that bureaucracies will go to great
lengths not to come clean."
The Senate banking committee initially got involved because it oversees legal exports
that may have military applications, such as chemical, biological and nuclear materials.
More than 50,000 gulf veterans have reported a range of
ailments that include fatigue,
muscle and joint pain, heart
and intestinal problems, memory loss, rashes and sores. They
suspect they were exposed to
chemical or biological agents
from Iraqi artillery and Scud
missile attacks, fallout from coalition bombing of Iraqi chemical and biological targets, and
exposure to munitions in Iraqi
storage facilities.
The Pentagon steadfastly
says troops were not exposed
to chemical or biological
agents. But there are many accounts to the contrary.
• An Army chemical and
biological warfare specialist
received a meritorious service
medal for "supervising the positive identification" of mustard
agent in Kuwait The Pentagon
says there were no chemical
agents in Kuwait
• Air Force battle repair
mechanics say they were ordered to decontaminate F i l l s
returning from bombing missions of Iraqi chemical weapons plants but didn't have proper protective gear. At least 14
of them are sick.
• Membeis of a 5th Special
Forces unit detached to Egyptian coalition forces twice confirmed the presence of a nerve
agent during bombing of Iraqi

�GLs ill-prepared
for the detection
of chemical arms
By John Ritter
USA TODAY
The Pentagon acknowledges
it had no reliable system to
monitor battlefield environments during the gulf war and
is scrambling to develop better
methods of protecting troops.
"We've learned we'd better
get more serious about identifying what our soldiers are
breathing" says Theodore Prociv, deputy assistant secretary
of Defense for chemical and
biological matters.
Military officials say US.
forces were ill-prepared to detect biological weapons, and an
effective Iraqi attack could
have caused many casualties.
Troops also were exposed to
pesticides, diesel fuel and
smoke from oil-well fires.
"The modern military has to
reconcile itself to people sincerely saying they've acquired
some syndrome from military
service," says Matthew Messelson, a Harvard University molecular geneticist
"There needs to be a carefully worked out format for data
collection."
The Pentagon is developing
a system for medical personnel
in every unit to take air samples several times a day or during suspicious events.
Air canisters would be labeled, dated and stored for later analysis, if needed.
Officials say better alarms
and protective suits also are being developed. And commanders are getting better training
Meanwhile, as the number
of veterans reporting gulf-illness symptoms grows, so do
calls for a fuller accounting of:
• How well chemical-detection equipment performed.
What good were chemical
weapons alarms if dust heat
smoke and low batteries triggered hundreds of false alarms
— as the Pentagon says.
"Why weren't they recalled?" Army Maj. Gus Grant
wants to know.
Grant got to King Khalid Military City near the Iraqi border
two weeks after the air war
started and was astonished at
how troops reacted to alarms.
"They were used to i t they
didn't reach for gas masks," he
says. "Eventually, we picked
up the attitude like everyone
else that it was just dust and
PROCIV: 'We d better get
more serious...'
heat"
• The possibility troops
were exposed to fallout from
bombing Iraqi targets.
Poisonous debris clouds
rose, the theory goes, then
winds carried them south.
Ex-Senate investigator
James Tuite says satellite photos show upper air moving
smoke plumes south from oilwell fires, in the opposite direction of ground winds. The same
could have happened with a
chemical plume, he says. "The
Pentagon simply won't address
high-altitude fallout"
Most experts agree with the
Pentagon that contaminants
would disperse at high altitude
and never reach troops. Biological agents, particularly, are
short-lived and perishable.
"Once you get up that high,
dilution takes over," Prociv
says. "The stuff becomes insignificant" But that theory has
never been field tested.
• The possibility troops
were exposed to doses too low
to Mil but enough to bring on
delayed symptoms.
Pentagon critics use the lowdose scenario to explain why
some troops got sick and others
didn't "Like when the flu hits
town," says Tuite.
"Some people don't get sick,
but some do — and some sooner than others."
Physician John Bailar says
the Institute of Medicine panel
he headed considered the lowdose.issue and concluded
chemical agents "would have
different kinds of lon^term
consequences than what we
were seeing in veterans. But
it's not an ironclad argument"

To aid peace, Israel must become nuclear-free
Your editorial exposes the kind of flagrant double standard you subscribe to in
the Middle East ("Do what it takes to keep
Iran from getting nukes," Our View, Debate, Friday).
You argue that Iran — a willing signatory of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty
— must not be allowed to pursue the use of
even commercial nuclear power. But you
make absolutely no mention of the one
Middle Eastern country that has repeatedly refused to sign the treaty while flagrantly violating all international norms by
building, over the years, a nuclear arsenal
with many hundreds of active warheads.
I refer, of course, to the state of Israel.
It is truly regrettable that you choose not
to be evenhanded in your "bad Muslim/
good Jew" coverage of the Middle East
Only when all countries of that region
are held to the same strict behavioral standards vis-a-vis a nuclear-free commitment
may one expect to experience reduced terrorism and, ultimately, full and honorable
peace in that part of the world.
Prof. Merwein Pondorf, Joplin, Mo.

�Social Security Looms Over Balanced Budget
Debate (Washn) By James Risen= (c) 1995, Los
Angeles Times=
WASHINGTON The bitter struggle over the balanced
budget amendment has boiled down to a debate over the
unresolved fate of Social Security, one of the toughest
and most explosive issues that Washington will face as it
edges closer to the tum of the century.
Grudgingly, Senate Republican leaders are now offering
to exempt Social Security from the requirements of the
balanced budget amendment in order to win critical
Democratic support and salvage the most visible
centerpiece of the Republican agenda.
Yet those same Republican leaders know that exempting
Social Security and thus prohibiting its huge surpluses
from being used to offset the budget deficit will make the
task of balancing the budget next to impossible. But the
GOP leaders are one vote short of victory , they need the
votes of at least one of North Dakota's two Democratic
senators, Kent Conrad and Byron Dorgan, who both want the
Social Security fund totally divorced from the rest of the
budget before they agree to vote for the amendment.
That change would protect Social Security benefits from
the fiscal pressures that are sure to build in Washington
in the coming years if the balanced budget amendment is
passed. Social Security is perhaps the most popular and
sacrosanct program in the federal government, providing
retirement, death and disability benefits to 45 million
American families. Insulating it would help avert the
potential for a political firefight every time Congress
deals with the budget.
Yet it will also keep a huge pot of money out of the
reach of lawmakers who will be scrambling to bring
spending and revenues into balance as the amendment's
deadline of 2002 approaches. Social Security is the
government's single biggest program, and slicing it out of
the budget-balancing equation would create havoc
throughout the rest of the federal establishment. The 1996
budget would be $66 billion higher if the surplus in the
Social Security trust fund was not available as an offset;
within four years, Social Security will be running annual
surpluses of close to $100 billion. Thus, Congress would
have to impose far more draconian spending cuts or face
up to steep tax increases to cover that gap.
Lawmakers would haye to find at least another $558
billion over the next seven years on top of the $1.2
trillion now estimated to be the total cost of achieving a
balanced budget by 2002.
The Social Security trust fund is accumulating an
ever-growing balance, which now stands at roughly $500
billion. That balance is expected to peak at $2 trillion
around the year 2013.
But isolating that trust fund wouldn't necessarily
protect Social Security from budgetary gimmicks. Analysts
warn that taking Social Security out from under the
balanced budget law will increase the incentive for
Congress to dump unrelated programs into Social Security
to benefit from its exemption. "1 could see how we could
expand the definition of Social Security in order to cover
lots of favored spending programs; we could end up with
welfare being counted as Social Security," argues Henry
Aaron, an analyst at the Brookings Institution in
Washington.
But while Social Security looks like a tempting source
of funds today and for the near future, ultimately it will
face an enormous budgetary crisis of its own, one that
Congress and the public have yet to confront. The
demographic bulge that is expected to be caused by the
retirement of the Baby Boomer generation after the turn of
the century will shift the fund from annual surpluses to
yearly deficits after 2012 or 2013. By 2029 the huge shift
of boomers from working status to retirement will have
exhausted the entire $2 trillion balance, the Social
Security Administration predicts. And, if no action is
taken before then, the fund will go broke.
Thus, a constitutional amendment that isolates the fund
may limit the long-term solutions that Congress can use to
address that looming crisis.
GOP to Propose Tough Work Requirements in
Food Stamp Program (Washn) By Elizabeth
Shogren= (c) 1995, Los Angeles Times=
WASHINGTON In an abrupt change of course on welfare
reform, congressional Republican leaders have decided to
subject the government's $27 billion food stamp program to
the same kind of stringent work requirements they intend
to impose on cash benefits, according to congressional
sources.
The plan, details of which will be released later in
the week, would also allow states to set time limits for
food stamp eligibility that are in accordance with their
time limits for cash welfare.
Under the overhaul, able-bodied people between 18 and
50 without dependent children would be required to work
within months of receiving food stamps.
Although food stamps would be retained as a federal
program, states would have authority to impose some of
their own rules, such as eliminating food stamps to
recipients who lose their eligibility for cash assistance
under Aid to Families with Dependent Children, according to
the new rules, which are being drafted by the House
Agriculture Committee.
The development could have far-reaching implications
for the federal program, which has been the most generous
and widely available part of the safety net in America for
decades.
Other welfare programs have been provided only to
certain people
families with dependent children, the elderly or disabled
but food stamps are available to any one who is hungry and
poor. The changes in the food stamp program that have been
agreed upon by the House leadership would put an end to
that.
The GOP welfare reform plan attached to the "Contract
With America" did not call for work restrictions on food
stamps but envisioned handing control of the program to
the states. Republican leaders decided only a few days ago
not to follow through with their original plans.
By retaining the program at the federal level, House
Republicans stressed, they would maintain one program to
smooth the transition as states were taking over much of
the rest of the safety net for the poor.
But GOP congressional aides said Wednesday that the
federal food stamp program would be changed to reflect the
same philosophies driving the reform of other welfare
programs: people should only receive public assistance if
they work and Congress should restrict the growth of
welfare programs.
The GOP food stamp initiative would prevent the costs
of the program from growing, the aides said. Predictions
show that under current law, costs for food stamps would
expand from $27 billion to $35 billion.over five years,
but congressional aides said the new measure would cut
costs from the current level.
About 40 million people use food stamps during the
course of a year, and at any one time about 25 million
people receive the benefit. Twenty percent of the
�households receiving food stamps currently have some earned
income.
(Optional add end)
Administration officials said they did not have a
response to the GOP plan to place work restrictions on
food stamps, but stressed that the measure represents a
dramatic departure from the goals of the program first set
forth by President Kennedy when he created it in 1961.
While income maintenance programs have had combined
goals of supporting poor families and helping them get on
their feet again, the only goal of food stamps has been to
make sure people do not go hungry.
"You measure success of nutrition programs by whether
they prevent hunger. It's a different goal," said Neil
Flieger, deputy administrator of the Agriculture ,
Department agency that runs the food stamp program. "The
president's (welfare reform) proposal recognized that
nutrition programs were the ultimate safety net. Nutrition
programs were not part of the package that was subject to
a two-year time limit."
Clinton Spares Colombia From U.S. Sanctions
(Washn) By Norman Kempstei- (c) 1995, Los
Angeles Times=
WASHINGTON President Clinton spared Colombia from
U.S. sanctions against governments implicated in the narcotics
trade Wednesday despite what officials called "pervasive
corruption" of the South American nation's political and
judicial systems by the cocaine cartels.
In his annual report to Congress, Clinton said
Colombia's anti-drug effort fell far short of what is
required but he waived the economic penalties set by U.S.
law because he concluded that it was in the U.S. national
interest to continue normal dealings with the country
including flawed but better-than-nothing cooperation
against drug traffickers.
Overall, Clinton certified that the governments in 18
of the world's 29 narcotics producing or transit countries
have "cooperated fully" with international
anti-narcotics efforts. At the other end of the scale, he
imposed sanctions on five countries, denying them U.S.
foreign aid and export-import bank credits and requiring
Washington to veto loans to them from the World Bank and
other international lending institutions.
In a middle group were six countries in which
anti-narcotics efforts were found to be inadequate but
were the administration decided to withhold penalties. In
addition to Colombia, the waivers were granted to Bolivia,
Lebanon, Pakistan, Paraguay and Peru.
Most U.S. aid to Colombia and to the coca-producing
countries of Bolivia and Peru is in the form of assistance
to anti-narcotics programs. So i f the administration
imposed the sanctions specified by U.S. law, the result
would be to further damage already crippled law
enforcement, programs.
Sanctions were ordered for Afghanistan, Burma, Iran,
Nigeria and Syria. Of those five, Iran and Syria are also
on the State Department's list of countries that support
international terrorism, which imposes the same sanctions
required by the drug law.
Robert Gelbard, assistant secretary of state for
narcotics and law enforcement, was unstinting in his
criticism of Colombia although he said the United States
cannot simply walk away from the pivotal country in the
administration's Western Hemisphere narcotics-control
strategy. In addition to dominating 80 percent of the
cocaine market, traffickers in Colombia also control about
12 percent of the heroin smuggled into the United States.
On Capitol Hill, Republican members of the Senate
Foreign Relations Committee called on Clinton to impose
sanctions on Colombia. Gelbard said the president
determined that such a step would be counterproductive.
(Optional add end)
"We are seriously concerned that there have been no
major drug prosecutions in Colombia," Gelbard said. Even
when drug figures are prosecuted, he added, the courts let
them off with '' slap on the wrist" penalties. Moreover,
he said Colombia has no adequate law against money
laundering and does not take adequate steps.to seize the
assets of drug traffickers.
"We are hopeful that in 1995 we will see better
performance by Colombia," he said.
At the same time, Gelbard said the U.S. government is
"aware" of reports that Colombian President Ernesto
Samper has close links to the Cali cocaine cartel. He said
Samper recently apologized to the cartel because police
interrupted the birthday party of a cocaine figure, an
incident that he said provoked "our very great concern."
"We have been fundamentally concerned about the ...
pervasive corruption throughout political institutions at
all levels" in Colombia, Gelbard said.
He said U.S. officials have discussed the issue with
senior members of the Samper government in recent weeks
and "there can be no doubt in their mind about our
expectations."
High Quality of -Bases Complicates Choice of
Closures (Washn) By Richard A. Serrano= (c)
1995, Los Angeles Times=
WASHINGTON Decisions this year over which military
installations to save or scuttle " w i l l be all the more
difficult" because only the best facilities are left
after three earlier, grueling rounds of closings, the
chairman of a special base-closing commission said
Wednesday.
Alan J. Dixon, head of the independent Defense Base
Closure and Realignment Commission, said that the
Pentagon's recommendations would close fewer bases this
year but larger ones than in the past, providing more
budget savings.
While previous closings have provided long-term savings
of less than $16 billion, officials hope that the new
round will trim as much as $18.5 billion from the defense
budget.
The Pentagon is recommending that 33 major military
bases close their gates this year in the fourth and final
series of base closings under the current law. In
addition, the Pentagon wants to shut down or curtail
operations at another 113 installations.
In all, about 34,200 civilian jobs are on the line. And
local officials around the nation are gearing up to try to
convince Dixon and his panel that their communities should
be spared.
But at the commission's first hearing in Washington,
Dixon and top Pentagon leaders said that the most painful
closings must come this year.
"What you might call the easy decisions have all been
made," Dixon said. "We are down to, for the most part,
excellent bases, many with a long and distinguished
history of support for our armed forces. Our decisions
this year will be all the more difficult for that
�reason.
(Optional add end)
Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, chairman of the Joint
Chiefs of Staff, said the armed services will be about 34
percent smaller over the decade stretching from the end of
the Cold War to the end of this century. He said that the
military budget will fall by about 40 percent.
Even so, "after three rounds of base closures and
realignments, our infrastructure is only projected to be
15 percent smaller."
Under the law, the commission now begins the process of
deciding whether to spare any of the installations or
leave the list intact. Next week, each of the service
chiefs are scheduled to justify for the panel why they
targeted the installations under their domain and
commission members then plan to visit many of the sites
and hear arguments from local officials on why individual
bases should be spared.
The SEC has been criticized for not taking action after
that meeting. SEC officials have replied that it yielded no
indication of fraud and that the commission has limited
authority over local governments. Hearings about that
meeting might be a good idea, one SEC official said. But
it "was just unbelievable," he sputtered, that Cox would
choose that time and place for the announcement.

CLINTON VS. GORE: Just suppose Vice President Al Gore
wakes up one morning, decides his boss is a dead duck and
decides to challenge him in the 1996 primaries. Would
Democrats buy it? No way, says a new national survey from
Ed Sarpolus, a Democratic pollster. By 63 percent to 27
percent, Democrats say they would stick with President
Clinton. What of California Gov. Pete Wilson's chances?
The survey says just 7 percent of Republicans backed
Wilson as the party's nominee, compared to 19 percent for
Texas Sen. Phil Gramm and 5.4 percent for Senate Majority
Leader Bob Dole of Kansas.

WASHINGTON INSIGHT: FBI vs. Business
Spies By Drex Heikes and Ronald J . Ostrow= (c)
1995, Los Angeles Times=
WASHINGTON With worries mounting over foreign
spying against U.S. business, the FBI is pushing for a law to
clarify its legal authority in that realm. The bureau now
pursues thieves of business secrets through laws barring
wire and mail fraud and interstate transportation of stolen
property. To erase doubts about FBI jurisdiction, many
prefer a federal statute outlawing theft of intellectual
property the object of most economic espionage.
Businesses are expected to welcome the idea, but some may
have doubts. That's because the law wouldn't just curb
espionage by foreign interests. It could apply to any
American company whose spying benefits its foreign
operations.
-0-=
COOKIE MONSTER: What drives peripatetic House
Speaker
Newt Gingrich? The Georgia Republican provided some
insight during his college course. "People who are truly
successful have some internal technique of maximizing the
good luck and minimizing the bad luck," Gingrich said in a
lecture. "1 was dramatically shaped by my grandmother and

it can be baked or it's already been bought, but it's in a
jar ... somewhere. ... And so that means when you open up
the cupboard and the cookie isn't there, I don ! say,
'Gee, there's no cookie.' I say, ' I wonder where it is.'

U.S. Aid Program for Mexico Endangered
(Washn) By Robert A. RosenbIatt= (c) 1995, Los
Angeles Times=
WASHINGTON The $20 billion U.S. financial aid program
for Mexico became endangered Wednesday when the House
voted overwhelmingly to demand Clinton"administration
docutnents about the arrangement.
The leaders of both parties reluctantly agreed to the
vote in hopes it would head off a further protest by
rank-and-file members angered by the administration's
decision to sidestep Congress and provide loan guarantees
from a fund under the president's control.
"We have had to fight a war in this chamber to even
get a vote," said Rep. Marcy Kaptur, D-Ohio. The
resolution of inquiry was approved by a lopsided margin of
407-21. "Let me remind my colleagues this is a first
vote," said Kaptur, one of the leaders of the forces who
hope to scuttle the aid package.
Intensifying the debate, a House subcommittee chairman.
promised an investigation of a potential conflict of
interest by Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, the author of
the bailout plan and the man who will disburse the funds
to Mexico. Rubin was the former chairman of brokerage giant
Goldman, Sachs & Co., which marketed more than $5 billion
in Mexican securities between 1992 and 1994.
Rubin should have avoided any involvement because "you
can't forget who you are or where you came from," Rep.
Spencer Bachus, R-Ala., chairman of the oversight
subcommittee of the House Banking Committee, said
Wednesday. He promised a hearing by the end of the month.
(Begin optional trim)
In Mexico City, the Mexican Stock Exchange's key index
fell 31.88 points to 1,517.96 Wednesday, even though
interest rates on Mexican treasury bills auctioned
�Wednesday came down somewhat from last week's
stratospheric
levels.
Still, rates are around 50 percent, reflecting the
crisis of confidence in the Mexican economy and the
government. The general disarray was heightened by
Tuesday's arrest of the brother of former President Carlos
Salinas on charges that he ordered and planned the
assassination of a key ruling party official last year.
(End optional trim)
Bachus and other Republicans are defying their party's
leadership, which agreed with President Clinton on the
need for the aid package to help Mexico whose economy
cracked in late December under the weight of a severe
trade deficit and a sudden devaluation of the peso!
The administration argued that fears over Mexico could
jeopardize the ability of many other fast-developing
nations to raise capital.
The GOP dissidents will force a vote at Thursday's
Republican conference on their demand that their party
bring the issue to a vote on the House floor. They want a
vote on a bill that would block the administration from
providing funds without prior Congressional approval.
If the critics are successful at the Republican
conference, the full House will get a chance to express
itself on the idea of financial aid for Mexico. Many
members, upset at the political difficulty of cutting
popular domestic programs, will be reluctant to cast a.
vote for what would be perceived as unpopular foreign aid.
(Optional add end)
Rubin, who is in charge of the loan guarantee program,
was defended vigorously on Wednesday as a man of integrity
by Leach and several Democratic members. They were angered
by criticisms from Bachus and other Republicans about the
potential conflict of interest or appearance of a
conflict.
Rubin left Goldman Sachs, where he had served as
co-chairman, to join the Clinton administration, and
placed his assets in a blind trust.
Goldman Sachs was the lead underwriter for Mexican
securities, arranging the sale of $5.7 billion worth of
issues between 1992 and 1994. Goldman Sachs' own holdings
of Mexican securities currently are less than $100
million, small compared with the firm's assets of $130
billion, according to knowledgeable sources.
Treasury ethics officials gave Rubin a ruling that it
would be permissible for him to become involved in the
Mexican issue.

By Paul Bedard
THE WASHINGTON :iMES
President Clinton last night
railed against Republican "new
isolationism" in foreign affairs,
while top GOP congressional leaders all endorsed his call for U.S.
involvement overseas.
"If we are to be strong at home
and lead abroad, we must overcome a dangerous and growing
temptation in our land to focus
solely on the problems we face
here in America," Mr. Clinton told
a conference held at the Mayflower Hotel by the Nixon Center
for Peace and Freedom.
Aides said the president was attacking Republicans in general in
his speech. Mr. Clinton mentioned
no one by name, although Senate
Majority Leader Bob Dole earlier
had criticized Mr. Clinton's foreign
policies as timid.
"The new isolationists are
wrong," said the president. "They
would have us face the future
alone. Their approach would
weaken America. We must not let
the ripple of isolationism they
have generated build into a tidal
wave. If we withdraw from the
world today, we will have to contend with consequences of our neglect tomorrow."
The president, who proudly
touts his success in Haiti, Russia
and on nuclear-arms accords, provided a long list of achievements
and then said many weighty
chores lie ahead.
"In this year of decision, our
agenda is even more ambitious. If
our people are to know real, lasting
security, we must redouble our
arms-control, nonproliferation
and anti-terrorism efforts. We
must do everything we can to avoid
living with the 21st-century version of fallout shelters and 'duck
and cover' exercises to prevent another World H-ade [Center] tragedy," said Mr. Clinton.

�North Dakota's
Conrad, Dorgan
appear as clones
Careers linked in state backing bill
By Seari Piccoli
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
For those who may be confused,
North Dakota has two Democratic
senators. It's just that, sometimes,
they can look like one.
Kent Conrad and Byron L. Dorgan — born in North Dakota and
schooled in the prairie populist
style that both mastered in intertwining careers — have staked out
similar positions on the balancedbudget amendment, whose fate
now rests in their hands.
The amendment is one vote shy
of Senate passage, with both North
Dakotans holding out. A nod from
either will do.
None of these parallels surprise
folks back home, who describe the
pair as friends and fellow populists who sometimes function like
political bookends for their closeknit, rural state.
"In some ways contrasting is
difficult," said Ronald Pynn, a political science professor at the
University of North Dakota in
Grand Forks. "They're very similar. In fact, Kent Conrad is really
a protege of Byron Dorgan."
And vice versa.
"They are each other's proteges," said Rep. Bill Oban, leader of
the state legislature's Democratic
House minority.
Indeed, the two have nurtured a
sort of reciprocal rise to power.
When Mr Dorgan made an unsuccessful bid for Congress in 1974,
Mr. Conrad managed the campaign. Mr. Dorgan, 52, was elected
state tax commissioner in 1968
and served until 1980. Mr. Conrad,
46, was his top assistant for six of
those years.
When Mr Dorgan graduated to
the U.S. House in 1980, Mr. Conrad
stepped into the tax commissioner's job.
Mr. Conrad beat his former boss
to the Senate by challenging an incumbent in 1986. Mr. Dorgan followed in 1992.
"Kent and Byron are very close
friends," said Rep. Earl Pomeroy,
North Dakota Democrat and the
third member of the state's congressional delegation. "And I think
each's success reflects how comfortable North Dakotans are with
both."
But Mr. Pomeroy said the two
are not interchangeable.
"They make their decisions on
an independent basis," he said.
"They have never run as each other's clone. I mean, Conrad is Conrad and Dorgan is Dorgan."
Colleagues describe both as
thoughtful, intelligent, articulate
and equally willing to break ranks
with the party, a posttfre that plays
well in North Dakota, a border
state with a population of 634,935,
fourth-smallest in the nation.
"We are fiscally conservative,
so the balanced-budget amendment would have a lot of support,"
Mr. Pynn said. "But we also have a
long streak of prairie populism. So.
mavericks are not only tolerated,
they're celebrated."
"They're very much populists,"
agreed Mr. Oban. "They very
much understand people. . . . And
they're very consistent. It would
be easy for them to take the politically easy way out and vote for this
[balanced-budget amendment] because polls show people want this."
Both have resisted that choice
"despite incredible pressure," Mr.
Oban said.
The two have been known to disagree. Mr. Conrad voted for the
General Agreement on Tariffs and
TVade. Mr. Byron voted against it.
The two also show differences in
political style.
"Dorgan is a consummate campaigner," Mr. Pynn said. "He
comes back to the state frequently,
has town hall meetings, rolls up his
shirt sleeves and talks to farmers,
goes out to the small town cafes."
Mr. Conrad, he said, "does not
have the same outgoing personal

"It would be easy for them to take the
politically easy way out and vote for this
because polls show people want this"
style."
But it was Mr. Conrad who
promised in 1986 that he would not
seek re-election if he could not
pass a balanced budget. He announced his retirement in 1992,
but when Sen. Quentin N. Burdick

JO attack
food-stamp
abuses
/99S
By Marc LaFountain
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
Agriculture Department officials proposed legislation yesterday to combat fraud and abuse of
the $27 billion federal food-stamp
program.
If passed, the legislation would
give the USDA increased powers
to screen, monitor and penalize retail stores involved in the program.
The agency is targeting stores that
traffic in food stamps, redeeming
the stamps for nonfood items such
as cash, alcohol and tobacco.
"Those profiting by this crime
steal more than money and undermine public trust," said Ellen
Haas, USDA undersecretary for
food, nutrition and consumer services. "They steal food out of the
mouths of needy children and
families."
The USDA does not have an official estimate of how much money
is lost each year to food stamp
fraud, although $1 billion a year is
an often quoted figure. The
agency estimates another $i.8 billion is lost each year from the overpayment of benefits.
Spokesman Neal Flieger said
the USDA has already been working to solve the overpayment problem. He said fraud and abuse is a
more difficult problem to deal
with.
"It's a covert activity," he said.
"What happens between when a
person gets stamps and when the ,
stamps are cashed in to us by the
stores is something we can't know."
One of the ways the USDA
would try to monitor what happens
to food stamps is by the use of the
Electronic Benefit Transfer system. Under EBT, cpnsumers are
issued "Electronic Security
Cards," which allow them to use
food stamp money much like a
banking card.
The procedure leaves an electronic trail for the USDA to follow
in search of traffickers. The USDA
wants tp use that data to take action against.traffickers.
EBT is in development in 41
states and is already being used
statewide in Maryland.
The USDA wants to couple increased monitoring with .stiffer
penalities for abuse of food
stamps. The proposed legislation
would allow the USDA to seize
property used in or gotten from
food stamp violations of $5,000 or
more.
Food stamp reform appears to
have a good chance of passing on
Capitol Hill.
"We will possibly add it to the
markup of our welfare reform
bill," said a House Agriculture
Comminee staff member.
The food-stamp program was
-eated under the Food Stamp
an to aid families during the Deession in the 1930s. It expanded
pidly in 1974, after Congress
andated that all states must proie food stamps to low-income
useholds.

By Bill Gertz
:HE WASHINGTON TIMES
1
A fight over how easy it should
be for white families to adopt black
children is expected to erupt in the
House Ways and Means Committee as early as today.
The Republican welfare reform
bill before the committee makes it
illegal for agencies that receive
federal money to discriminate
based on race when placing children.
The idea, conceived by Rep. Jim
Running, Kentucky Republican
and committee member, is to return to the 1964 Civil Rights Act,
which bars discrimination based
on race, and to reduce the time
black children spend in foster
care.
"The current policy puts a preference on race consciousness to
the detriment of the child being
adopted — especially black kids,"
Mr. Bunning said. "Our proposal
puts a priority on placing kids in
foster care instead of satisfying
the social engineers who know
what the child needs."
About 40,000 of the 100,000 children awaiting adoption are black.
Black children wait twice as long
as white children to be placed in
homes.
Mr. Bunning said that because
40 percent of the children in foster
care but only 12 percent of Americans are black, minority children
languish in foster homes. The
older they get, the harder it is to
place them,
The National Association of
Black Social Workers opposes
white families' adopting black
children and once said interracial
adoption is "tantamount to genocide."
The group says it is best for
blacks to be reared by blacks —
even if it means waiting longer to
be adopted.
"To deny African-Americans
the right to live and experience
their culture is not to understand
the severe issues of separation and
loss suffered by adoptees," said
Leora Neal, executive director of
the New York chapter of the association.
Cassie Statute Bevan, vice president of the National Council for
Adoption, said she expects a com-
mittee fight.
"Democrats are going to say,
'First you are taking our money,
and now you are taking our kids,' "
she said yesterday during a break
in the markup of the welfare proposal. "But what makes for the
health of black kids is not responding only to the blackness of
the kid."
Rep. Charles B. Rangel, New
York Democrat, said the language
under consideration is too broad.
"It tends to remove all authority
from the agency for being able to
hold back adoption based on race,"
he said. "It takes away the discretion of the social worker."
But Rep. Harold E. Ford of Tennessee said he hopes to rally fellow
Democrats around the proposal.
" I will lead the fight on the
Democrat side tomorrow," he said
yesterday, adding that he is unsure
how much opposition to expect.
State law governs adoption and
foster care placement. Forty-three
states require race matching in
regulation, statute, policy or practice.
Last year. Sen. Howard M.
Metzenbaum, Ohio Democrat,
wrote and shepherded a bill
through Congress that sought to
make it easier for black children
to be adopted by white families.
But the Department of Health and
Human Services modified the bill
so that in practice it has had the
opposite effect.
Yesterday, from his home in
Pompano Beach, Fla., the former
senator said he supports the repeal of his bill.
"It was always my intent and
policy to be supportive of whites
who wanted to adopt black children," he said, adding that he feels
more strongly about transracial
adoption than any issue he worked
on during his Senate career.
"This actually strengthens my,
bill," he said, adding that in modifying the bill, HHS neutered it.
"There were those over at HHS
who were doing violence to the intent of the law."
Mr. Bunning said he has a
daughter who adopted a biracial
child but "because of the Metzenbaum language was not able to
take that child home when it was
bom, because they were looking
for a black family."

GOP's King wants
federal workers'
charity list purged
Says advocacy groups are subsidized
By Kristin E. Hussey
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
A Republican congressman
wants to eliminate advocacy
groups from a taxpayer-supported
program that collects and dispenses federal workers' charitable
donations.
In a letter to James B. King, director of the Office of Personnel
Management (OPM), Rep. John L.
Mica of Florida asked that groups
not directly benefiting human
health and welfare be excluded
from the Combined Federal Campaign (CFC), the umbrella program that acts as distributor for
donations and provides the list of
recipients.
"The federal government can't
become a collection agency for advocacy groups, whether they are
of the left or the right," Mr. Mica,
a member of the House Government Reform and Oversight civil
service subcommittee, said in a
separate statement. "It is a travesty to require taxpayers to subsidize the fund-raising efforts of political and ideological advocacy
groups."
The CFC was developed in 1961
by President Kennedy to protect
federal employees from solicitations in the workplace.
And an OPM official who requested anonymity noted, "When
[the CFC] was initially developed,
it did say in the regulations that
the organizations where contributions would go were ones that directly provided human health and
welfare programs."
In 1993, the latest year for which
such figures are available, the
CFC collected nearly $200 million
to be distributed among more than
1,000 charities nationwide.
A report issued in 1988 by a task
force on the CFC acknowledged
that the program is "a subsidy for
participating organizations," Mr.
Mica's statement said. The subsidy was estimated to be "in the
neighborhood of $55-$60 million"
per year.
"American taxpayers simply
should not be compelled to subsidize these advocacy groups," Mr.
Mica said.
During the 1980s, President
Reagan tried to restrict participation in the CFC to traditional charities. A group of nonprofit agencies whose work affects health and
human welfare sued.
The Supreme Court ruled even-

can't become a
collection agency for
advocacy groups."

"has exploded," Mr. Mica said. "In

CFC are the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, the Firearms Civil
Rights Legal Defense Fund and
the conservative Heritage Foundation.
"The CFC fund-raising is about
giving federal employees a choice.
They don't have to contribute to
any particular group," said Earl
Blauner, an attorney for the Sierra
Club Legal Defense Fund. "Since
1983, a substantial number of employees have supported the Legal
Defense Fund."
The Center for Investigative Reporting, a nonprofit organization,
&lso was mentioned in Mr. Mica's
letter as one that should be excluded from the CFC. The center
has received $1,700 from the CFC
in the past 18 months, said Executive Director Dan Noyes.
"We consider ourselves a combination of a journalism education
program and a nonprofit independent source of journalism," Mr.
Noyes said. "A lot of people, particularly on the right, consider
what we do advocacy."
The head of the Office of Personnel Management yesterday reassured members of the President's management council that
phasing out OPM's investigations
, office would not hurt their depart: ments' security operations.
At the closed-door meeting,
James B. King outlined the implications of his plan to privatize
much of OPM's Office of Federal
Investigations by the end of the
year. The management council is
composed of senior Cabinet department officials designated as
' chief operating officers.
Most federal agencies depend
on OPM to conduct background investigations, used for screening
prospective employees and validating security clearances.
Under Mr. King's proposal,
OPM would continue to issue policy guidance on investigations and
would retain control of the central
records repository on all employees. But agencies would take responsibility for conducting background investigations, using
either their own staff or contracting with private firms.
Security officials at some departments have raised concerns
; that eliminating the centralized investigations branch would , force
jevery agency to set up its own staff
iof investigators. Others fear that
using private investigators could
have serious national security repercussions.
In a Feb. 24 letter to OPM officials, the director of security for
the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) wrote:
"FEMA has had experience in the
past with contracting some of its
investigations to private firms,
and can emphatically state that it
was neither cost-effective nor efficient
From a national security
perspective, privatization of this
function would surely weaken the
country's susceptibility to security risks."
Officials at private security
firms dispute such fears, saying
they perform accurate and reliable investigations at half the
price of OPM's services. One company noted that its investigators
are required to have at least five
years of prior federal experience,
unlike OPM, which uses investigators right out of college with as
little as two weeks of training.
OPM will ask a private consultant to study the feasibility of an
employee stock ownership plan, or
ESOR Under that option, OPM
would help its employees set up a
private company to conduct investigations. The feasibility study,
due out in mid-April, will include
a business plan for the private
company, along with a survey of
OPM investigators to assess the
level of interest in such a venture.
The agency touts this proposal
as a way to provide uninterrupted
service to the agencies it currently serves. "OPM investigative
staff would be positioned to make
the transition from federal to a
privatized entity in a manner that
would be seamless to our customers — no service interruption."
" I f the ESOP is not possible, we
will have an out-of-business situation by the end of the year," the
meeting notes said. If formation of
a private company is found to be
feasible, however, OPM will develop legislation necessary to implement the plan.
An OPM spokesperson confirmed that investigations director
Patricia Lattimore met with
agency security officials last week
to discuss their concerns.
"She assured them that the records repository and the central
data base are not going away,
which was one of their biggest
concerns."
Notes from last week's meeting,
obtained by The Washington
Times, indicate that the Office of
Management and Budget estimates that privatizing investigations will save an estimated $30
million.

Pena's role in deal
with LA. subway
probed by Justice
By Michael Hedges
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
TVansportation Secretary Federico Pena is the subject of a Justice Department review into how a
company he once headed, Pena Investment Advisers, won a contract
to manage $5 million in the Los
Angeles transit system pension
fund.
The contract was awarded to
Mr. Pena's former company in
1993,19 days after he became head
of the TVansportation Department,
which contributes to the building
of a multibillion-dollar subway
system in Los Angeles.
Rep. John J. "Jimmy" Duncan
Jr., Tennesse Republican and
chairman of the House TVansportation and Infrastructure aviation
subcommittee, said that during
hearings he may question Mr.
Pena about that contract as well as
others to his former company by
companies tied to the Denver International Airport.
" I have no way of knowing if Mr.
Pena did anything wrong, but
there is at least the appearance of
impropriety," Mr. Duncan said. "It
doesn't appear to me that this company would have gotten this contract unless it was close to Mr.
Pena."
Mr. Duncan said Mr. Pena called
him last week about the contract.
"He said he would be glad to come
in and show me his records and
explain the whole thing," the congressman said. No meeting has yet
occurred on the matter, he said.
Mr. Pena is the fourth member
of the Clinton Cabinet to be investigated by the Justice Department.
• Independent counsel Donald
Smaltz is probing accusations that
Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy
took improper trips and other inducements from Arkansas poutry
giant Tyson Foods Inc. Mr. Espy
resigned at the end of the year.
• Last week, Attorney General
Janet Reno said she found specific, credible evidence against
Commerce Secretary Ron Brown
and ordered a preliminary investigation into whether to appoint an
independent counsel.
• The Justice Department in
January asked for more time to
decide whether to seek the appointment of an independent
counsel to investigate charges that
Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development Henry Cisneros lied
to FBI agents and sought to hide
the amount of payments he made
to a former mistress.
The Denver-based Pena Investment Advisers, which was started
by Mr. Pena in the early 1990s, won
a contract to manage $5 million in
the Los Angeles transit system
pension fund in 1993.
-' In January, Mr. Pena approved
$187 million in additional federal
funds for the Los Angeles Metro
H-ansit Authority system, which
has become one of the most costly
federal projects in history. Since
he took office Mr. Pena has committed $1.7 billion in federal
money to the project.
In a statement released yesterday, Mr. Pena noted that he had
reported on federal financialdisclosure forms in January 1993
that he sold his interest in the company at a loss.
"Before taking office, I completely severed all ties with my old
investment firm, selling my interest in the company at a financial
loss and recusing myself from any
business the firm had at that time,"
he said. " I have taken every
appropriate measure within my
control to avoid potential conflicts
of interest."
Mr. Pena's spokesman, Richard
Mintz, downplayed the Justice Department's decision to review the
contract. "Any allegation Justice
Secretary Federico Pena's old
firm won a S5 million contract.
receives they are obligated to pursue, including barking dogs," he
said. "We can find no allegations of
illegal or unethical conduct."
Mr. Duncan said his aviation
subcommittee also is in the process of hiring former FBI investigators to examine suspicions of
wrongdoing stemming from the
huge cost overruns involved in
building Denver's new airport.
Among the matters the subcommittee may review is how Pena Investment Advisers was given $10
million to manage by USWest, a
Denver-based telecommunications company. USWest contributed $200,000 to Mr. Pena's successful campaigns for mayor of
Denver. It later won a $24 million
contract to put phones in the airport.
"Some of the things that went on
with the Denver Airport may be
more closely tied to Mr. Pena [than
the Los Angeles deal]," Mr. Duncan said.
Justice Department officials
said a 30-day preliminary inquiry
began in February into the deal
between the Los Angeles transit
and Pena Investment Advisers
after an article on the contract appeared in the Los Angeles Times.
If it finds specific, credible evidence that Mr. Pena may have violated federal law, the Justice Department then would conduct an
investigation lasting up to 90 days
to decide whether the charges
warranted appointment of an independent counsel.

SOMEONE TO WATCH OVER D . C ?
Examples of oversight boards in other large cities that have run
Into fiscal trouble:
Chicago School Finance Authority
Established: 1980. Still operating.
Members: Five-member board of directors, two appointed by the
governor, two by the mayor and a jointly appointed chairman. They are
not paid but have expenses reimbursed.
Enforcement: Extremely broad. Can approve the school board's
budget and staffing plan, has the power to assume administrative
control of the school system.
Cleveland Financial Planning and Supervision Commission
Established: 1980. Still operating.
Members: The Ohio treasurer, budget director, mayor, City Council
chairman and three members appointed by the governor and approved
by the state Senate. They are not paid.
Enforcement: Approves the city budget, aids in establishing an
accounting system and approves new debt, among other powers.
New York State Financial Control Board
Established: 1975. Still operating.
Members: Governor and comptroller, mayor and city comptroller, three
members appointed by the governor and approved by the state Senate.
They are not paid.
Enforcement: Approves all New York City borrowing and spending,
creates a financial plan and administers a wage freeze, among other
powers.
Pennsylvania Intergovernmental Cooperation Authority
Established: 1991. Still operating.
Members: Governor, state Senate president and minority leader,
House speaker and minority leader each appoint a member. State
budget secretary and Philadelphia finance director serve but cannot
vote. Members should live or work in Philadelphia.
Enforcement: Approves five-year city spending plan, can impose a tax
until bonds are retired, can withhold state grant money if city is not in
compliance with the approved financial plan.

The Washington Times
Decades of oversight possible for D.C.
Other cities have remained under scrutiny until bonds are fully paid
By Lorraine Woellert
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
Other big cities in financial
trouble have found themselves
subject to years — sometimes decades — of outside oversight of
their budgets, according to a study
to be presented to a congressional
subcommittee today.
D.C. officials have said they
hope that any congressionally appointed oversight board set up to
grapple with the city's estimated
$722 million deficit be temporary
and short-term. But history has
shown that is rarely the case, says
a Feb. 10 memo from the Congressional Research Service (CRS).
That report, to be presented today to the House Government Reform and Oversight subcommittee
on the District, examines the
boards that stepped in when other
large cities like New York, Philadelphia and Chicago neared insolvency.
Boards in those cities are expected to serve as models for lawmakers drawing up a similar oversight panel for the District.
"New York and Philadelphia
will be very instructive to us," said
Rep. James Walsh, chairman of
"New York and Philadelphia will be very
instructive to us. They looked for the same
financial and operating qualities we are."
— Rep. James Walsh, subcommittee
the House Appropriations subcommittee on the District.
"They looked for the same f i nancial and operating qualities we
are. They may be some of the best
examples of the interplay we
would look for between the council, the state and the board," said
Mr. Walsh, New York Repubiican.
He said he would like to see such
a board remain in control for five
years. That would be on the short
end of oversight boards studied by
CRS: New York City's Municipal
Assistance Corp. was set up in
1975 and is still operating, for example.
D C. Delegate Eleanor Holmes
Norton called for an oversight
board two weeks ago, after the
city's bond rating was downgraded to junk by two rating
chairman
houses. She said then that the
board should only be around until
the city was back on solid financial
footing.
But most statutes establishing
such boards require them to retain
some authority until all bonds,
notes or other loans involved in a
bailout are fully paid.
New York's Municipal Assistance Corp., for example, was set
up in 1975 to sell bonds and collect
revenues when the city dug itself
into an $8 billion deficit and its
borrowing needs swamped bond
markets. TNventy years later, MAC
is still in business and is considered a permanent agency, in existence for as long as the city has
outstanding bond debt.
When it became clear that MAC
was not enough to solve the city's
fiscal crisis, state officials also set
up the Emergency Financial Control Board to draw up a long-term
financial plan and balance the
city's budget by 1978. The boardaccomplished those tasks but is
still business and will be as long as
the city has outstanding bonds issued under the Municipal Assistance Corp.; or at least until July2008.
Such multiyear boards appear
to be the norm, not the exception "
Chicago's School Finance A u "
thority was set up in 1980, for example, is still in existence.
Cleveland's Financial Planning
and Supervision Commission was
also created in 1980 after the city '
defaulted on $15.5 million in short- '
term notes. The city balanced its
budget in 13 months, but the com- •
mission will be active until the
Ohio auditor deems the city has
met a number of conditions.
Pennsylvania's legislature ere- ;
ated an oversight group in 1991, ,
when Philadelphia began a fourth .
year of deficit spending. Tbday, the
Pennsylvania Intergovernmental .
Cooperation Authority continues '
to review city budgets and borrow
money for the city.

By Rod Dreher
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
Fighting for the life of her
agency. National Endowment for

grants.

House Speaker Newt Gingrich
said yesterday he would postpone
action on a compromise term, limits bill until after the 100-day
deadline for the "Contract With
America."
With none of the proposed constitutional amendments likely to
attract the necessary 290 votes in
the House, term limits now
seems almost certain to become
the first full Contract plank to be
defeated in the House — a prospect that leaves backers outside
Congress seething in anger.
"You'll see the amendments
brought up during the Contract
period." Mr. Gingrich said at his
daily news conference, "but we'll
reserve the right to bring up" a
compromise statute allowing
states to set their own limits after
the Supreme Court rules on the
validity of state-imposed limits,
probably this spring.
"Let the courts decide? That's
what Tom Foley said," objected
Paul Jacob, head of U.S. Term
Limits Inc., a grass-roots organization that played a key role in
the historic defeat of the former
Democratic speaker last November.
Reps. Nathan Deal, Georgia
Democrat, and Mark Sanford,
South Carolina Republican, yesterday proposed giving states the
power to determine how long
their legislators will be in Congress.
As ordinary legislation, their
bill would require only a simple
majority to pass; a constitutional
amendment needs approval of
two-thirds of both chambers,
then must be approved by the
legislatures of three-fourths of
the states.

With Medicare already a prime
target for budget cuts, Congress
was presented with evidence yesterday that hospitals are turning
a profit on Medicare patients for
the first time since the 1980s.
The Prospective Payment
Assessment Commission, a congressional advisory board, recommended that lawmakers allow
Medicare payment rates to go
up by just 2.1 percent in fiscal
1996.
It also urged a 13 percent cut
in the extra subsidies Medicare
pays teaching hospitals to train
interns and residents.
Dr. Donald A. Young, the commission's executive director, said
that "for the first time since 1989,
hospitals are making money on
Medicare."

War II generation of leaders.

has said he is healthy and his age

every generation, particularly the
World War II generation," Mr.
Alexander said in Waterloo, Iowa.

and my assessment is that most
Republican voters by the time we

THURSDAY, MARCH 2, 1995
By James Morrison
Bosnia's struggle
The Bosnian ambassador yesterday marked the third anniversary of his war-torn country, declaring that the Balkan nation
will continue to fight for its freedom with or without Western support.
" I can only say that our struggle for survival will continue until the day when we may once
again walk our streets in safety,
knowing that decisive justice has
been achieved," Sven Alkalaj said.
He noted that Bosnia observes
its independence "during a fragile four-month cease-fire" and under a Western arms embargo
that has deprived it of heavy
weapons for its war against Serbian rebels.
"We welcome this anniversary
with pride because we have succeeded to not only militarily organize ourselves and improve our
defensive capabilities, but have
also maintained the
multinational, multiethnic and
multireligious character of our
state while safeguarding the human rights of all of our citizens,"
he said.
Straight talk
Venezuela's new ambassador is
a change from diplomats who
talk a lot and say little.
Addressing a tough audience
of foreign affairs specialists, Ambassador Pedro Luis Echeverria
recently delivered a sobering account of his country's struggle to
repair its economy.
Mr. Echeverria, who became
Caracas' envoy to Washington in
July, addressed the failures of
previous Venezuelan politicians
who reversed free-market reforms, and he explained how the
current government hopes to correct those mistakes.
"Very difficult events have unfolded in the last decade," Mr.
Echeverria told the Americas Society in New York City.
Most recenty, he said, the
gross domestic product dropped
3.3 percent last year, which "indicates that the economic recession that began in 1993 deepened
in 1994."
He said the economy also suffered from a banking crisis and a
"massive capital outflow" in the
first six months of last year. The
1994 inflation rate was estimated
at 40 percent.
"The government is aware that
inflation is the driving force of
social and economic difficulties
and that fiscal deficits and excess liquidity are the principal
sources of inflation," he said.
"A new tax package and other
measures were implemented, all
designed to increase revenues, to
improve tax-collection procedures, heighten public-sector per•ormance and re-initiate the
rivatization program."
He said the government's proram is just starting to show rejlts.
A new report from Credit Lyonnais Securities, a New York investment bank, is recommending
Venezuelan stocks.
Mr. Echeverria said the report
is titled "Out of Adversity Comes
Opportunity."
"Let us all work on that belief,"
he said.
Prize for a king
King Hussein of Jordan, who
has received many honors in his
long reign, adds another prize to
his trophy case tomorrow.
But this one is named for a
man accused of a Nazi past and
barred from the United States!
The monarch is this year's recipient of the Kurt Waldheim
Prize.
The king was nominated for .
the prize for his efforts to bring
peace to the Middle East, capped
by Jordan's peace treaty with Israel on Oct. 26.
King Hussein is only the second person to receive the $30,000
prize, which was first awarded to
Jelena Brajsa, head of the Roman
Catholic charity Caritas in Croatia.
He will be presented with the
prize at a ceremony in the former
imperial Hofburg Palace in Vienna, Austria.
The peace prize was founded
by a body called the Friends of
Waldheim Institute after Mr.
Waldheim ended his six-year
term as Austrian president in
1992.
Mr. Waldheim, U.N. secretarygeneral from 1972 to 1981, went
from widespread respect to international notoriety in 1986, when
he was found to have concealed
facts about his war activities as a
German army officer.
He remains on a list barring
entry into the United States by
war criminals, terrorists and
those concealing World War I I actions.
Mr. Waldheim has denied responsibility for the persecution
of Jews or other civilians or for
any war crime during his time as
an Austrian officer in the German army.

Defense
a threat
to ABM
Treaty
Testing OK, but
not deployment
By Bill Gertz
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
Deployment of the Pentagon's
centerpiece missile defense system will violate the 1972 AntiBallistic Missile TVeaty unless the
pact is clarified with the Russians,
a senior arms control official says.
John Holum, director of the U.S.
Arms Control and Disarmament
Agency, says the Theater High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD)
"can be tested, but its deployment
will create difficulties" for ABM
Treaty compliance.
Mr. Holum's remarks — made
during a luncheon meeting Tuesday with reporters and editors of
The Washington Times — reflect
the divergent views within the administration on the issue.
The Pentagon has set initial deployment for THAAD in 2001 and
identified it as one of three "core"
theater missile defense (TMD)
programs to be built in the next six
years.
However, officials at ACDA and
the White House National Security
Council and vice president's office
are opposed to building any theater systems that might weaken
the ABM TY-eaty.
The CUnton administration informed the Russian government
Jan. 12 that it is going ahead with
14 THAAD tests over two years,
despite ongoing talks with Moscow aimed at clarifying the ABM
Tt-eaty.
The talks are deadlocked over
Russian insistence on restricting
individual components of U.S.
anti-missile systems.
A U.S. government official familiar with the compliance issue
said Mr. Holum's remarks were
contrary to both the Pentagon and
State Department views.
"The ABM TVeaty has always
been interpreted as linking development, testing and deployment
[of systems] as a single unit," the
aide said. "You can't say testing is
approved but deployment is not."
Pentagon and militarv officials
are firmly against letting the
treaty interfere with efforts to
build needed defenses against rhe
growing threat of short-range missile attacks against U.S. troops and
interests overseas.
The White House National Security Strategy, released yesterday,
says the TMD talks with Russia
"reflect the administration's commitment to maintaining the integrity and effectiveness of crucial
arms agreements." The 33-page
document makes only a passing
reference to missile defenses.
Mr, Holum, a State Department
official in the Carter administration and former aide to Sen.
George McGovern, said the U.S.
side could not make a unilateral
declaration to the Russians on its
TMD programs without undermining the ABM TVeaty.
"Remember, there is a fundamental value to the ABM TVeaty in
the current context," he said. "The
ABM TVeaty is likely to be fundamentally important to ratification in Russia of the START I I
treaty."
Russian officials have made
continuation of the ABM TVeaty a
precondition for "further deep
strategic arms reductions" after
the START I I treaty, which has
been signed but not ratified, Mr.
Holum said.
Mr. Holum also said the administration is not certain it will submit an agreement with Russia on
the theater missile defense issue
to the Senate, as Senate leaders
have requested.
"Our position has been that we
will consult with the Senate and
that the form in this case follows
substance," the ACDA director
said. "Until we have an agreement,
we won't know whether it's an
amendment to the treaty or not."
A senior administration official
said the problem with submitting
the treaty to the Senate is that it
would also require submission to
the legislatures of Russia, Ukraine
and Belarus, which the Clinton administration has designated as
ABM . successors to the Soviet
Union.
Mr. Holum declined to discuss
the stalemated talks with the Russians but said "the treaty needs to
be clarified" and the issue of successor states is "a matter of some
concern."
The objective of the talks is to
produce a "dividing line" between
strategic anti-missile systems, capable of knocking out ICBMs and
other strategic missiles, and theater anti-missile systems used
against short-range missiles, he
said.
"We have not yet reached an
agreement," Mr. Holum said.

NATO denies

By Catherine Toups
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
NEW YORK — U.N. peacekeeping troops reported another plane
in Bosnia's no-fly zone yesterday,
while officials said NATO had no
evidence to prove cargo planes
were making weapons drops
there.
Yesterday's reported sighting of
a single-propeller aircraft was the
latest of several incidents that began last month, when peacekeepers in the Hizla area reported
planes flying low and slowly in the
NATO-enforced no-fly zone.
Officials yesterday speculated
that the single-propeller plane
flew for either the Bosnian government or Bosnian Serbs. Both sides
have routinely violated the no-fly
zone with helicopters and small
aircraft.

Colombia
on drugs
More help sought
to fight traffickers
But the earlier sightings, including those of C-130 cargo
planes Feb. 10 and 12, led some to
think someone is supplying the
government forces in violation of
a weapons embargo.
And reports that fighter jets
have accompanied some of those
cargo planes have led to speculation that NATO is granting approval for or cooperating in an illegal mission.
But a NATO report released yesterday discounted those claims.
The report said peacekeepers may
have witnessed NATO training
missions Feb. 10 and 12.
The report also accused the
peacekeepers of inaccurately re-
"The United States is
not supplying
weapons to any party
in Bosnia"
— Pentagon
spokesman
Ken Bacon
porting the identities of the
planes, which they said could have
been commercial jets.
"The hypothesis that some kind
of clandestine cargo, possibly
arms deliveries, . . . is considered
not conclusively proven by any of
the information available," U.N.
spokesman Fred Eckhard said yesterday.
But Mr. Eckhard conceded that
the sightings of cargo planes
"have not been fully explained and
remain something of a mystery."
Officials in Washington yesterday strongly denied reports that
the Bosnian government or anyone I
else in the area was receiving
weapons from U.S. airdrops.
"The United States is not supplying weapons to any party in
Bosnia," Pentagon spokesman Ken
Bacon said in an interview.
In trying to contain the fighting
in the Balkans, "we also want to
avoid taking any actions that
would Americanize the war, and
we don't intend to take any such
actions," Mr. Bacon said.
He said the NATO report
"speaks for us" on the issue of reported arms shipments.
U.N. officials yesterday said
there is not enough proof to merit
a continued investigation of the
sightings. But Russian diplomats
called the NATO report unacceptable and said they will press
for an explanation when the Security Council meets tomorrow.
"We are by no means satisfied
by what this investigation came up
with," a senior diplomat at Russia's
U.N. mission said yesterday.
"We are still awaiting an explanation from the secretary-gen- 50
eral. If we do not get these explanations, we'll take a stance . . . to
find out what went on there."
Peacekeepers have not reported
seeing any planes land or drop 8
weapons, though they were prevented by Bosnian government
troops from examining the ground
under the flights. The peacekeepers have based their speculation of cargo drops on the low altitude of the flights.
NATO officials pledged yesterday to better inform the U.N. force
in Bosnia of training missions and
flights. U.N. officials said they will
beef up their observation posts to
watch for violations.

By Martin Sieff
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
The United States sharply criticized the new Colombian government yesterday for not cooperating fully with Washington to fight
the international drug trade and
called for it to adopt an aggressive
policy to capture and prosecute
traffickers.
The State Department also accused President Ernesto Semper
of being apologetic toward the Cali
drug cartel.
TVvelve percent of the heroin entering the United States last year
came from Colombia, the department said, while 60 percent originated in Burma.
The department's 534-page International Narcotics Control
Strategy Report angered Thiwan
by including it on a list of 29 countries that are major centers for international drug trading. But it
gave Taiwan high marks for fighting the scourge.
Afghanistan joined Nigeria,
Burma, Syria and Iran as countries that are not cooperating with
the United States in fighting drug
trafficking or making sufficient
efforts to combat the trade themselves.
Although Colombia produces an
estimated three-fourths of the
world's cocaine, the State Department for eight years had praised
its efforts to fight the drug trade.
That changed yesterday.
The report was a slap at Mr.
Semper, who was elected last year,
but Colombia still was certified as
an ally in fighting drugs. Refusal
to grant certification would have
forced a cutoff of aid and cooperation for Colombia.
In Bogota, the U.S. criticism
drew an indignant reaction from
Attorney General Orlando Vasquez.
"No country in the world involved in drug-trafficking problems has paid a higher price in
human sacrifice," he said, recalling the drug violence of the past
decade.
"The fundamental issue in Colombia is strong, serious law enforcement. The world's largest
cocaine-trafficking organizations
are based in Colombia, and they
threaten Colombia's very social
and political institutions," Robert
Gelbard, assistant secretary of
state for international narcotics
and law enforcement, said at a
news conference.
"Colombia needs an aggressive
policy to capture and prosecute
major drug traffickers. They need
a judicial system and process that
really punishes drug traffickers
with sentences commensurate
with their crimes rather than just
slaps on the wrist. They need
money-laundering and assetforfeiture laws," he said.
"We clearly do not feel at this
point that the Colombian government is cooperating fully with us."
Asked about reports that Colombia's police chief had phoned
the Cali drug cartel to apologize
for disrupting a birthday party for
one of its chieftains, Mr. Gelbard
said: " I don't believe it was the national police commissioner who
did that, lb our very great concern, I think it was the president
who did that. We were very concerned about it."
