�Letters
Repeal regs that keep minority workers unemployed
5
a
As President Clinton's bureaucrats conduct a review to identify
obsolete and burdensome rules
("President battles GOP rules
freeze," Federal Report, Feb. 22),
there is one set of rules crying out
for repeal: regulations implementing the Davis-Bacon Act.
Davis-Bacon, enacted in 1931 during the heyday of the Jim Crow era,
had the unambiguous intent of eliminating "colored labor" as competition for members of the mostly segregated construction unions.
Little-noticed amid the clamor and
hysterics from the civil-rights community about an alleged Republican
conspiracy to "roll back" gains made
under affirmative action were recent
hearings held by Republican-controlled committees in both the House
and Senate to repeal Davis-Bacon.
Davis-Bacon increases the cost of
federal construction projects by
upwards of 20 percent and adds at
least SI billion annually to the federal budget deficit. The act imposes an unreasonable paperwork burden on small and minority
construction companies that do not
have personnel to comply with its
record-keeping rules, and are therefore discouraged from bidding on
federal construction projects.
Davis-Bacon impedes the growth
of minority construction companies
because their historical lack of
access to working capital limits their
capacity to compete for construction
projects on which prevailing wages
(read: union wages) must be paid,
which, in tum, minimizes their role
in community development. DavisBacon's impact is particularly pernicious in low-income areas where
there is a high concentration of
young, unskilled workers who are
willing to work for less than the prevailing wage on projects in their
own communities and often in the
very public housing in which they
live. Davis-Bacon's mandated wages
render them unemployable because
a federal contractor is unlikely to

S m civil servants at the National Archives live up to their title
o e
Countless stories have been
printed about the sins of the federal government. In fairness, other
accounts must also be heard: Here's
one.
I recently spent a week at the
National Archives at Archives II in
Maryland, researching material for
Stanford University's conductorson-film collection. I was astounded
by what I experienced.
The facilities are first-class by
any standard, well-organized and
sensibly displayed. The staff are
even better. I found them professional, available and enormously
helpful. They took a genuine interest in my project and in those of the
several dozen researchers in there
at every hour. Patient, thorough
and deeply knowledgeable of the
American history for which they
are responsible, the staff could not
have been more committed to their
work.
Citizens who encounter nothing
but roadblocks in bureaucracy may
not know that there is another side
to our civil service. I now know it
for a fact.

Give tax credits to the fathers who pay for child support
Let me respond to Mona
Charen's Feb. 13 column, "The
child support trap."
I agree that we need tougher laws
to get the deadbeat fathers to pay
their child support, but I also think
there should be (for the lack of a
better word) ah incentive to make
it easier for the fathers to pay their
fair share.
I am one of the few fathers who
is more than happy to pay his fair
share of child support without a
judge or anybody else telling me
when or how much I have to pay.
But I think it is a shame that we lawabiding fathers can't take the support we pay off our taxes.
Just because the child doesn't
live with the father most of the year,
we are not allowed to claim dependent-care expense. Even if the child
is with us every other weekend (26
weekends a year), and two weeks
for vacation. Yet we are still expected to pay the support and in some
cases, such as mine, also provide
the health care coverage, which
isn't cheap under a two-party plan.
I, too, think there should be more
emphasis placed on the father helping to raise the child, but for those
of us who are proud of of our children and more than willing to pay
the support, I think we should be
able to enjoy the same tax breaks as
the parents who have custody when
it comes to paying for support and
health coverage.
THOMAS M. PITTS
Falls Church
'Loser pays' rule won't fix what's wrong with our legal system
Should the loser pay to prevent
frivolous lawsuits?
Republicans in Congress are
wise to confront the chaos and nonsense of our court system. But
"loser pays" is a serious mistake in
legal reform.
Our legal system is bleeding from
a thousand wounds of irrational
precedents, legislating from the
bench and uncertainty as to what the
laws are. A "loser pays" bandage is
inadequate tofixthe faults of our
laws, lawyers and courts.
We don't have legal problems
because people initiate frivolous
lawsuits. All too often, people actually win thosefrivolouslawsuits.
"Loser pays" is wrong because it
does not go far enough.
In their "Contract With America,"
Republicans proposed the Common
Sense Legal Reform Act Responding to exploding litigation against
defendants with little relationship to
the wrong, on questionable grounds,
for excessive amounts, many argue
that American should adopt the
English Rule: The loser in a lawsuit
would pay all the legal expenses for
the winning party.
This proposal rests on a very
dubious assumption: that the
"loser" was the one who was wrong,
who should have lost. When the
gavel sounds, we think we know
who was the frivolous party,
responsible for absurd lawsuits: the
party who lost.
This is a sad fantasy. Dont assume
courts give correct results. It is
charming that American have that
much faith in judges, courts and
lawyers but there is no reason to
think a party loses due to being
wrong.
"Loser pays" is more like spinning a roulette wheel, disregarding
right and wrong. If the person is
lucky, he takes it all. If he is unlucky,
he pays both his own legal fees,
plus those of the winner.
We must reform absurd rules
that allowfrivolouslawsuits to win.
We should be much more alarmed
about why they so easily win. The
incentive to file meritless cases is
driven by the strong chance of
pulling it off, regardless of bandage
solutions.
As a third-year law student, my
blood boils when I read our judges'
irrational opinions. This is no
defense of lawyers or judges.
"Loser pays" is much too easy on
them. The answer is to dig deeper
andfixdozens of legal mistakes and
failings.
Most people don't realize that
their state legislature could correct
the problems in our courts by the
stroke of a pen.
Instead of just telling lawyer
jokes, let's pressure legislators to
actuallyfixthe legal madness.
JONATHON MOSELEY
Arlington

Tearing a royal blue suit
that was a shade or two
brighter than the sapphire hue of the satin draperies and

Clinton opened the newly refurbished White House Blue Room to

favorite" — The

the
women's
Suzanne
pages of any
Fields
newspaper of the

ability, would have suggested that

Putting official language on our lips
H
ere's a totally rad idea:
Make the language of the
Declaration of Independence and US. Constitution — the language in which congressional debate takes place and
the language spoken by most Americans throughout our history — the
official language of the United
States.
That's the objective of the National Language Act of 1995, filed last
week by Rep. Peter King, New York
Republican. Besides the ceremonial designation of English, the measure would abolish federal subsidies for bilingual education and
prohibit printing federal documents, including ballots, in any
other language.
It would strike a blow against
the linguistic separatism that's
becoming a feature of daily life in
multicultural America, where you
can graduate from high school, get
a driver's license, pay your taxes
and vote without knowing a word of
the mother tongue.
In a country of many religions,
races and ethnic groups, English is
our social adhesive. When a
nation's people can no longer speak
to each other, they often resort to
nonverbal communication — witness Bosnia.
The federal government subsidizes bilingual education to the tune
of $254 million annually. More than
2 million children are in bilingual
classes, learning everything from
art to science in every language
from Arabic to Russian.
What was meant as a transition
for immigrants and their children
has turned into a ghetto from which
many never escape. A 1994 study
by the New York City Board of Education documented the bankruptcy
of bilingualism. An American education system that stops educating
students to be Americans has failed
in its most essential function.
Students who graduate unable to
read their diplomas can proceed to
vote in elections where they can't
understand stump speeches or
most political advertising.
Under a 1992 extension of the
Voting Rights Act, bilingual election
material must be provided in districts where more than 5 percent of
the population or more than 10,000
are foreign-language speakers. In
1993, Los Angeles county spent
$125,250 for election information in
Spanish, Vietnamese, etc. Only
3,264 voters actually availed themselves of this option.
For the first time last year, the
Internal Revenue Service printed a
half-million tax forms in Spanish
(at a cost of $113,000). Less than
1,000 were used. When ethnic pandering is the goal, cost is no obstacle.
Increasingly, bilingualism bor-
ders on coercion. The Tfexas Public
Utilities Commission is considering
a rule to require utilities to employ
Spanish-speaking
operators,
repairmen and linemen.
The rule would make it difficult
for Americans who speak only English to get a job in the industry.
Anglo Tfexans would be better off if
the state were still part of Mexico.
Then, Santa Anna's successors
could cater to them.
More than 40 states give driver's
tests in languages other than English. Some even provide interpreters for road tests. Can street
signs in Tbgalbg be far off?
M
jobs program. Ethnic activists
would prefer that their constituents
never learned English. In this way,
they can maintain their status and
power as liaisons between immigrants and the political establishment. It alsoflattersactivists' group
pride to think the country must

And bilingualism perfectly fits
the multicultural agenda, which

What better way to demonstrate

ost immigrants reject this

THOMAS SOWELL
all those who took an interest in the 12-year-old black
youngster whom we called
"Billy," let me thank you for
your letters to me and your phone
calls to the San Mateo County Department of Social Services, which was
trying to take him away from the
white foster parents who have been
caring for him forfiveyears.
The social workers and bureaucrats
did not come to their senses — that
would have been expecting too much
—but the judge in this caserefusedto
be bamboozled by their dogmas and
instead ruled that Billy could go with
hisfosterparents to Oregon.
Billy's attorney, Marta Diaz, was
also very moved by the letters and
faxes that she received from across
the country. One interracial couple
in Seattle sent her a picture of their
family, which included Hispanic,
Korean and Eskimo children that
they had adopted. They urged her to
fight hard to save Billy.
It is one of the small but important signs of progress that there are
more such families today than any of
us would have dreamed of jdst a
quarter-century ago. I have encountered a number of families that have
adopted minority children — and
none of these children have suffered
any of the horrors dreamed up by
social workers, "identity" experts
and miscellaneous race hustlers.
A pediatrician in St. Louis sent a
long letter to Stuart Oppenheim,
director of the youth and family services division, pleading with him not
to ruin this child's life by tearing
him out of the only home he has. But
it made no difference. The San
Mateo County Department of Social
Services insisted on going forward
with its attempt to take Billy away,
even though they had no better alternative to offer him than institutional care.
Mr. Oppenheim said "a transracial placement" can "create for an
adolescent a terrible identity crisis." But apparently all will be
peaches and cream if you just snatch
him out of his home and throw him
in with a bunch of strangers.
If Mr. Oppenheim truly believes
that, then we might at least feel
sorry for him. But cases like this are
not usually about different beliefs
but about the ugly politics of race
and the culture of resentment that
has grown up around it.
King Solomon understood, thousands of years ago, that anyone who
would tear a child apart to make a
point was not a real mother. It is
truly tragic if Mr. Oppenheim does
not understand the same principle
today. But all this is not just one
man's doing.
Behind such callous bureaucratic policies are organized groups of
black social workers who have successfully intimidated social service
agencies across the country into
preventing black children from finding homes with white families.
Those who wear their "blackness"
like a chip on their shoulder do not
hesitate to sacrifice a black child to
score a point against whitey.
Unfortunately, Billy was not
T
1
Billy
is all
right
unique in being a target for those
who put dogmas above human
beings. What was unusual was that
it didn't work this time.
At this moment, social welfare
officials in Denver are trying to yank
a Hispanic child out of a foster home
where a white couple have raised
him from early infancy to age 5.
Since the bureaucrats cannot find a
Hispanic home for him in Denver,
they want to send him to Fort Collins,
more than 60 miles away, to an unrelated Hispanic family. That means
he may lose contact with every child
and every adult that he has ever
known in his life.
In New Jersey, an interracial
couple — black wife, white husband — are trying to adopt a black
child, and the New Jersey bureaucrats are fighting them.
Make no mistake about it, the
racial resenters are determined to
get their own way, and are
unscrupulous about how they do it.
They have no facts to back up their
claims, but they don't rely on facts.
They rely on intimidation and
underhanded maneuvers.
Any white official who stands in
their way can expect to be called a
"racist," even though it is the social
workers who are hyping race. And
if intimidation does not work, trickery often will.
Last year, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum introduced a bill in Congress
to stop all this interference with
transracial adoptions. But by the
time the bill came to a vote, it had
been so sabotaged with new provisions that it has actually made it
harder than before to adopt a child
of a different race.
Among those fighting for these
children's needs to take precedence
over racial dogmas is Professor
Rita Simon of American University, who has just helped found the
Adoptions Studies Institute. Now
people who want to know the facts,
instead of the strident rhetoric, will
have a place to turn to.
The Institute for Justice, headed
by Clint BoUck in Washington, is
looking into the legal issues to see
what can be done to help these children who need homes, not ideology.
Let us rejoice for Billy — and
then see what can be done for
other minority youngsters who still
need a home and have not been so
lucky.
Thomas Sowell, an economist
and a senior fellow at the Hdover
Institution, is a nationally syndi
cated columnist.

r

poverty line. That is not objectionable — though it should be borne in
mind that the poverty rate is calculated without including benefits like
housing subsidies and food stamps.
Additionally, children whose
families earn between 130 percent
and 180 percent of the federally
established poverty line are eligible
to receive lunches at reduced cost
(about 40 cents a meal).
But those are not the only children who participate. Any child
who attends a school that receives
funds for subsidized school lunches may buy a lunch — and that
lunch will be subsidized to some
extent by the federal and state governments. Moreover, funding is
supplied based on meals served.
So the more kids who eat subsidized
food, the more money the school
district gets. With an incentive
structure like that, the only wonder
is that the participation level isn't
100 percent instead of 59 percent!
In fiscal 1994, the federal government appropriated $4.3 billion
for the school lunch program. The
states spent additional funds. The
appropriation for 1996 will be S6.7
billion. This is in addition to the
more than S25 billion spent annually on food stamps. Someone who
wanted to be truly obstreperous
might ask why the meals of poor
kids are being subsidized twice,
once by food stamps and again by
the school lunch program.
But those of us with more even
dispositions merely note that the
school lunch program is subsidizing
lunches (and breakfasts) for a lot of
kids who clearly don't need the help.
"Eixpayers are the losers. Who
benefits? As it happens, one group
that benefits is a traditionally
Republican constituency — farmers. If middle-class kids are getting
subsidized peanut butter and jelly,
there are peanut farmers and grape
growers who are being paid to provide them.
And perhaps that explains a mystery: The Republicans in Congress •
have endured the curses and insults
of the Democrats, but they haven't
even proposed a substantive reform
of the program! All the Republicans
have sought to do is wrap the school
lunch program into a block grant
and permit the states to set their
own nutrition standards. That is
what the governor of Vermont predicted would result in "children
going hungry."
Bunk. The school lunch program
has become obese. It deserves to be
cut radically, so that only poor kids
are eligible. But don't hold your
breath, because some of the people
who've been fed by the school lunch
program are Republican farmers.
Mona Charen is a nationally syndicated columnist.

Living the tragedy of
Alzheimer's disease
By Kay Ryan
M
1
Kay Ryan is a congressional
aide.
WRS
y mother used to tell me on
a regular basis to live every
day with the conscious
intent to make other human beings
happy that you exist. She also used
to say, "You'll never see a deaf and
dumb man in jail." Mother fussed
over every minute detail of my life
— proms, play dress rehearsals,
speeches, swim practice, new
school uniforms, college boards,
dates, etc. Her Southern, Will
Rogers-like observations of life
have been silenced now. My mother has been diagnosed with
Alzheimer's.
Mostly her days are nbw spent
looking out the front window of the
house, pacing incessantly like a
caged tiger and humming hyms to
herself. This woman, who was so
fastidiously neat, now must have
her diapers changed at least every
two hours. This woman, who was
the consummate Southern hostess,
now cannot find the kitchen, much
less cook. This woman, who was the
epitome of health and decorum,
now refuses to take showers and
curses like a bawdy sailor.
The eternal grief I. feil for my
mother is a neverending torture.
Death is cruel this way, ensnaring
my mother's brain in the vicelike
grip of Alzheimer's. I see reality
flicker in her eyes every so often,
only to note it as a cruel hoax, prolonging the agony of the eventual.
Mother's clarity in moments of
recollection occurs at random
times. Worse still, she has become
the perfect editor — remembering
things as she would have liked them
to be. I am now the only link
between past and future generations, relying upon historical accuracy from stories told long ago in
my childhood.
It has been many years since I
sought her counsel. I miss it dearly. My mother maintained such a
presence in every decision I made
professionally and personally. This
disease has created a massive void

�The smart alternative for WTO head
By Daryl Plunk
W
ith the arrest this week of
former Mexican President
Carlos Salinas de Gotari's
elder brother on assassination
charges, the crisis gripping America's neighbor and close ally worsened. Political and economic turmoil in Mexico presents clear
threats to U.S. national interests.
Arelatedmatter affecting American interests is also at stake: Washington's choice to lead the New
World Drade Organization (WTO).
Fbr months, the Clinton administration has backed President Salinas for the new WTO DirectorGeneral post. These hopes have
been irreplacably damaged, and
administration officials know this,
with one admitting privately that
Daryl Plunk is a senior analyst
with the Heritage Foundation's
Asian Studies Center.
"Salinas is finished." So, the administration must now choose a new
candidate. It should move swiftly to
back Kim Chulsu, South Korea's
ambassador for international trade.
The WTO was created by the conclusion of the GATT Uruguay Round
last year. It will oversee the voluminous new trade rules spelled out in
the 20,000-page Final Act. The WTO
also has new dispute resolution powers that have raised concerns in the
United States about the future of
America's economic sovereignty.
The organization's first director-general will give direction to this new
mechanism and, thus, is important to
America's economic interests.
For months, the only formal
WTO leadership candidates have
been Mr. Salinas, Mr. Kim and former Italian TY-ade Minister Renato
Ruggiero. Mr. Ruggiero is backed
by the European Union (EU) and
currently is considered the front
runner. Given the plethora of trade
disputes the United States has with
the EU, together with the fact that
all past GATT directors have been
European, the administration rules
out American support for Mr. Ruggiero. However, the Office of the
US. Tt-ade Representative, the point
agency on the WTO, also expresses
reservations about Mr. Kim, charging that Korea's market-opening
record is not up to speed. Instead,
it is rumored that they may seek a
new "compromise candidate."
This position is misguided. Past
and present trade disputes with
Korea are well known, but its market-liberalization program in recent
years has been impressive and effective. American exports to Korea are
growing, and are valued at about
$20 billion annually. America's trade

A fter several months of consignment to oblivion,
Z \ the Maryland smoking ban has suddenly
1 \.returned to life. Last year, then-Secretary of
Licensing and Regulation William Fbgel took upon
himself the awesome and compassionate responsibility of caring for the humble folk of his state by issuing a bureaucratic decree banning smoking in all
workplaces — inclyding private bars and restaurants, private hotel rooms, offices, factories and corner pool parlors. A court ruling found that the decree
was improperly issued and held it up, and most people forgot about it. Now, another state court has resurrected it, and the ban will go into effect in 30 days.
That's what happens when people forget
What is curious about the ban is that not a single
soul in the state was allowed to vote on it — not the
citizens, not the state legislators, not the consumers
who want to smoke or who do or don't care about
smoking, not the private merchants whose businesses may be harmed by it. As in "The Wizard of
Oz," nobody gets to see the wizard, not no way, no how.
Of course, this is not "The Wizard of Oz" but "Alice
in Wonderland," wherefictionis truth and the impossible happens frequently. The smoking ban is based
on the supposition, trumpeted by anti-smoking propagandaforseveral years, that "passive smoke" is.
harmful to those exposed to it. Never mind that the
"studies" that supposedly prove that claim have been
discredited as havingreliedon unscientific and tendentious methodologies. Never mind that those who
dislike tobacco smoke or who may be harmed by exposure to it can always avoid places where it is common
or ask politely those who are smokingtorefrain out
of courtesy. In the new Wonderland, courtesy has no
more place than democracy or valid science.
Critics of the ban, including a coalition of small
businessmen whose restaurants and bars could be
ruined by the exodus of smoking customers, were
instrumental in bringing the legal action that temporarily halted its implementation, but neither Maryland Attorney General J. Joseph Curran Jr. nor the
anti-smoking battalions were interested in what the
people who actually have to live with the ban had to
say. "Waiters and waitresses," intoned Mr. Curran the
other day, "people who carry food and drink to the
tables in small restaurants, they're entitled to the
same protection as people in bigger businesses." Mr.
Curran was inveighing against the prospect of Gov.
Parris Glendening modifying the ban to exempt
small restaurants and tavems. As Mr. Curran would
have it, nobody gets exempted, not no way, no how.
But Mr. Curran's solicitude for "waiters and waitresses" who might catch a snoutful of tobacco aroma
when they serve the tables is a pretense. If waiters
and waitresses are concerned about their exposure,
they can probably arrange to serve tables in the nonsmoking section (which virtually all restaurants
have already). Even if they can't so arrange and even
if exposure to passive smoke were proved to be
harmful, how much exposure do waiters and waitresses get? If Mr. Curran is so worried about the waiters and waitresses, why doesn't he let them vote on
the ban?
The implications of what the state government—
the unelected bureaucrats, the judges, the attorney
general, and the governor — have done reach far
beyond this particular decree, however. In the first
place, if the state can ban smoking in private workplaces (including hotel rooms, on the grounds that
maids who make the beds might be affected by last
night's orgy of smoking), why can't it ban smoking
in private homes (on the grounds that the Maytag
repairman might contract cancer if he gets a whiff
of your cigar)? In the second place, if it can ban smoking, why can't it ban anything else it doesn't like?
The old-fashioned answertothe latter question is
that, well, of course the voters wouldn't allow it to.
But what this ban shows is that in Maryland the voters don't determine such matters anymore. If Maryland voters are smart, they'll do something about this
and demand a vote, on the ballot or at least in the legislature, before the ban can go into effect, and thereby make sure that this kind of government by decree
can't happen here, not no way, no how.

�Clinton says he'll shrink nuclear stockpile; slams
GOP for isolationism By William Neikirk
Chicago Tribune
WASHINGTON Decrying a "new isolationism" in
American politics, President Clinton announced Wednesday
night he was dramatically shrinking the U.S. nuclear stockpile
as a good-faith effort to win a permanent extension of the
nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
In a foreign policy address, the president unveiled the
unilateral step as an olive branch to non-nuclear nations
balking at extending the landmark accord when it comes up
for renewal in April. They claim the United States and
other nuclear powers are hypocritical and seeking to
cement a nuclear double-standard.
At the same forum, named in honor of former President
Richard IA. Nixon, Senate Republican Leader Robert Dole of
Kansas accused Clinton of conducting a misguided " Yeltsin
first" policy in Russia, implying it led to the loss of
life'in the rebellious republic of Chechnya.
Clinton's attack on isolationism in the Republican
Party and Dole's counterpunch at the president's Russian
policy put foreign policy in the middle of a fierce
polilical arena that has, until now, largely focused on
domestic policy.
The president used the power of his office by ordering
the removal of 200 tons of fissile material, enriched
uranium and plutonium, from the stockpile used to make
weapons. This would be enough to make thousands of nuclear
weapons and represents a "significant reduction" in the
stockpile, according to senior administration officials.
Noting that the expiring non-proliferation treaty marks
its 25.th anniversary this week, Clinton said, "nothing is
more important to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons
than extending-the treaty indefinitely and
unconditionally."
The treaty must be reviewed by all 171 countries that
have pledged to abide by its restrictions. The Clinton
administration concedes it is at least 17 votes shy of the
majority it needs to make the treaty permanent.
Some countries point out that the United States and
other nuclear powers still control huge stockpiles of
nuclear material and weapons, and should do more to reduce
them. Others favor an extension of the treaty, but for a
limited time.
While uranium can be used for power reactors, plutonium
can't be destroyed and would have to be stored,
administration officials conceded. But one senior
administration official said, "When you take the material
to make nuclear weapons out of the stockpile, it makes it
impossible for it to be used again in weapons."
National Security Adviser Anthony Lake expressed hope
that the president's initiative would help persuade other
countries to go along with indefinite extension of the
treaty. Officials said the United States wouldn't
compromise over the permanent extension and that 60 to 70
countries of the 87 necessary to make it permanent favored
the indefinite extension.
In his speech, Clinton also said the non-proliferation,
treaty was a major example of the need for U.S. engagement
in the world.
"Arms control makes us both safer and stronger," he
said. " I t is one of the most effective insurance policies
we can write for the future."
(EDITORS: STORY CAN TRIM HERE)
The president called 1995 a year " i n which the United
States will pursue the most ambitious agenda to dismantle
and fight the spread of weapons of mass destruction since
the atom was split."
The president said the "new isolationists, both on the
left and right, would radically revise the fundamentals of
our foreign policy that have earned bipartisan support
since World War II."
He said they would eliminate any role for the United
Nations and U.N. peacekeeping efforts, deny foreign aid lo
fledging democracies and trumpei ihe rhetoric of American
strength while denying resources that would make America
strong.
"We must not let the ripple of isolationism they have
generated build intoia tidal wave," he said.
Lake told reporters earlier that Clinton was referring
chiefly to Republicans in the House and that isolationism
could be contained in the Senate.
But Dole, a candidate for president in the 1996
campaign, showed that an internationalist like himself
could pose a major challenge to Clinton on foreign policy.
He said Russia's policies, from North Korea, to
Yugoslavia, to Iran, were "often in conflict with
American interests." Just as it was wrong for President
George Bush to place loo much faith in Soviet President
Mikhail Gorbachev, it is now wrong for Clinton to put so
much faith in Yeltsin, Dole said.
"The Clinton's administration's misguided devotion to
a Russia First' policy which has turned into a 'Yeltsin
First' policy resulted in the loss of a tremendous
opportunity to state American concerns forcefully before
thousands were slaughtered in Chechnya," Dole said.
He called upon Clinton to develop a more realistic,
honest relationship with Russia. In response, Lake said
Clinton had spoken out against the war in Chechnya and
denied the United States was pursuing a Russian first or
Yeltsin first policy.
"Chechnya has started to drive a wedge between
President Yeltsin and some of the reformers," Lake said.
"In our view, it is important that we act in a way that
makes it easier rather than harder for Yeltsin and the
reformers to come together again. ..."
Dole also warned against the United States falling into
a false sense of security even if the non-proliferation
treaty was extended indefinitely. When Iraq's nuclear,
ambitions became clear after the Gulf War, he said, the
administration dispatched U.N. Ambassador Madeleine
Albright to Europe to plead for cooperation in putting
pressure on Iraq. "Where would such timidity have gotten
us in the Cold War?" he asked.
Lake fired back that Dole's statement was "simply
unfounded on the facts." He said Albright's mission was
to give members of the U.N. Security Council a tough
message that the United Stales would insist on sanctions
against Iraq as long'as it violated U.N. resolutions.
�School food service officials fear consequences of
federal bill By Rachel L. Jones Knight-Ridder
Newspapers
WASHINGTON In Richmond, Calif., where Heidy
Camorongan is administrator of food services for the local
school district, children start lining up at 6 a.m. during summer
months for free breakfast.
Under a change in federal school nutrition programs now
before the House of Representatives, her West Contra
Costa Unified School District, with its high percentage of
poor black, Latino, Laotian and Vietnamese children, would
probably have to end that program and drastically cut back
on the fresh fruits and vegetables in the 17,000 daily
meals it provides.
"1 did the numbers, and, under this bill, I'd have to
come up with a half-million dollars extra for next year,"
Camorongan said. " I don't think they understand just what
we're up against."
Camorongan and other members of the American School
Food Service Association shared their frustrations about
the House bill, known as HR 999, at the group's annual
legislative conference here. These are the people who feed
millions of schoolchildren each day. For them, the House
bill intended to combine federal school nutrition programs
into state block grants is a disaster waiting to happen.
Under the bill, part of the Republican Contract With
America's welfare-reform package, school breakfasts,
lunches and child care meals would be combined with such
programs as supplemental nutrition for Women, Infants and
Children, or WIC. One grant to the states would cover
school meals and the other would cover all remaining
child-nutrition programs and WIC.
The bill currently calls for annual increases of 4.5
percent over five years in the amount of money for the
block grants, and backers say this would mean more money
for school meals. But ASFSA members say the bill doesn't
allow for inflation or for the possibility of increased
participation in food programs during a recession.
While the focus of the debate is on free meals for poor
students, school administrators say that, because all
school meals arc subsidized, the House bill would affect
their ability to feed all students. Slightly more than
half the 25 million schoolchildren get free or cut-price
meals, costing $5 billion a year, according to the U.S.
Department of Agriculture.
The federal move toward block grants is touted by
Republicans as a way to cut bureaucracy and allow states
to decide the best ways to serve residents. But ASFSA
members have little confidence that already-overburdened
states will help them perform their complex, daily
juggling act of providing nutritious meals to America's
students, poor or otherwise.
They fear that block grants will ultimately mean less
money for school lunches. In the first year, states would
receive money based on the number of meals provided the
year before. After that, money would be based on the
number of meals served compared with those served in other
states.
"You'd have a situation where states might be tempted
to cut back on meals or to lower nutritional standards to
save money and compete for more funds," said Vivian
Pilant, president of the association and state director of
school food service for South Carolina.
In ending the school lunch program, she said, the
government would no longer require schools to meet a
nutritional standard, and states could decide what
constitutes a healthy meal.
When the school lunch program was cut back in the
1980s, Pilant said, 1,000 schools stopped providing meals.
She and other association members estimated thousands more
could drop out this time around.
(EDITORS: STORY CAN END HERE)
Gene White, the association's special legislative
liaison, said not just the poor would be hit hard by the
cuts. Under the bill, 80 percent ol" block grant money must
be used for poor children defined as those whose family
income is less than 185 percent of the poverty level. White
says the definition doesn't include all the children who
need help paying for school lunches.
"You're talking about a lot of working poor families
who are just barely getting by," she says. "Two dollars
a meal may not sound like much to a family that's well
off, but when you're just making ends meet, you can't come
up with the extras."
Governors could spend ihe remaining 20 percent of their
grants as they sec fit, oven on programs that don't
provide food, and food service association members think
they will.
(EDITORS: STORY CAN END HERE)
The 800-plus members from schools nationwide said they
would go home and write legislators and rally parents
against the bill. " Y o u have io be willing to fight for
the future of America's children and for what you believe
to be a real danger lo ihem," While House Chief of Staff
Leon Panetta told them.
Camorongan said her impossible job would be even harder
because of an amendment lo the bill this week in which
schools could not use block-grant funds lo feed children
of illegal immigrants.
"Are we supposed to go through the lunch line and ask
kids i f they're legal before we take away their trays?"
she said. "We are there to feed children, and yet all
this bill will do is make sure that we can't." .
DEA clears agent accused of taking bribe from
Medellin drug lord By Jeff Leen and Gerardo
Reyes Knight-Ridder Newspapers
M I A M I An internal review by the U.S. Drug Enforcement
Administration has concluded that a Colombian drug
informant lied when he accused a DEA agent of accepting
$25,000 to import a luxury car for a Medellin cartel drug lord.
DEA's Division of Inspections rejected the story told
by the informant, Gabriel Taboada, a convicted drug dealer
who testified for the government at the 1992 drug trial of
Gen. Manuel Noriega.
Taboada alleged lasi September that he paid a middleman
in 1986 to give DEA agent William Michael Aldridge $25,000
to use his diplomatic privileges to import a Mercedes-Benz
230 station wagon into Colombia for Gustavo Gaviria,
cousin of top cartel boss Pablo Escobar.
" I n this case we did establish a number of
discrepancies and inconsistencies in Taboada's statements
and allegations," said DEA Chief Inspector Johnny Phelps.
"Wc fully documented every stage of the purchase,
ownership and sale of the vehicle."
Aldridge told The Miami Herald he felt vindicated by
the DEA's review of the matter.
"I'm happy the investigation's over," Aldridge said.
" I t really kind of gave me a bad lime for the last three
months. I don't know why the guy did it. A l l I can say is
the guy's lying, whatever his motives arc."
But Taboada told The Herald he stands by his account
despite the DEA's findings. His attorney, John Mattes of
Miami, called the DEA review a "whitewash."
"Why are they so quick lo rush to judgment to protect
their own?" said Mattes, a former investigative counsel
for the U.S. Senate. "Why don't ihcy do a complete and
thorough investigation.'
�"It's deeply disturbing to me that the DEA has chosen
to ignore the truth regarding criminal activity in the
U.S. Embassy."
In the past, Taboada has been a key witness for the
DEA. His testimony was crucial to Noriega's conviction on
federal drug charges in Miami, a case that has been called
the most important in DEA history.
Now the DEA says it believes that Taboada is distorting
the truth because he is bitter about serving a 12-year
federal prison despite his previous testimony for the DEA.
"We do feel that (Taboada) was lying," Phelps said
Aldridge, who retired from the DEA after 30 years of
government serv ice in December, served as the DEA's
assistant country attache in Colombia from 1985 to 1988.
"I've never ever knowingly done anything to help or
assist any traffickers in my life," he said. " A n d I
certainly never took any bribe or gift or anything. The
only thing I've ever done is put those bastards in jail."
Last fall, Taboada told The Herald in several
interviews that Aldridge provided cover for the cartel's
purchase of the Mercedes.
Taboada said that Aldridge had the car in his
possession for only a few months before it was driven to
Medellin and added to the cartel's carpool.
The DEA began investigating Taboada's story after The
Herald obtained a Colombia customs manifest from July 1986
showing that Aldridge had imported a Mercedes-Benz 230
station wagon valued at $17,360 from Stuttgart, Germany,
to Santa Marta, Colombia.
A DEA official familiar with the review said that
Aldridge provided the DEA with a copy of a notarized
contract showing that he raised the money lo purchase the
Mercedes from two friends who worked in English-speaking
foreign embassies in Colombia.
The two friends supported Aldridge's account in
separate telephone interviews, the DEA official said. The
DEA refused to identify the two friends.
Aldridge planned lo hold onto the car as an investment
and sell it after his tour of duty in Colombia ended, the
official said.
The DEA did not obtain bank records from Aldridge
showing how the car was purchased. Instead, the agency's
review relied on the contract provided by Aldridge and
records at Auto Mercantil Limitada, a luxury car
dealership in Bogota that ordered the Mercedes from
Germany.
Auto Mercantile records showed that the car was ordered
by Luis Rueda, a broker in Bogota. The down payment was
paid in the form of two checks totaling $1,350.20 signed
by Aldridge. The Auto Mercantil files do not reflect how
the balance of the car purchase was funded, the official
said.
The DEA interviewed Rueda, who supported Aldridge's
account and said Taboada had nothing to do with the deal,
the official said.
Aldridge purchased the car at a time when
narco-terrorism was rampant in Colombia. By .order of the
U.S. Embassy, DEA agents like Aldridge were driven to work
by bodyguards.
Both of Aldridge's Colombian bodyguards, Marco
Urrego-Moreno and Edgar Amaya-Pulido, told DEA that the
Mercedes remained in Aldridge's possession until he left
the country in 1988, long after the time Taboada said it
had gone to the cartel.
Aldridge was able to provide the DEA with a receipt
showing he paid 19,000 Colombian pesos for a car cover for
the Mercedes in 1988.
The DEA's review found that Aldridge sold the car in
1988 for about $25,000 to two Colombians, Julio Tellez and
Hermann Neckam. They, in turn, sold the car to Fabio Cruz
Bernal, a Bogota car dealer.
Taboada, a Colombian car importer as well as a
convicted drug dealer, said the cartel bought the car for
$147,000. He said a two-year-old Mercedes station wagon
could not be purchased for as little as $25,000 in
Colombia because of an import ban on luxury cars.
Jose Clopatofsky, a Colombian car expert, said a price
of $25,000 was so low for a Mercedes Benz in Colombia in
1988 that it amounted to "a gift."
But Tellez and Bernal supported Aldridge's story.
Neckam could not be located and was not interviewed by
DEA, the DEA official said. Taboada identified Neckam as
his go-between with Aldridge on the deal.
Aldridge did not supply bank records showing that
Tellez and Neckam bought the car in 1988. He reported a
$10,500 profit from the car sale on his 1988 income tax
return, the DEA official said. The two friends who appear
in the contract with Aldridge told the DEA he repaid them
and they made a profit on their loan. They also did not
supply bank records.
"What this case demonstrates is that we as an agency
are very concerned about any allegations of wrongdoing on
the part of DEA employees," Phelps said.
Clinton blasts Colombia's efforts to fight drugs,
but refuses to impose sanctions By Christopher
Marquis Knight-Ridder Newspapers
WASHINGTON The Clinton administration on Wednesday
sharply criticized Colombia's efforts to combat illegal
drug trafficking last year but refused to impose economic
sanctions against the world's largest cocaine exporter.
"We clearly do not feel at this point that the
Colombian government is fully cooperating with us," said
Robert Gelbard, the assistant secretary of state for
international narcotics matters.
The administration, reviewing Colombia's performance
for 1994, is "seriously concerned" about Colombia's
failure to pursue drug kingpins, revamp lenient sentencing
laws, enact legislation against money-laundering and
battle corruption "at all levels" of Colombian society,
Gelbard said.
Still, the government chose not to risk seriously
straining relations with the Colombia by "de-certifying"
it under the terms of an eight-year-old annual evaluation
process. That would have required the United States to
halt most aid to the country and oppose loans to Colombia
from multilateral lenders.
Instead, in its annual report to Congress on the
performance of drug-producing nations and countries
through which drugs are shipped, the administration took
the lesser step of censuring Colombia's anti-narcotics
efforts.
Clinton's finding was also an acknowledgment of
fundamental disarray in the U.S. strategy to halt cocaine
and heroin at its source. Despite sending hundreds of
millions in U.S. anti-narcotics aid to Colombia and
several other South American nations since 1990, production
is actually increasing and prosecutions of major
traffickers are scant.
'' We want to continue to try to develop further our
bilateral cooperation and try to achieve much better
results in Colombia on counter narcotics," he said, in
explaining the lighter punishment.
However symbolic, the censure was a blow to the
government of Colombian President Ernesto Samper, which
had dispatched a flock of diplomats and law enforcement
officials to Washington in recent days to lobby for full
certification.
The Samper government released a statement Wednesday
�saying it "regrets" the U.S. decision, insisting that
" i t does not acknowledge the magnitude of the effort our
country has made in the struggle against drug trafficking,
at a high cost in human life and economic resources."
Privately, Colombian officials said the move would not
affect their current anti-drug efforts and suggested that
it had more to do with domestic U.S. political concerns,
namely President Clinton's desire to demonstrate toughness
against drugs before a Republican-controlled Congress.
As the source of virtually all of the refined cocaine
reaching U.S. cities, Colombia is "the most critical
country in terms of the United States government and the
president's Western Hemisphere drug strategy," Gelbard
said.
Meanwhile, Bolivia and Peru, which account for 80
percent of the raw material for cocaine, remained on the
list of countries receiving
a so-called "national interest waiver" the same
treatment given Colombia this year despite a performance
deemed unacceptable.
"More than five years after the Andean Initiative was
announced, the U.S. government has yet to reach effective
agreements on anti-narcotics policy with its three key
allies in the region," said George Vickers, executive
director of the Washington Office on Latin America, .a
church-funded policy watchdog.
In addition, Paraguay, a growing transit country for
cocaine and marijuana, was added to the list for the first
time.
Only one nation in the hemisphere, Panama, improved its
standing in U.S. eyes, winning full certification largely
due to a policy of sweeping money-laundering controls
imposed by the government of President Ernesto Perez
Balladares.
By law, Congress has 30 days to overturn a presidential
certification, and it was unclear Wednesday whether the
waiver for Colombia would meet opposition among lawmakers.
North Carolina Sen. Jesse Helms, the Republican
chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said
Wednesday that Colombia's anti-drug performance has been
"demonstrably and woefully inadequate."
Helms' committee staff released its own report on
Colombia this week urging decertification.
(EDITORS: STORY CAN END HERE)
The report was especially critical of Samper himself,
citing "credible allegations" that he had received up to
$6 million, in campaign contributions from the Cali cocaine
cartel.
" I t is an understatement to say that I am concerned
about reports of widespread narco-corruption at all levels
of the Colombian government," Helms said. "... Colombia,
in my judgment, has failed to meet even minimal standards
for certification."
The administration report made no mention of the
charges against Samper, allegedly documented on cassette
tapes produced by the CIA and Colombian police. Samper
aides vigorously deny the charges and expressed confidence
this week that they had put the " narco-cassette" incident
behind them.
Gephardt to Propose Bill to. Erect Import
Barriers By John Maggs, The Journal of
Commerce Knight-Ridder/Tribune Business News
WASHINGTON-Mar. 2-House Minority Leader Richard
Gephardt, D-Mo., plans to introduce a new Japan trade bill
in the next two weeks, according to House aides.
While the Clinton administration and aides to the
Republican leadership do not give it much of a chance, the
bill could be an early test of sentiment for major trade
legislation this year, and of the level of protectionism
in the new GOP majority.
It also could be a referendum on Rep. Gephardt's
ability to use tough trade rhetoric to galvanize
Democrats, something that has not happened nearly as much
under President Clinton as under his two Republican
predecessors.
The bill could be called the " I f You Cant' Beat 'Em,
Join 'Em" act of 1995. In a new twist for Rep. Gephardt,
it would give President Clinton new powers to respond to
Japan's restrictive business practices by establishing
mirror restrictions in the United States.
For example, U.S. officials complain Japan excludes
many foreign auto parts through an unfairly discriminatory
certification procedure.
Under the Gephardt bill, the president could propose a
similar licensing system for the United States, and get
special expedited consideration for such a proposal in
Congress.
Since many of the retaliatory actions would erect
similar bureaucratic hurdles for imports, it is not clear
that the bill would slip through the fervor in Washington
to cut government.
. The rather blunt approach echoes the complaints that
Rep. Gephardt has made for years about Japan and revives
his effort, put forward in string of hortatory bills, to
express the inequity that many Democrats feel about trade
relations with Japan.
The bill may serve to increase the pressure on Japan in
long-running auto parts talks with the United States,
which U.S. officials want to wrap up by March 31.
Notwithstanding its slim chances, for approval in the
Republican Congress, the bill addresses a lingering question
left from the Uruguay Round on world trade that took effect
Jan. 1.
With most forms of U.S. trade retaliation restricted by
new international rules, what credible threat will the
United States be able to use to force reforms by
recalcitrant countries?
Japan's major trade barriers are beyond the scope of
these rules - enforced by the World Trade Organization but any retaliation against Japan's exports of
manufactured goods would be prohibited by the WTO.
Action to erect similar barriers in the United States
would avoid this dilemma. END!A4?JC-GEPHARDT

The Journal of Commerce

WASHINGTON-Mar. 2 - A House panel Wednesday
approved a bill that will clean up constitutional questions
about Congress' oversight of two Washington-area airports.
National and Dulles International.

with the current law, recently underlined by the Supreme
Court, in a way that continues to protect airport users
and allows the airports to continue their vital .
improvement programs," Rep. Bud Shuster, R-Pa., chairman
of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee,
said in a prepared statement Wednesday.
The Supreme Court recently decided in favor of a group
led by former District of Columbia Council Chairman John
Hechinger and a group called Citizens Against Aircraft
Noise. They had argued that Congress' control of the
�airport oversight board was an unconstitutional breach of
the separation of powers between the legislative and
executive branches.
The bill approved Wednesday increases the number of
presidential appointees to the airport authority's board
of directors from one to five. The bill replaces the
Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority Board of
Review, chaired by Rep. Norman Y. Mineta, D-Calif., with
an advisory commission.
"To really understand the present situation, you have
to take a step back into the past. In 1986, the two
airports were leased by the federal government to a local
authority, the board of directors, for 50 years. This
transfer freed the airports from federal budget
constraints and permitted them to issue bonds in order to
launch a major capital improvement program," Rep. Shuster
said.
"The federal government built the airports, still owns
the airports and only about one-third of the passengers
are local passengers. The fact is,
there is an overriding federal interest in these
airports and that's why we have this bill," Rep. Shuster
said.

details of the new advisory board and the ability of the
airports to expand under federal authority when it goes to
the House 'floor, possibly as soon as next week.

U.S.-Russia Enterprise Investment Fund Starts
Slowly By Milan Ruzicka, The Journal of
Commerce Knight-Ridder/Tribune Business News
NEW YORK-Mar. 2-After more than 18 months in
existence, the $340 million Russian-American Enterprise
Fund got off the ground, committing $12 million in equity
investment on five Russian enterprises but investing far
more on itself than on the companies it was designed to
help.
According to its own figures, so far, the fund has
spent $3.5 million on administration and its staff
salaries and travel expenses. It invested $2.5 million and
extended another $600,000 in loans.
Steven Halliwell, the fund's chief financial officer,
said, "We're being very, very prudent in making
investment decisions." But he added, "The $64 question
in these markets is what the value of your investments
will be."
The $340 million fund, set up in September 1993 and
endowed by the U.S. government,, is in business extending
financial assistance to small and medium-sized enterprises
in Russia by either buying a share of their stock or
extending loans.
The U.S. government has set up similar funds to help
most of the other Eastern bloc countries. All these funds
operate on similar principles and are aimed at stimulating
entrepreneurship in the former communist countries.
The largest of the five deals the Russian fund has
struck so far is
a commitment to invest $8 million in Dieselprom, an engine
manufacturing company in Cheboksary, the republic of
Chuvashia.
The fund's latest project is an investment of $600,000
for the purchase of 20 percent of Financial Center Grant,
a Moscow-based financial services company heavily involved
in bidding for Russia's state-owned companies. The fund is
also involved in financing the acquisition of new
machinery for Marigrazhdanstroy, a recently privatized
construction company. The fund's other projects include
investment in a wood-processing company in Siberia and a
garment-manufacturing firm south of Moscow.
The fund, while not giving out grants, provides loans
of up to $100,000, charging, according to Senior Managing
Director Roman Pipko, less than the 30 percent going
short-term rate in Moscow.
Because of the instability of the Russian currency, Mr.
Halliwell said in a telephone interview, "Ruble returns
are very difficult to evaluate." He said that to hedge
its bets, the fund is looking for export potential - and,
therefore, non-ruble earnings - as one of the key
factors in its investment decisions.
The fund employs 12 professionals and 15 support staff
in its Moscow office and another six professionals in New
York. END!A4?.1C-RUSSIA-FUND
�Social Security Is Focus of Debate Over Budget
Amendment (Washn) By Saul Fiiedman= (c)
1995, Newsday=
WASHINGTON Depending on your point of view, the
Social Security system has become a stalking-horse or a piggy
bank.
But either way, the future of the nation's retirement
system has become the focus and the biggest sticking
point in the Senate battle over the balanced budget
amendment.
The reason: The Social Security trust fund, which was
once in danger of going into the red, will be rich in cash
for the next decade or so. Indeed, the Social Security
Administration estimates that the trust fund, which has
been taking in much more than it pays out, will have a
surplus of more than $1 trillion in 2002.
That is the year for balancing the federal budget,
under provisions of the amendment. And among many
Democrats, Republican moderates and other advocates of
Social Security, there is concern that the fund will be a
tempting target for politicians looking for money to meet
the amendment's requirement.
There is a deeper suspicion of Republican intentions
toward the retirement system. Conservative leaders of the
Republican congressional majority, especially in the
House, have voiced opposition to any government-run
retirement system. And conservative think tanks such as the
influential Heritage Foundation are planning voluntary and
private alternatives to Social Security.
Senate Minority Leader Tom Daschle, D-S.D., told
reporters Wednesday that concern about Social Security had
become the central issue in the balanced budget debate.
Daschle, who met with senior citizens groups Wednesday,
questioned how Republicans could keep their promise to cut
taxes, increase military spending and balance the budget
all without touching the Social Security fund.
Daschle voted for the amendment last year when he was
part of the Democratic majority. And he would do so again,
" i f I trusted them (the Republicans) as much as I trusted
my own majority."
Republicans angrily scoff at Democrats' fears and
charge they are merely using the Social Security issue as
an. excuse and political cover to defeat the amendment,
which 75 percent of voters support, according to most
polls.
But the polls also report that voters oppose balancing
the budget by using Social Security funds. And House
Speaker Newt Gingrich told reporters Wednesday, "We're
prepared to guarantee Social Security's not going to be
touched, period."
Democrats reply that i f Republicans mean what they say,
they should agree to language in the amendment to exempt
the Social Security trust fund, which is financed by
pavroll taxes and is separate from the rest of the federal
budget.
Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., who unsuccessfully
sought such an exemption, said during the Senate debate
Tuesday that her proposal "would place Social Security
off-budget, thereby enshrining into the Constitution
congressional action and guaranteeing the integrity of the
system."
In 1983, when the Social Security system was in danger
of running out of money. Congress followed recommendations
of a special commission appointed by the Reagan
administration. Lawmakers raised payroll taxes and made
other adjustments so that the trust fund could deliberately
build a surplus to pay for the massive number of
retirements of baby boomers beginning in 2010.
That's the surplus that worries Democrats. Sens. Byron
Dorgan and Kent Conrad, the two North Dakota Democrats
who
helped block Senate passage of the amendment, said
Wednesday that they did so because without exempting
Social Security, future Congresses would be free to
"raid" the fund to cut the federal deficit.
Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, leader of the Republican
forces for the amendment in the Senate, called Fcinstein's
amendment "a sham" and he insisted Republicans had no
intention of raiding the Social Security system.
(Optional add end)
Intentions may collide with the reality of the numbers.
Republican plans to balance the budget with total cuts of
at least $1.2 trillion in spending by 2002 will be
difficult and painful enough.
But that figure includes using the $1 trillion surplus
in the Social Security trust fund, which means the cuts
necessary to reach
a balanced budget are closer to $2 trillion, which most
experts consider virtually impossible.
Thus, when the debate over the amendment began in the
House more than a month ago. House Judiciary Committee
Chairman Henry Hyde, R-lll., acknowledged that " i f you
exclude the receipts of Social Security from computing the
budget, then cuts necessary in other programs would be
Draconian."
Feds Plan Crackdown on Food Stamp Fraud
(Washn) By William Doiiglas= (c) 1995,
Newsday=
WASHINGTON Spurred in part by multimillion-dollar
fraud cases, the U.S. Department of Agriculture Wednesday
proposed steps to crack down on trafficking in food
stamps.
The department said it would ask Congress for
legislation that would permit tighter screening of grocery
stores applying to participate in the $25 billion program,
enhance fraud-fighting technology and stiffen the
punishment for violators.
The food stamp program, which serves more than 27
million people, has come under fire from Congress for
losing an estimated $1 billion annually to illegal
trafficking and $1.8 billion a year to fraud and mistakes
by recipients and welfare caseworkers.
House Republicans had planned to put food stamps under
state control as part of their "Contract With America"
welfare reform bill. But House Agriculture Committee
Chairman Pat Roberts, R-Kan., persuaded the Republican
leadership to keep food stamps at the federal level to
maintain a "safety net" for the poor.
About 77 percent of all food stamps are redeemed at
authorized supermarkets, but these represent only about 15
percent of all authorized stores Most illegal activity
occurs in small operations, some of which arc not real
stores at all, said Roger Viadero, the Agriculture
Department's inspector general.
In most cases, a recipient sells the food stamps for 50
cents to 70 cents on the dollar, Viadero said, and the
retailer is reimbursed the full value by the federal
government. Under the plan, which still needs sponsors in
Congress, retailers will have to prove they are legitimate
grocery markets before getting authorization to handle
food stamps. Stores may receive short-term authorizations
to join the program while USDA officials scrutinize their
records.
"They may have to wait six months while wc check them
out," Viadero said.
The department wants the authority to suspend alleged
violators more quickly when business or tax records
�indicate fraud, Acting Agriculture Secretary Richard
Romingcr said. Agriculture officials are also seeking the
power to seize assets acquired through trafficking of food
stamps.
The Agriculture Department's crackdown is, in part,
motivated by high-profile New York City fraud cases that
have cost the government tens of millions of dollars.
A two-year investigation that ended last September
revealed that 70 "owners" of non-existent stores
laundered $40 million in food stamps. Investigators said
many of the fake stores were closed during business hours,
had little or no food and even fewer customers.
Twenty-nine people were arrested and warrants were issued
for 40 others.
Dole Calls for 'New Realism' in U.S.-Russian
Relations (Washn) By Martin Kasindorf= (c)
1995, Newsday=
WASHINGTON Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole,
suggesting at a foreign affairs conference Wednesday that an
authoritarian Boris N. Yeltsin had outlived his political
usefulness, charged President Clinion with excessive
coziness toward Moscow's leader.
But Dole agreed with Clinton who spoke to the same
forum Wednesday night that the United States should
maintain world leadership despite growing isolationist
sentiment.
Dole, a Kansas Republican who plans to declare his
presidential candidacy April 10, called for a "new
realism" in U.S.-Russian relations that "does not paper
over important policy differences with an appeal to
personal ties." Dole asserted that Clinton, following a
"Russia-first policy, which has turned into a
Yeltsin-first policy," had neglected to "state American
concerns forcefully before thousands were slaughtered in
Chechnya."
Dole said it is wrong to "ignore the fact that
President Yeltsin has made serious errors, and has moved
toward authoritarian rule, and has lost the political
support of virtually all reform-minded Russians."
In a more "honest relationship," Dole said, the
United States would emphasize "the significance of
Russia's 1996 elections and the pivotal importance of a
peaceful democratic transition of power." Yeltsin is
expected to seek re-election.
Dole also asserted that Clinton is showing "timidity"
by sending U.N. Ambassador Madeleine Albright to world
capitals to lobby for continuing U.N. Security Council
sanctions against Iraq, rather than announcing that the
United States would veto any attempt to lift the
sanctions.
Clinton made no direct response to Dole's criticism in
the prepared text of his address to the conference,
sponsored by the Richard Nixon Center for Peace and
Freedom.
The president focused roughly half of his speech on the
U.S. campaign to persuade an 86-nation majority of the
signers of the 25-year-old Nuclear Non-Proliferation
Treaty to renew it indefinitely at a meeting in New York
in April.
In a display of U.S. nuclear disarmament efforts to
wavering Third World nations, Clinton announced the
removal of 200 tons of enriched uranium and plutonium
enough for "thousands of weapons," an administration
official said from U.S. military stockpiles.
Clinton argued forcefully for U.S. engagement in world
problems, indirectly attacking Republican-sponsored House
legislation that would curtail U.S. support for U.N.
peacekeeping missions and U.S. troops' involvement in such
operations.
"The new isolationists are wrong," Clinton said.
"They would have us face the future alone. We must not
let the ripple of isolationism they have generated build
into a tidal wave. I f we withdraw from the world today, we
will have to contend with the consequences of our neglect
tomorrow."
Dole, too, recognized and rejected a widespread
"eagepess to unload the burden" of involvement.
"Richard Nixon was right," Dole said. "Leadership does
not come without a price tag, but, in my view, it's a price
worth paying."
(Optional add end)
National security adviser Anthony Lake, telling
reporters that "we welcome the thrust of the senator's
speech, much of which We could have given ourselves,"
took issue with Dole over the administration's dealings
with Russia and Iraq.
Lake noted that Clinton has spoken out against Russian
military excesses in Chechnya. Acknowledging-that the war
has alienated Yeltsin from reformist allies, Lake said the
United States should act to make their reconciliation
"easier," while "making known our disagreements arid
concerns."
Dole is "misinformed" about Albright, who is carrying
a "very tough message" on Iraq and has declared that
Clinton is prepared to use a veto to keep sanctions, Lake
said.
"We do not need lectures on how to stand up against
the Iraqis," Lake said, citing Clinton's cruise-missile
retaliation for an alleged Iraqi assassination plot
against former President Bush and the dispatch of U.S.
forces when Saddam Hussein appeared ready to reinvade
Kuwait.
�Dole says Senate to vote on balanced budget
amendment Thursday By Robert Dodge Dallas
Morning News
WASHINGTON As the battle over the balanced budget
amendment took an acrimonious turn, Senate Majority Leader
Bob Dole said Wednesday he would allow senators a final
vote on the proposal Thursday.
The Kansas Republican said there had been no progress
in resolving differences with pivotal Democrats, and the
GOP was still one short of the 67 votes needed for
approval.
If the amendment fails, Dole said, he will bring it up
again shortly before the 1996 presidential election.
"We are still hopeful, we are still receptive, but
we've gone as far as we can go," said Dole, noting that
six Democrats who voted for
a balanced budget amendment last year were opposing this
year's proposal.
" I t is an interesting nip-Hop that they cannot
explain, and the American people do not understand," he
said.
Dole made his announcement after House Speaker Newt
Gingrich of Georgia drew the wrath of Senate Democrats by
accusing several of lying to constituents by promising to
end deficit spending and then opposing the balanced budget
amendment. He singled out Minority Leader Tom Daschle,
D-S.D., and Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif.
Democrats called Gingrich's behavior unseemly and
accused Republicans of trying to loot the Social Security
trust fund to balance the budget.
The discord festered early .in the day after Dole
refused to allow a vote on the balanced budget amendment
and recessed the Senate for a second lime in two days.
With pivotal Democrats refusing to support the amendment,
GOP leaders could not come up with the two-thirds majority
needed to approve a constitutional amendment.
But at the end of the day, Dole said he would allow the
Senate to vote Thursday. The amendment would require
Congress and the president lo balance the budget by 2002.
" I t never occurred to me you (would) have two senators
who lied with their states to get re-elected," Gingrich
said when asked about the Senate's failure to vote.
"She went back home, she campaigned in a very close
race, she said 'I'm for a balanced budget,'" Gingrich
said of Feinstein. "She said ' ] really am a fiscal
conservative; we really need the balanced budget.' She's
now found the skinniest and most spurious of excuses to
hide."
Asked whether there was a second liar, Gingrich
immediately pointed to Daschle. And he referred to others
without mentioning names, who voted for a balanced budget
amendment in the past when there was no chance of approval
but now had withdrawn their support.
"Apparently there are several liberal Democrats who
were for a balanced budget amendment as long as it wasn't
going to pass," he added. " I mean, how else can you
explain some of these votes?"
Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., general chairman of the
Democratic National Committee, said Gingrich's remarks had
done a "great disservice to the office he holds.
" I think this is unseemly," Dodd added. " I think it
brings dishonor to him as an individual and dishonor on
the office of the speaker. Serious senators are giving
serious consideration to one of the most serious votes
they will ever cast."
Daschle said, " I n South Dakota, we can disagree
without being disagreeable. Frankly, I am disappointed. I
would have expected more from Newt Gingrich than that."
Feinstein said she voted for the balanced budget
amendment last year and made note of that during her 1994
campaign. But she said it became clear this year that
�Republican leaders want to use Social Security payroll
taxes to cut the deficit.
" I wasn't elected by Newt Gingrich, but by
Californians," Feinstein said. "1 do not consider that 1
have lied to my constituents, because I voted for a
balanced budget amendment.
(EDITORS: STORY CAN TRIM HERE)
"I've been a mayor for nine years," the former San
Francisco leader added. " I have been Mau-Maued by the
very best in the business ... and it does not move me."
Currently, the Social Security trust fund has a
surplus.
The government's accounting methods include the surplus
in calculating the deficit, which makes Washington's red
ink look smaller. Without this year's $70 billion Social
Security surplus, the deficit would be $260 billion.
Democratic senators have said they want to make sure
the surplus is not used to reduce the deficit or mask the
size of the shortfall.
But Republicans said the best way to protect Social
Security was to stop the government's deficit spending. The Treasury already borrows from the Social Security
surplus and issues bonds to the trust fund.
Fuiure tax revenues will be required to retire those
bonds.
Without the surplus, the Republican majority on Capitol
Hill would have to find even more unpopular spending cuts
to balance the budget. And they have been under pressure
from Democrats to show how they plan to meet the 2002
goal.
"They have refused to listen to the people of this
country who have a right to know how they will balance the
budget, and most importantly, they have refused to join us
as wc insist on real protections for Social Security,"
Daschle said.
In a final effort to underscore their argument,
Democrats sent to Republicans an alternative amendment
that would protect Social Security.
"We can get more than 70 votes for a balanced budget
amendment with this proposal, and now it's up to
Republicans to prove that they won't raid Social Security
by simply putting it down in black and white," said Sen.
Ernest Hollings, D-S.C.
Republicans offered Democrats several alternatives
Tuesday to protect Social Security in separate
legislation. The various proposals failed to satisfy
Democrats who said lawmakers could easily repeal the
legislation if it was not part of the constitutional
amendment.
If the balanced budget amendment fails, it would be a
major setback for Republicans.
' The proposal is a key element the House Republican
"Contract With America." And it would be an
embarrassment for Dole, who is seeking the 1996 GOP
presidential nomination.
Republicans portrayed Thursday's vote as among the most
important lawmakers will face. They said it was an
opportunity to protect the financial of future
generations.
"We will determine once and for all who is for and who
is against
a balanced budget amendment," said Sen. Orrin Hatch,
R-Utah.
Clinton acknowledges failure in Colombia, but
doesn't urge sanctions By David L. Marcus
Dallas Morning News
WASHINGTON President Clinton formally criticized the
anti-drug efforts of four South American countries
Wednesday in an admission that America's overseas fight
against narcotics trafficking is failing.
While acknowledging setbacks in Colombia, Peru, Bolivia
and Paraguay, Clinton asked Congress not to impose
economic sanctions against the countries.
Clinton's announcement, made by the White House and the
State Department, concluded a debate over the
"certification" process that has raged for weeks.
"This tough approach makes it clear again this year
that counternarcotics is crucial to U.S. foreign policy
and our bilateral relations," said drug czar Lee Brown.
Every year the administration evaluates the efforts of
27 countries that produce and ship illegal drugs. After
being measured against standards in U.S. laws and a U.N.
international drug accord, they can be certified or
decertified. Or they can be given conditional approval
because they represent a "vital national security
interest" as in the case of the four South American
countries and Lebanon and Pakistan.
Clinton urged the harshest action against Iran,
Nigeria, Syria, Afghanistan and Burma. They will be denied
U.S. aid, and American representatives to the World Bank
and other agencies must vote against their requests for
loans.
A lengthy State Department report on the international
narcotics situation described Colombia as having a
"lackluster" counternarcotics performance in 1994.
"Weak legislation, corruption and inefficiency
hampered efforts to bring mid- and high-level narcotics
traffickers to justice," the report said. "No
drug-related assets were forfeited, while already lenient
sentences were further reduced pursuant to automatic
sentencing reductions."
Arguing that cocaine production is soaring and
"narco-corruption" is spreading, a few influential
officials said they urged the White House to take harsher
actions against several Latin American countries. Those
present at the discussions said the most controversial
decision involved Colombia, the world's leading producer
and distributor of cocaine and the fastest-growing
producer of heroin.
Wednesday's action marked the first time that Colombia
once considered Washington's best ally in the drug fight
was not fully certified for its actions.
Colombian officials in recent weeks have said the
United States is hypocritical because it complains about
the supply of drugs from overseas, but has had little
success in curbing demand at home.
Bogota already turned its attention to the U.S.
Congress, which has
a month to approve or change Clinton's recommendations.
Colombia has hired two lobbyists with Republican
connections, and a source said it is screening another
lobbying firm.
Colombian officials said they are most worried about
two members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee,
Sen. Jesse Helms, the chairman, and Sen. John Kerry, who
has held hearings on drugs and terrorism.
Both denounced President Ernesto Samper last summer
after secretly recorded conversations of Cali drug bosses
were made public. The bosses spoke about donating $3.8
million to the Samper campaign in the closing days of a
tight race.
Samper denied receiving "hot money" and opened his
books to reporters. A prosecutqr cleared the campaign of
any wrongdoing. But two officials who worked with former
President Cesar Gaviria told The Dallas Morning News that
Samper campaign workers in several closely contested
regions spoke of an infusion of cash from unknown sources
in the campaign's final days.
This week, Helms demanded that the United States revoke
visas from "Colombian officials, regardless of rank, who
are implicated in narco-corruption" a warning to Samper,
according to a Helms spokesman.
